Editor's note- Section 4-6 is derived from and has been amended by the ordinances listed in the history note following said section. The extent of the amendment precludes editorial analysis. 
 Ord. No. 2009-02, § 1, adopted February 2, 2009, changed the title of section 4-6 from "Areas where sale of beer permitted for consumption on premises" to "Areas where sale of beer and wine permitted for consumption on premises." 
Sec. 4-7. - Hours for sale of beer and wine. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell beer, or offer the same for sale, for on-premises consumption: 
(1)  On Sunday at any time between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday following. 
(2)  On any day except Sunday at any time between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  Provided however that the provisions of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code providing that the holder of a retail dealer's on-premises late hours license allowing extended hours and Sunday sales of beer and wine for on-premises consumption in public places until 2:00 a.m. are hereby adopted by the city. The penalty for violation of this subsection shall be the same as provided by state law. 
(c)  The sale of beer shall be allowed for off-premises consumption on Sunday between the hours of 12:00 noon and 12:00 midnight by the holder of a retail dealer's off-premises license. 
(Ord. No. 235, § 2, 12-18-61; Ord. No. 556, § 1, 11-18-74; Ord. No. 582, § 2, 12-16-75; Ord. No. 585, § 2, 1-26-76; Ord. No. 84-23, §§ 1, 3, 12-17-84) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate hours of beer sales, V.T.C.A. Alcoholic Beverage Code, § 109.32(a)(2). 
Sec. 4-8. - Hours of consumption-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage in any public place, or for any person to possess any alcoholic beverage in any public place for the purpose of consuming the same in such public place, at any time on Sunday between the hours of 1:15 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following Monday morning, and on all other days at any time between the hours of 12:15 a.m. and 7:00 a.m.; provided, however, that hours of consumption of beer and wine shall be subject to the time limitations set out in section 105.06(c) of the state Alcoholic Beverage Code. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 87-06, § 2, 3-9-87) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, V.T.C.A. Alcoholic Beverage Code, § 105.06. 
Sec. 4-9. - Same-Private clubs. 
    In the City of Groves the holders of private club registration permits or licenses or the holders of mixed beverage permits or licenses for private clubs or public places under the Texas Liquor Control Act shall be governed and controlled by the provisions of said act, and regulations thereunder. 
    The provisions of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code providing that the holder of a private club late hours permit may allow persons to consume or be served alcoholic beverages on club premises until 2:00 a.m. are hereby adopted by the City of Groves. The penalty for violation of this section shall be the same as provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 477, § 1, 4-24-72; Ord. No. 581, § 2, 12-16-75; Ord. No. 586, §§ 2-4, 1-26-76; Ord. No. 84-23, §§ 1, 3, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 4-10. - Consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages on street, sidewalk or park prohibited unless permitted by special event temporary permit. 
    Unless a special event temporary permit has been granted by the city council, it shall be unlawful to consume, or to possess for the purpose of consumption' any alcoholic beverage (as defined by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, or subsequent amendments thereto), while on any street, sidewalk or other public way, or in any park in the city. 
    Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the provisions of section 1-5. 
(Ord. No. 2009-02, §§ 2, 3, 2-2-09) 
Secs. 4-11-4-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3, Ord. No. 87-06, adopted Mar. 9, 1987, repealed §§ 4-10-4-18, relative to drunkenness, intoxication and consumption, sale, purchase and possession of alcoholic beverages and unlawful conduct on premises where sold. Such sections contained no historical notation and are presumed adopted with the adoption of this Code. 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation generally, Ch. 13; application of traffic regulations to person riding animals or driving animal drawn vehicles, § 25-6. 
State Law reference- Duties of officers, V.T.C.A. Agric. Code, §§ 143.031, 143.080; sale of impounded stock, §§ 143.029, 143.032, 143.081, fees for sale of impounded stock, § 143.031. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Report of rabid animals. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or harborer of any animal, and any practicing veterinarian, to report to the city health officer all cases of rabies with which he comes into contact or to which his attention has been directed. This report shall be made immediately upon diagnosis or suspicion of such cases of rabies. 
Sec. 5-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in a sum not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) 
(Ord. No. 538, § 8, 4-8-74) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 538, § 8, adopted April 8, 1974, amended § 5-101 by making the penalty provisions applicable to the entire Chapter 5, whereas formerly § 5-101 set out the penalty for violation of Art. VI only. In this regard the editors, at their discretion, have deleted said former § 5-101 and designated the provisions of § 8 of Ord. No. 538 as new § 5-2 in order to preserve Code format. 
Sec. 5-3. - Snakes and other reptiles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any snake or other reptile in captivity on any premises in the City of Groves except in a cage or other enclosure constructed in such a manner as to prevent their escape therefrom. 
(b)  Any person who keeps or harbors any snake or other reptile in captivity on any premises in the City of Groves shall not allow any such snake or reptile outside a cage or other enclosure at any time. 
(c)  Any snake or other reptile found outside a cage or other enclosure may be captured or destroyed by any police officer or humane officer of the city whether on private or public property. 
(Ord. No. 559, §§ 1-3, 3-10-75) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 559, §§ 1-3, adopted March 10, 1975, being nonamendatory of this Code, was codified as § 5-3 at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 5-4. - Keeping wild animals within the city. 
(a)  Definition. A "wild animal" shall mean and include any mammal, amphibian, reptile or fowl, which is of a species which is wild by nature, and of a species which, due to size, vicious nature, or other characteristic, is dangerous to human beings. Such animals shall include, but not be limited to, lions, tigers, leopards, panthers, ocelots, wildcats, bears, wolves, raccoons, skunks (whether deodorized or not), apes, gorillas, monkeys, foxes, elephants, rhinoceros, alligators, crocodiles, and all forms of poisonous reptiles. The term "wild animals," as used in this section, shall not include gerbils, hamsters, guinea pigs, mice, or rabbits. 
(b)  Nonapplicability to veterinary treatment. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the keeping of wild animals for treatment in a facility operated by a veterinarian licensed by the State of Texas. 
(c)  Prohibition; exception. It shall be unlawful within the corporate boundaries of the city for a person or persons to possess, keep, or maintain any wild animal; except, that such possessing, keeping, or maintaining by circuses, zoos, or educational institutions for purposes of study or exhibition, in accordance with such regulations as shall be established, is not prohibited. 
(d)  Enforcement. The city humane officer or any police officer shall seize all animals found in violation of this section and impound all such animals at the city animal shelter or in a facility operated by a veterinarian licensed by the State of Texas. If within seven (7) days the owner of such animal does not locate a facility for housing the animal outside the city limits, said animal shall be destroyed. 
(e)  Fees. If the wild animal is impounded in the city animal shelter, the impoundment fee shall be the same as provided in section 5-47 of the Code of Ordinances. If, however, the animal is impounded in a facility operated by a veterinarian as provided herein, the owner shall pay a fifty dollar ($50.00) impoundment fee to the city and shall pay the veterinarian his usual and customary charges for such services. 
(Ord. No. 83-03, § 1, 3-14-83) 
Cross reference- Impoundment fees set out, § 5-47. 
Sec. 5-5. - Disposal fee for large and small household pets in city crematoriums. 
    The following fees shall be charged for the disposal of household pets in the city crematorium of the City of Groves: 
(1)  Small household pets ..... $1.00 
(2)  Large household pets ..... 2.00 
(Ord. No. 91-01, § 1, 1-21-91) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 91-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 21, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as § 5-5 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 5-6-5-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIVESTOCK AND DOMESTIC FOWL 

Sec. 5-12. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Domestic fowl shall mean and include any or all of the following: chickens, ducks, geese, guineas, peafowl, turkeys, or any other fowl, owned or possessed by or under the control of any person. 
    Livestock shall mean and include any or all of the following: horses, mules, colts, jacks, jennets, cows, bulls, calves, sheep, goats, swine or other domesticated animals, except common household pets. 
(Ord. No. 183, § 1, 12-21-59) 
Cross reference- General definitions and rules of construction, § 1-3. 
Sec. 5-13. - Livestock not to run at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any livestock owned, kept, or under the control or care of any person to run at large within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 1, 4-8-74) 
State Law reference- Stock running at large, V.T.C.A. Agric. Code, §§ 143.029, 143.032, 143.017 et seq. 
Sec. 5-14. - Staking of livestock restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any livestock to be tied or staked upon any open or unfenced lot or land within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 183, § 4, 12-21-59) 
Sec. 5-15. - Keeping livestock and domestic fowl restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep, feed, breed, stable, pasture, herd or maintain any livestock on or in any lot, pen, building, parcel of land, stable or other enclosure in the city; or to keep, feed, breed or maintain domestic fowl on or in any lot, pen, building, parcel of land or other enclosure in the city, any part of which enclosure is nearer than seventy-five (75) feet to a building which is occupied by any person for residential or business purposes. 
(Ord. No. 183, § 3, 12-21-59; Ord. No. 393, § 2(4), 8-19-68; Ord. No. 406, § 1, 12-9-68; Ord. No. 94-16, § 1, 12-5-94) 
Sec. 5-16. - Maintenance of premises where kept. 
    Any person owning or keeping any livestock or domestic fowl within the city shall be required to keep such livestock or domestic fowl adequately penned in an enclosure sufficiently secure to prevent escape therefrom. 
    Each such enclosure shall be maintained in a sanitary condition subject to the approval of the health officer. 
    Each place used for feeding, stabling, pasturing or keeping any livestock or domestic fowl shall be kept free from offensive odors, flies, rodents and other pests. 
(Ord. No. 183, § 3, 12-21-59) 
Cross reference- Ratproofing of feed storage required, § 13-37; electric fence prohibited, § 16-13. 
Sec. 5-17. - Compliance with technical provisions required. 
    Any building, pen, storage bin, or other structure used or constructed for the feeding, stabling, maintaining or keeping of any livestock or domestic fowl shall conform with the applicable provisions of the building, electrical and plumbing codes of the city. 
Cross reference- Building code, Ch. 28; electrical code, Ch. 29, plumbing code, Ch. 31. 
Sec. 5-18. - Disposal of dead livestock. 
    The carcass of any livestock dead of disease or other cause not slaughtered for food shall be removed and/or disposed of by the owner, at his own expense, within twenty-four (24) hours after such death, according to such method as may be approved by the health officer. 
Cross reference- Disposal of animal wastes and dead animals, § 12-14. 
Sec. 5-19. - Domestic fowl not to run at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any domestic fowl owned, kept, or under the control or care of any person to run at large within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 2, 4-8-74) 
Sec. 5-20. - Keeping of gamefowl and gamecocks. 
(a)  This section shall not be construed to authorize the fighting of gamecocks, since the causing of one animal to fight with another is prohibited by V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, organization, group or association to keep or maintain any gamecock in such a manner than such fowl, by crowing or otherwise, creates such a noise as to cause serious disturbance, annoyance or inconvenience to persons residing in the vicinity and interferes with the reasonable and comfortable use and enjoyment of their property. 
(c)  All gamefowl or gamecocks shall be penned, staked or fenced to prevent the fowl from running at large as prohibited by section 5-19. 
(d)  No gamefowl or gamecock shall be kept, possessed or maintained within three hundred (300) feet of any residence or building used for human habitation (other than that of the keeper or owner of such fowl), any business, church, school or hospital. The distance of three hundred (300) feet shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest point of the pen, gamecock, game fowl or fence to the nearest point of such building used for human habitation, business, church, school or hospital. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, possess or maintain more than five (5) gamecock or gamefowl on any premises in the city unless that premises has at least one acre (43,560) square feet of area. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person living in the city to keep more than ten (10) gamecock or gamefowl per premises unless that person has at least five (5) acres (217,800 square feet) of land. 
(Ord. No. 2009-06, § 1, 3-16-09) 
Sec. 5-21. - Chickens, ducks and fowl numbers limited; pools prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, possess or maintain chickens, ducks or fowl within the city, except when the chickens, ducks or fowl are fenced in, and coops, pens or cages are provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, possess or maintain any such fowl within three hundred (300) feet of any residence or building used for human habitation (other than that of the keeper or owner of such fowl), any business, church, school or hospital. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person living in the city to keep a combination of no more than five (5) chickens, ducks or fowl on any premises in a residential district unless that premises has at least one acre (43,560) square feet of area. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person living in the city to keep more than ten (10) chickens, ducks or fowl per premises unless that person has at least five (5) acres (217,800 square feet) of land. Duck or waterfowl pools are prohibited within the city. 
(e)  All droppings from coops, pens, cages, yards and other enclosures shall be removed regularly, and disposal of the excretions shall be handled in such manner as to keep the premises free of any public health nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2009-06, § 1, 3-16-09) 
Sec. 5-22. - Nuisances declared. 
    The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent or long-continued noise, disturbs the comfort and repose of any person of ordinary sensibilities in the immediate vicinity is declared a nuisance and is in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2009-06, § 1, 3-16-09) 
Secs. 5-23-5-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WILD FOWL 

Sec. 5-30. - Bird sanctuary created. 
    The area within the city is hereby designated as and declared to be a bird sanctuary. 
(Ord. No. 198, § 1, 1-25-60) 
Sec. 5-31. - Destroying or molesting wild fowl prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot, or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird or wild fowl nests within the city. 
(Ord. No. 198, § 2, 1-25-60) 
Sec. 5-32. - Congregating of birds declared nuisance; meeting with bird and garden clubs required; emergency power in city marshal. 
(a)  If starlings, pigeons or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality so as to constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property in the opinion of the health authorities of the city, such health authorities shall meet with representatives of the Audubon Society, Bird Club, Garden Club or Humane Society, after having given at least three (3) days' notice of the time and place of such meeting to the representatives of such clubs. 
(b)  If at the meeting required in subsection (a) of this section no satisfactory means of dispersing such congregation of birds is found, such birds may be destroyed in such manner as is deemed advisable by the health authorities under the supervision of the city marshal. 
(c)  If in the opinion of the city marshal an emergency exists making it impossible or impracticable to give such notice to the various clubs and societies, the city marshal is hereby authorized, in his/her discretion, to take any action, including the destruction of such birds, to protect the health and welfare of the community, without such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 198, §§ 2, 3, 1-25-60) 
Secs. 5-33-5-42. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY POUND 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-43. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a city pound. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 1, 9-13-65) 
Sec. 5-44. - Poundmaster appointed; duties; compensation. 
    The city manager shall appoint, for a period to be terminated at his discretion, a qualified person as city poundmaster, who shall enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 326, § 1, 9-13-65) 
Sec. 5-45. - Impoundment of animals, fowl. 
    Any animal or fowl except household pets, which may be found in violation of any provision of this chapter or other applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance, within the city shall be impounded by any authorized officer of the city. 
Sec. 5-46. - Duty of poundmaster upon impoundment. 
    The poundmaster shall deliver to the owner, after proper evidence of ownership is given him, each animal or fowl impounded by him under the provisions of section 5-45, provided that such owner shall pay all charges which may have accrued against such animal or fowl. 
Sec. 5-47. - Impoundment fees. 
    A pound fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged against each animal or fowl which may be impounded under the provisions of section 5-45, and an additional charge of four dollars ($4.00) shall be made against each such animal or fowl for each day or part of a day after the first day which such animal or fowl may be impounded. 
(Ord. No. 393, § 2(5), 8-19-68; Ord. No. 723, § 1, 10-13-80) 
Sec. 5-48. - Sale of unredeemed, impounded animals-Authorized, notice. 
    After the expiration of three (3) days after any animal or fowl may have been impounded, if the owner of such animal or fowl shall not have appeared and redeemed such animal or fowl, the poundmaster shall advertise the same for sale at public auction on a date not earlier than three (3) days after the first publication of such advertisement. Each such advertisement shall describe the animal or fowl to be sold as clearly as possible, shall name the date on which such animal or fowl was impounded, shall state the amount of the pound fees which have accrued against such animal or fowl, and shall name a definite date and hour at which the same is to be sold. All notices of sales of impounded animals or fowl shall be posted for the full period of three (3) days at some public place within the city, one of which places shall be the city hall, another the public pound, and the third shall be at some place which the poundmaster may select. 
(Ord. No. 504, § 1, 6-18-73) 
Sec. 5-49. - Same-Procedure. 
    At each sale of unredeemed, impounded animals or fowl, the poundmaster shall sell for cash only and to the highest bidder and shall deliver to the purchaser a bill of sale in the name of the city which shall have impressed thereon by the city clerk the corporate seal of the city, and shall be signed by both the city clerk and the poundmaster. 
Sec. 5-50. - Same-Disposition of receipts. 
    In the event of the sale of any animal or fowl which has been impounded under the provisions of section 5-45, the poundmaster shall deduct from the price of said animal or fowl obtained at such sale the full amount of such lawful fees and charges as shall have accrued prior to the sale. The remainder of such sale price shall be delivered by the poundmaster to the city clerk. Such money so paid to the treasurer shall be held by the clerk in a separate account for a period of one year from the date of such sale, and if the owner of any animal or fowl so sold shall appear within the year and establish his ownership to the satisfaction of the treasurer, the full amount so held shall be delivered to such claimant upon his executing a receipt for the amount and a full release of all claim against the city for the value of the animal or fowl. In the event that such money be not claimed within one year by a person who can show his ownership, then the full amount of such money shall be placed in the general fund of the city. 
Sec. 5-51. - Records to be kept by poundmaster. 
    The poundmaster shall keep a book in which he shall carefully record the following information concerning each animal or fowl which may be impounded therein, to wit: 
(a)  The date on which such animal or fowl was impounded; 
(b)  The name of the owner, if known; 
(c)  A full and clear description of the animal or fowl; 
(d)  The date on which such animal or fowl was discharged from the pound; 
(e)  The name of the person to whom delivered; 
(f)  The date on which such animal or fowl was advertised for sale; 
(g)  The places where notice of sale were posted; 
(h)  The number of days that notices were posted before sale; 
(i)  The price at which such animal or fowl was sold; 
(j)  The person to whom sold and his place of residence; 
(k)  The amount of charges accrued against such animal or fowl before sale; 
(l)  The amount of charges accrued before delivery to owner. 
Sec. 5-52. - Liability of owners of impounded animals or fowl. 
    The payment of pound fees shall not exempt the owner or person in control of any animals or fowl impounded from prosecution under the provisions of this chapter. 
Sec. 5-53. - Destruction of animals, fowl. 
    If at the time of the sale of any animal or fowl that may have been impounded, no purchaser can be found for such animal or fowl, the poundmaster shall kill or otherwise destroy or dispose of such animal or fowl. 
Sec. 5-54. - Confinement of rabid animals. 
(a)  Any animal or household pet that has rabies or symptoms thereof that is suspected of having rabies, or that has been exposed to rabies, shall at once be released by its possessor for disposal or confinement in a veterinary hospital approved by the city health officer, or immediately and securely confined by typing with a chain of good quality and kept there under the supervision of the department of health and sanitation for a period of not less than ten (10) days. 
(b)  Every animal or pet that has rabies or symptoms thereof, or any animal that bites, scratches or otherwise attacks any person shall be immediately quarantined and held for ten (10) days in any veterinary hospital approved by the city health officer, or shall be held at the city pound for ten (10) days. After such ten day period of time if the animal or pet has not been redeemed by the owner, or if it has rabies, it shall be destroyed at the city pound. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 12, 7-2-62; Ord. No. 444, § 1, 2-1-71) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 444, § 1, amended § 5-54(b) pertaining to the same subject matter to read as hereinabove set out. 
Ord. No. 44, § 2, provided: 
"Section 2. Penalty for violation of this ordinance shall be the same as provided in Section 5-101 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Groves, Texas." 
Sec. 5-55. - Payment of pound fees. 
    Every owner of any animal, including household pets, impounded, whether by the city or voluntarily by the owner, shall be liable for all costs and fees incurred by such impoundment or confinement and testing. 
Sec. 5-56. - Fees collected to be paid to city clerk. 
    The poundmaster shall collect all fees and other moneys required to be paid under the provisions of this article and shall pay all such fees and other moneys to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 11, 6-2-62) 
Secs. 5-57-5-61. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT OF PETS 

Sec. 5-62. - Authorized. 
    Any household pet found in violation of any applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation shall be taken up and impounded by the poundmaster or any other authorized officer or employee of the city. The poundmaster shall provide suitable and necessary sustenance for all pets impounded under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 8, 7-2-62) 
Sec. 5-63. - Impoundment fees. 
(a)  Impoundment. 
(1)  The following fees shall be charged for the impoundment of any pet under the provisions of this division: 
    Licensed dog ..... $40.00 
    Unlicensed dog ..... 60.00 
    Other pets ..... 40.00 
(2)  If any licensed dog, unlicensed dog or other pet shall be impounded a second time, within sixty (60) days of the first impoundment, the impoundment fee shall be twice the fee set out in subsection (1) above. 
(3)  If any licensed dog, unlicensed dog or other pet shall be impounded a third time, within sixty (60) days of the first impoundment, the impoundment fee shall be three (3) times the fee set out in subsection (1) above. 
(b)  Feeding. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day shall be charged for the feeding, care and handling of each pet impounded under the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 472, § 1, 2-28-72; Ord. No. 504, § 2, 6-18-73; Ord. No. 723, § 2, 10-13-80; Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 5-24-93; Ord. No. 06-22, § 1, 12-11-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 472, § 3, provided: "Section 3. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in a sum not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00)." 
Sec. 5-64. - Redemption-Right, conditions. 
    The owner of any pet which has been impounded under the provisions of this division shall have the right to redeem the same upon the payment of any and all fees which may be due and payable for the impoundment of such pet. 
    The owner of any impounded pet may, within thirty (30) days after such dog [pet] is sold, redeem the same from the purchaser by paying to him the amount of the purchase price paid by him to the poundmaster, and in addition thereto the licensing fee and the vaccination charges, if any were incurred, and in addition thereto a charge of one dollar ($1.00) per day for the number of days from the date of sale to the day of redemption. At the end of thirty (30) days from the date the pet is sold, the right to redeem shall expire. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 8, 7-2-62) 
Sec. 5-65. - Same-Time. 
    All impounded pets shall be redeemed within the length of time set forth below. Any such pet not redeemed within such time may be sold or destroyed. 
    Licensed dog ..... 5 days 
    Unlicensed dog ..... 3 days 
    Other pets ..... 3 days 
(Ord. No. 249, §§ 8, 9, 7-2-62) 
Sec. 5-66. - Redeemed dogs and cats must be vaccinated. 
    All dogs and cats redeemed at the pound must be immediately vaccinated against rabies. 
Sec. 5-67. - Records of impoundment. 
    The poundmaster, upon receiving any pet, shall make a complete registry, entering the breed, color, sex and species of such pet together with a statement of whether such pet, if a dog, is licensed or not, and the time and place of taking into custody. If such pet be licensed, the poundmaster shall enter the name and address of the owner and the number of the license tag upon such registry. In addition to such records, the poundmaster shall also keep necessary records as are required to show in detail the disposition of all pets impounded and the money collected by him and other records as are required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 10, 7-2-62) 
Sec. 5-68. - Sale, destruction. 
    At any time after the expiration of the period of time for redemption of impounded pets shall have expired, the poundmaster may, without further notice and without advertising in any manner, sell at private sale or public auction, for cash, any dog not redeemed or reclaimed. All pets impounded and not redeemed, reclaimed or sold after the period of time for redemption has expired, shall forthwith be humanely destroyed by the poundmaster. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 9, 7-2-62) 
Sec. 5-69. - Reports. 
    The poundmaster shall file such reports under oath as are required by the city manager or city council. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 10, 7-2-62) 
Sec. 5-70. - Licensed dogs to be kept separate. 
    All licensed dogs impounded under the provisions of this division shall be kept separated from unlicensed dogs and other pets at all times. 
Sec. 5-71-5-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, adopted Dec. 11, 2006, repealed article V, sections 5-81-5-95, in its entirety and replaced it with a new article V, sections 5-81-5-95. Former article V pertained to similar material and derived from Ord. No. 249, §§ 1, 3-6, 13, 14, adopted July 2, 1962; Ord. No. 472, § 2, adopted Feb. 28, 1972; Ord. No. 538, §§ 3-7, adopted April 8, 1974; Ord. No. 87-07, § 1, adopted March 9, 1987. 

Sec. 5-81. - License-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to own, keep, possess, or harbor upon premises under his control, any dog, male or female, without having obtained a license therefor as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-82. - Same-When not required. 
    The provisions of this article requiring a licensing of dogs shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Dogs under the age of six (6) months if kept within a sufficient enclosure. 
(2)  Dogs owned by or in custody or under the control of persons who are not residents of the city but who are traveling through said city or temporarily sojourning therein for a period not exceeding twenty (20) days. 
(3)  Dogs brought to the city exclusively for the purpose of entering or exhibiting same in any dog show, and which are actually entered in and kept at said show for exhibition. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-83. - Same-Fee. 
    There shall be an annual fee of one dollar ($1.00) charged for each animal license for each dog. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-84. - Same-Duration. 
    The dog license required under the provisions of this article shall be issued for a period of one (1) year and must be obtained on or before the first day of January of each year. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-85. - Proof of rabies vaccination required. 
(a)  Each owner of a dog shall have such dog vaccinated against rabies by the time such dog is four (4) months of age and at regular intervals thereafter as prescribed by rules of the state board of health. 
(b)  No license shall be issued for any dog owned, kept, possessed, harbored or allowed upon the premises of any person and under his control unless said dog shall have been vaccinated against rabies within twelve (12) months prior to the issuance of such license by a veterinarian licensed to practice in the state. 
(c)  There shall be delivered to the poundmaster of the city, prior to the issuance of such license, a certificate signed by such veterinarian, stated that the dog has been duly vaccinated and giving the date of vaccination therefor. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-86. - License-Tags. 
(a)  Issuance. Upon payment of the license fee required, it shall be the duty of the poundmaster to furnish the owner of such animal a license number and durable tag of a distinctive design, on one (1) side of which is stamped the words "fee paid" with the year for which the same is paid and the serial number of the tag, which tag shall at all times be securely attached to a collar around the neck of the dog or to a harness around the neck and body of the dog. 
(b)  Duplicates. In the event of loss or destruction of any dog tag issued by the city, and upon proper and satisfactory proof to the city of such loss or destruction, and upon proper application to the city with payment of a fee of fifty cents ($0.50) the city shall issue a substitute dog tag to replace the one so lost or destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-87. - Same-Removal of tag prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any tag issued under the provisions of this article from any dog without the written consent of the owner of such dog. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-88. - Register of licenses. 
    The poundmaster shall keep a register of all licenses issued under the provisions of this article in which shall be entered the name of the applicant, description of the dog, the numbers of the license and tag issued, and the date of issuance and expiration. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-89. - "At large" defined. 
    For the purpose of this article, the phrase "to run at large" shall mean to go free, or be free, with or without the knowledge of the owner, on private or public property outside of a secure enclosure and with a lease securely attached to the dog and being held by a person of competent strength to hold and control such dog, or securely fastened in a manner to cause such dog to be unable to leave the property. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-90. - Running at large prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any dog owned, kept or under the control or care of any person, whether licensed or not, to run at large within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-91. - Dangerous dogs. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "dangerous dog" means a dog that: 
(1)  Has inflicted severe injury or death to a person or bites a person other than the owner or a member of the owner's immediate family, without provocation on public or private property. 
(2)  Has killed or severely injured a domestic animal without provocation while off the owner's property. 
(3)  Has a known or apparent propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of persons or domestic animals; or 
(4)  Is trained or harbored for fighting which may be determined based on whether the dog exhibits behavior and/or bears physical scars or injuries which indicate that the animal has been trained or used for the purpose of fighting. 
(b)  If a dog acts as stated in subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section or is trained or harbored for fighting, the animal control officer shall impound the dog immediately if it is at large; or if it is in the possession of some person, the animal control officer may issue a notice requiring that the dog be taken to a designated location for impoundment. A dog that is impounded shall not be released until a final determination is made of the disposition of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-91.1. - Declaration of dangerous dog. 
(a)  The animal control officer may declare a dog to be a dangerous dog if the official has sufficient cause to believe that the animal is dangerous as defined under subsection 5-91(a). 
(b)  Within five (5) working days of declaring a dog to be a dangerous dog, written notice shall be given to the owner that the animal control officer has determined that the animal is a dangerous dog. This notice shall also set out the requirements for a dangerous dog with which the owner must comply as set forth in section 5-91.2. This notice shall be given to the owner by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. In the event that personal delivery or certified mail, return receipt requested, cannot be delivered, is refused, or is unclaimed, the animal control officer may then give notice by first class mail. Receipt of notice sent by first class mail is deemed to be two (2) working days after the letter is postmarked and deposited in the mail. 
(c)  The owner of a dog declared to be a dangerous dog may appeal the determination of the animal control officer. Appeal of the animal control officer's determination is accomplished by filing a written request for a determination hearing with the municipal court no later than five (5) working days from receipt of the written notice referenced in subsection 5-91.1(b). Failure to appeal the declaration by filing a written request for a determination hearing with the municipal court within five (5) working days from the owner's receipt of the written notice described in subsection 5-91.1(b) shall result in the animal control officer's declaration as being final. 
(d)  If the owner of a dangerous dog cannot be determined after reasonable efforts to do so and after holding the dog for seventy-two (72) hours, the animal may be disposed of in a humane manner. If the owner of a dangerous dog that has been impounded is known, but cannot be located for service of the notice required herein either in person or by mail, the animal may be disposed of in a humane manner after a reasonable effort has been made to locate such owner. Nothing herein shall be construed to require the city to hold the dangerous dog longer than seventy-two (72) hours because it is unclaimed. 
(e)  Determination hearing. 
(1)  Upon written request for a determination hearing by the owner of a dog declared dangerous, the animal control officer shall schedule said hearing with the municipal court. The determination hearing shall be conducted by the municipal court judge within the ten (10) days of receipt of the request of such a hearing. The owner shall be notified of said hearing by first class mail. Failure of the owner to appear at the determination hearing shall in no way prevent the municipal court judge from proceeding with the hearing. The decision of the municipal court judge shall be the final administrative determination by the city. 
(2)  Pending the outcome of the determination hearing, the dog must be securely confined in the animal control facility or, at the request of the owner of the dog, with a licensed veterinarian. The costs of securing the dog at the animal control facility or with a licensed veterinarian pending the determination hearing shall be borne by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-91.2. - Requirements for owner of a dangerous dog. 
(a)  No later than fifteen (15) days after a dog is declared dangerous, the owner must comply with all of the following requirements before the subject animal can be released to the owner by animal control: 
(1)  Register the animal as a dangerous dog with the animal control officer. The cost of registration shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. 
(2)  Obtain and maintain liability insurance coverage or show financial responsibility in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to cover damages resulting from an attack by a dangerous dog causing bodily injury to a person or for damages to any person's property resulting from the keeping of such dangerous dog. A certificate of insurance or other evidence of meeting the above requirements shall be filed with the city animal control officer before said dangerous dog shall be returned to the owner if it is being held by the city or a veterinarian. 
(3)  Restrain the dangerous dog at all times on a secure leash in the immediate control of a person or in a secure enclosure. The enclosure must have secure sides, a secure top attached to the sides, and a secure bottom which is either attached to the sides or else the sides of the structure must be embedded in the ground no less than two (2) feet. 
In addition, the secure enclosure must be: 
a.  Locked; 
b.  Capable of preventing the escape or release of the dog; and 
c.  Clearly marked as containing a dangerous dog. 
(4)  The owner shall post a sign on his premises warning that there is a "dangerous dog on the property." This sign shall be visible and capable of being read from the public street or highway. In addition, the area where the animal is kept must be kept secure from small children gaining access. 
(5)  The dangerous dog, when taken outside the enclosure, must be securely muzzled in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal nor interfere with its vision or respiration, but shall prevent it from biting any person or animal. 
(6)  A dangerous dog may not be chained to any object outside of a secure enclosure either on or off the property of the owner. 
(7)  If the owner of a dangerous dog is unable or unwilling to comply with the ownership requirements listed above at any time, the animal must be euthanized in a humane manner by the city animal control officer or a licensed veterinarian or removed from the city. A dangerous dog shall not be offered for adoption or sale within the city unless the new owner is willing to comply and does comply with the provisions of this section. Transfer of the dangerous dog to a new owner must be approved by the municipal court judge. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-91.3. - Report significant events. 
    The owner of a dangerous dog shall as soon as possible report to the animal control officer any of the following events: 
(1)  The escape of the animal; 
(2)  An attack or biting of a person or other animal; 
(3)  Change of location within the city; 
(4)  Permanent removal of the dog from the city; or 
(5)  Death of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-91.4. - Exceptions. 
(a)  No dog shall be declared a dangerous dog if: 
(1)  The threat, injury or damage caused by the animal was the result of a willful trespass upon another's property, or the person injured was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal or its owner, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime at the time of injury unless other independent grounds exist for such a declaration; or 
(2)  The sole cause of the attack was that the animal was injured and responding to pain. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs under the control of law enforcement or military. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-92. - Destruction of dangerous dogs. 
    Any dangerous dog found at large after the owner thereof has previous knowledge or notice that such dog is dangerous, may be killed by any police officer of the city without such officer having to catch or impound such dog. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-93. - Confinement during estrus. 
    Any female dog in the stage of estrus (heat) shall be confined during such period of time in a house, building, or secure enclosure. Such areas of enclosure shall be so constructed that no other dog may gain access to the confined animal. Owners who do not comply shall be ordered to remove the animal in heat to a boarding kennel, veterinary hospital or the city animal shelter. All expenses incurred as a result of the confinement shall be paid by the owner. Failure to comply with the removal order of the animal control officer shall be a violation of this article and the dog will then be impounded. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-94. - Maintenance of premises where dogs kept. 
    Any person keeping one (1) or more dogs within the city shall be required to maintain the area in which said dog or dogs are kept in a sanitary condition subject to the approval of the poundmaster. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 5-95. - Issuance of citations. 
    The animal control officer may issue a citation for a violation of this chapter. The citation shall include: the name of the accused; the nature of the violation; the ordinance section violated; the date and location of the violation; that a complaint will be filed in the municipal court of the city; and that the person cited must appear at municipal within fourteen (14) days from the date shown on the citation, and shall be signed by the officer. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-11-06) 
ARTICLE VI. - CATS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Article VI, §§ 5-96-5-101, is derived from Ord. No. 418, §§ 1-6, enacted Sept. 5, 1969. This ordinance did not amend this Code. 

Sec. 5-96. - Vaccination against rabies. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to own, keep, possess, harbor, or to allow to remain upon premises under his control, any cat that has not been vaccinated against rabies by a veterinarian duly licensed to practice in the State of Texas by the time such cat is four (4) months of age and at regular intervals thereafter as prescribed by rules of the state board of health. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 1, 9-8-69; Ord. No. 87-07, § 2, 3-9-87) 
Sec. 5-97. - Impoundment of cats running at large without vaccination tag. 
    Any cat running at large without a vaccination tag attached to its collar or harness indicating the cat has been vaccinated within the last twelve months from the time said cat is found running at large shall be impounded and kept in the city pound and redeemed by the owner, or sold or destroyed by the poundmaster, in the same manner as dogs, in accordance with Articles IV and V [of this chapter] of the Code of Ordinances, City of Groves, Texas. Impoundment fees shall be the same as those provided for dogs in said Code. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 2, 9-8-69) 
Sec. 5-98. - License not required. 
    No license from the city shall be required for cats. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 3, 9-8-69) 
Sec. 5-99. - Dangerous or vicious cats. 
(a)  No cat of dangerous, vicious, fierce or mischievous propensities or tendencies may be at large at any time within the limits of the city. 
(b)  If any cat bites or attempts to bite any person while such cat is at large, then such cat shall be conclusively presumed to be a dangerous cat and a cat of dangerous propensities and tendencies. 
(c)  If any cat attacks or attempts to attack any other cat or other animal while such cat is at large, or chases or otherwise attempts to catch a person, then such cat shall be conclusively presumed to be a vicious cat and to have vicious propensities and tendencies. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 4, 9-8-69) 
Sec. 5-100. - Disposition of dangerous or vicious cats found at large. 
    Any dangerous or vicious cat or cat having dangerous or vicious propensities and tendencies found at large may be killed by any police officer of the city or the poundmaster without such officer or poundmaster having to catch or impound such cat. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 5, 9-8-69) 
Sec. 5-101. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- See the editor's note following § 5-2. 
Chapter 6 - TOW TRUCKS AND TOW TRUCK COMPANIES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ambulance means any vehicle of the modular or van type which is used, designed or redesigned for the purpose of transporting the dead, sick or injured, including any nongovernmental emergency medical service vehicle. 
    City means the City of Groves, a political subdivision of the State of Texas and of the area within its corporate limits. 
    City marshal means the City Marshal of the City of Groves and any employee(s) of the police department assigned by him to perform the duties and/or actions prescribed in this chapter. 
    Commission means the Texas Commission of Licensing and Regulation. 
    Consent tow means any tow of a motor vehicle initiated by the owner or operator of the vehicle or by a person who has possession, custody or control of the vehicle. The term does not include a tow of a motor vehicle initiated by a police officer investigating a traffic accident or a traffic incident that involves the vehicle. 
    Department means the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation. 
    Non-consent tow means any tow of a motor vehicle that is not a consent tow. 
    Public roadway means a public street, alley, road, right-of-way or other public way, including paved and unpaved portions of a right-of-way. 
    Tow truck means a motor vehicle, including a wrecker, equipped with a mechanical device used to tow, winch or otherwise move another motor vehicle. 
    Towing company means an individual, association, corporation or other legal entity that controls, operates or directs the operation of one (1) or more tow trucks over a public roadway in this state, but does not include a political subdivision of this state. 
    Vehicle means a device in, on or by which a person or property may be transported on a public roadway. The term includes an operable or inoperable automobile, truck, motorcycle, recreational vehicle or trailer, but does not include a device moved by human power or used exclusively on a stationary rail or track. 
    Vehicle owner means a person: 
(1)  Named as the purchaser or transferee in the certificate of title issued for the vehicle under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 501; 
(2)  In whose name the vehicle is registered under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 502, or a member of the person's immediate family; 
(3)  Who holds the vehicle through a lease agreement; 
(4)  Who is an unrecorded lien holder entitled to possess the vehicle under the terms of a security agreement; or 
(5)  Who is a lien holder holding an affidavit of repossession and entitled to repossess the vehicle. 
    Vehicle storage facility means a garage, parking lot or other facility that is: 
(1)  Owned by a person other than a governmental entity; 
(2)  Is used to store or park at least ten (10) vehicles each year; and 
(3)  Is operated by a person who holds a license issued under V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 2303, to operate the facility. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-2. - Penalty. 
    Any person, either by himself or by his agent, who shall do any act or thing prohibited by the terms of this chapter, or who in any way violates provisions hereof, shall be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). It shall not be necessary for the complaint to allege or for proof to be made that the act was knowingly done, nor shall it be necessary for the complaint to negate any exception contained in this chapter concerning any prohibited act, but any such exception made in this chapter may be urged as a defense by any person charged by such complaint. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-3. - Applicability of federal and state law. 
    This chapter shall be cumulative of all laws of the state and the United States governing the subject matter of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-4. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter are not and shall not be held applicable to: 
(1)  A tow truck towing a wrecked or disabled vehicle from a point outside the city to a destination within the city; or 
(2)  A tow truck towing a wrecked or disabled vehicle from a point within the city to another destination within the city or outside the city, but not including the towing of vehicles that are considered non-consent tows. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-5. - General requirements. 
    All tow trucks operating within the city must have and maintain a valid and current license, inspection and registration pursuant to V.T.C.A., Transportation Code chs. 502, 548 and 643; and 16 Texas Admin. Code, Economic Regulations § 5.1 et seq., and their future amendments. All drivers of tow trucks must possess a valid and currents driver's license issued in accordance with V.T.C.A., Transportation Code chs. 522 and 524, and their future amendments. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-6. - Duties of drivers; prohibited acts by drivers. 
(a)  Operator's license required. Every tow truck driver shall hold a valid Texas operator's license of the proper class. 
(b)  Obedience to police officers. Every tow truck driver shall obey all lawful orders given by any police officer and shall not in any manner interfere with any police officer in the performance of such officer's duty. 
(c)  Authorization to remove vehicle. Tow truck drivers shall not remove any wrecked or disabled or illegally parked vehicle from any public street without authorization from a police officer; provided, however, that the driver or a stalled or disabled vehicle not involved in an accident may authorize a wrecker driver to remove his/her vehicle when no police officer is present. 
(d)  Transport of vehicle to storage facility. Upon authorization to remove any vehicle that is a non-consent tow, every wrecker driver shall transport such vehicle to his/her storage facility that is approved by the city or to such other destination as ordered by the police officer or vehicle driver immediately and by the most direct route. 
(e)  Removal of debris. Any tow truck driver towing a vehicle from the scene of a vehicular collision shall be responsible for the removal from the scene of such collision any broken glass or other debris resulting from such collision. If more than one (1) tow truck is summoned, each driver shall be responsible for such cleanup and removal. 
(f)  Receipt for payment of fee. The driver of any tow truck that performs any towing or other service and is paid a fee directly for such service shall issue to the vehicle driver or such driver's agent a signed receipt itemizing the services rendered and the fee collected for such services. 
(g)  Solicitation of business. No person shall solicit in any manner, directly or indirectly, on the streets of the city, the business of towing, removing, repairing, wrecking, storing, trading or purchasing any vehicle that is wrecked or disabled on a public street. 
(h)  Driving or parking near scene of accident. No person shall drive, stop or park a wrecker nearer than one hundred fifty (150) feet to the scene of an accident or collision on the streets of the city until directed to do so by the officer investigating the accident; and the person driving the wrecker shall remain with the wrecker at all times unless otherwise directed by the police officer in charge of the investigation. The prohibition of this subsection shall not apply when necessary to prevent death or bodily injury to any person involved in an accident or collision. 
(i)  Compliance with traffic laws. No tow truck driver, whether responding to or returning from the scene of an accident, is authorized to violate any traffic law as set forth in the Rules of the Road (V.T.C.A., Transportation Code chs. 541-600). 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-7. - Influence by police as to selection of wrecker. 
(a)  No police officer investigating or present at the scene of any wreck, accident or collision on a public street shall, directly or indirectly, either by word, gesture, sign or otherwise, recommend to any person the name of any particular person engaged in the wrecker services or repair business, nor shall any such police officer influence or attempt to influence in any manner the decision of a person in choosing or selecting a wrecker or repair service. 
(b)  However, should the driver of the vehicle be incapacitated and the officer not be able to promptly locate a person who has sufficient authority for the care of the vehicle, then the officer may, if it appears necessary and in such officer's judgment, order the removal of the vehicle to a place of safety for the benefit of the driver or owner of the vehicle. Charges for service or storage in such cases will be the responsibility of the owner. 
(c)  In any instance where the driver or owner of the vehicle does not have a preference and requests the officer to call a wrecker or if the driver is incapacitated as described in subsection (b), the officer will call central dispatch and request that the next towing company listed on the non-consent list be called to move the vehicle to safety. The non-consent list will be maintained by the city marshal and it shall include only permitees that have obtained permits in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-8. - Non-consent rotation system; charges for towing and storage. 
(a)  The non-consent rotation system has been established as a means of securing immediate wrecker service in cases of emergency relating to accidents on the public streets, abandoned vehicles on the public streets and other circumstances of public necessity arising out of law enforcement. The non-consent rotation system, therefore, is subject to the governance of the police department in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The police department shall maintain a list of participating vehicle storage facilities that hold a city permit. If owners/operators of disabled vehicles need towing company service but have no preference of towing companies or are unavailable to request a particular towing company, the police department will call participating vehicle storage facilities on a rotating basis until contact is made with a company that can perform the desired service. 
(c)  Police officers are empowered in exigent circumstances to select available tow trucks without regard to the rotation lists maintained by the police department. If a tow truck is utilized in the manner described in this subsection, that particular service will be charged to the towing company's next rotation turn. 
(d)  When a driver or owner of a vehicle to be towed away indicates or requests a particular towing company, the officer on the scene shall notify the communications dispatcher to summon that company by request. Any requested tow truck must be one that has obtained all necessary permits under this chapter. 
(e)  If the driver or owner of a vehicle to be towed expresses no preference as to wrecker service or for any reason cannot be questioned as to a preference, the officer on the scene shall notify the communications dispatcher to summon the vehicle storage facility whose name appears at the top of the non-consent rotation list. All vehicles that need to be towed incidental to an arrest will be considered a non-consent tow. 
(f)  Upon accepting a summons from the communications dispatcher, a towing company shall be allowed a maximum of twenty (20) minutes to appear on the scene. If the company does not appear on the scene within such a time limit, its call may be cancelled, its name placed on the bottom of the list and the next towing company on the list will be called. One towing company cannot respond for another towing company if the contacted company cannot respond to the call from the dispatcher. 
(g)  Towing companies participating in the non-consent rotation system are also required to comply with the following: 
(1)  The participating vehicle storage facility permit holder is responsible for the actions of tow truck drivers and employees or anyone acting on behalf of the company. 
(2)  Vehicle storage facility owners, drivers and employees, or anyone acting in their behalf, must fully comply with all state laws and local ordinances. 
(3)  A vehicle storage facility called to perform service shall be required to perform such service in a tow truck that has a tow truck permit in its name. 
(4)  A tow truck business cannot refuse to respond to a call from the police department and perform the requested service unless its tow trucks are all incapacitated or otherwise unavailable due to another bona fide engagement for their service. 
(5)  Towing companies are required to be on call for summons by the police department twenty-four (24) hours a day, including weekends and holidays. Repeated failure to respond to such summons shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this provision; such violation, however, is subject only to administrative action, which may be taken by the city marshal. 
(6)  Fees charged shall be subject to the following: 
a.  Fees charged by towing companies for non-consent rotation tows, pickups or related towing service shall not exceed the following: 
1.  Fees for use of standard tow truck and equipment shall not exceed the following: 
To remove any vehicle from public or private property to any storage area or destination within the city, by a standard tow truck, a basic fee may be charged not to exceed the following: 
(i)  First hour ..... $125.00 
(ii)  Each successive hour ..... $75.00 
(iii)  Use of rescue kit (air bags) when required ..... $115.00 
per bag, per hour 
2.  To remove any vehicle from a canal, river, lake or waterway and transport to any storage area or destination within the city by a tow truck, an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) may be charged as well as costs for the actual cost of diver services. 
3.  When any standard or heavy-duty tow truck is called for towing service and is unable to perform the required service and has need of an additional tow truck to perform such service, upon prior approval by the police officer on the scene, the towing company initially summoned shall be allowed to select and employ an additional tow truck to assist in performing the required service. The additional tow truck so employed shall be one that is permitted under this chapter to engage in the towing business in the city, if possible. The basic fee for the additional tow truck shall be the same as the first. 
4.  A fee for storage of a vehicle shall not exceed twenty dollars ($20.00) per day, and shall not be charged during the first twenty-four (24) hours such vehicle is in the storage facility. 
5.  Fees for a medium-duty tow (the towed vehicle is between ten thousand and one (10,001) and twenty-four thousand nine hundred ninety-nine (24,999) pounds) and a heavy-duty tow (the towed vehicle is twenty-five thousand (25,000) pounds or more) are not regulated by the ordinance codified in this chapter, but rather by state law. 
b.  Fees established in this chapter with respect to non-consent towing calls are inclusive. Additional fees for initial services are prohibited. This restriction does not apply to additional fees charged for subsequent services later requested by the vehicle owner or such owner's agent(s). 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-9. - Impoundment of towed vehicles by police. 
    Any police officer, in the exercise of his/her discretion as a police officer, may direct that any vehicle shall be taken by the driver of the tow truck towing the vehicle directly to a designated area or licensed vehicle storage facility and there be held by the city for inspection or investigation to determine the cause or reason for the accident such vehicle was involved in or such vehicle's disability or for any lawful purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Secs. 6-10-6-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS 

Sec. 6-20. - Required permits for persons performing non-consent tows. 
    The city marshal shall develop necessary application and permit forms to enact these provisions. Any person desiring to operate a towing company in the city shall make application with the police department for the issuance of a towing company permit. Such application shall be submitted on the forms furnished by the police department. The applicants shall furnish all required information and supporting documents listed on the application form. A towing company permit shall not be issued by the city marshal unless the applicant meets all the required provisions of this chapter, including but not limited to: 
(1)  All information on the submitted application shall be true and accurate and all required supplemental documents or information have been furnished. 
(2)  The towing company must operate a vehicle storage facility in the city, that is, at all times licensed pursuant to the Texas Vehicle Storage Facility Act, any provisions of the Texas Administrative Code relevant to operation of a vehicle storage facility and all other applicable laws. 
(3)  The physical facility to be operated by the towing company must meet the following requirements: 
a.  The facility must be in compliance with all zoning requirements of the City of Groves and all applicable state laws or regulations; 
b.  The physical facility operated by the towing company must not be a part of any other business which performs towing services and must not be located at the same physical location as any other tow truck company; 
c.  The towing company must have a physical office of not less than two hundred (200) square feet and storage facility located in the city, with the exception of towing companies operating heavy-duty specialty tow trucks capable of towing eighteen-wheeled vehicles or other commercial vehicles, which companies are not required to maintain a physical office or storage facility within the city limits of the City of Groves, Texas, and the services of which may be procured by a city-approved towing company if necessary; 
d.  The towing company must have a telephone number that is different from any other tow truck company; 
e.  The towing company must have a sign on the business premises identifying the towing company by the name as it appears on the license application, street address, telephone number, hours of business and any vehicle storage facility license number issued for that location. Said sign shall be of a size that may be read from a distance of not less than one hundred fifty (150) feet; 
f.  All sites for outdoor storage or disabled motor vehicles and associated auto parts shall provide a screening fence for any area within one hundred (100) feet of any public street right-of-way or any lot containing a residential use or zoned residential. Such screening fence shall be not less than six (6) feet in height and constructed of wood, metal, concrete or other substantial material and shall be so constructed that any open space between solid material shall be a maximum of one-half inch in width, and the solid material between open spaces shall be at least two (2) inches in width; and 
g.  Maintained exclusively for storage of vehicles towed by wreckers operating under such permit. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-21. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    The permit fee to operate a towing company under the terms and conditions of this chapter shall be payable as follows: 
At the time of the original or renewal application for a towing company permit, the applicant shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) as a nonrefundable application fee. If the permit is granted, there will be no additional charge for the inspection of one (1) tow truck, such fee being included in the aforementioned permit fee. Should the applicant desire to operate more than one (1) tow truck, an inspection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged for each additional tow truck and such fees must be paid at the time application for the permit is made. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-22. - Insurance. 
(a)  Each applicant for a permit under this article shall file satisfactory proof of garage keeper's legal liability insurance for the vehicle storage facility for which authorization to operate is sought. Such insurance shall include coverage for comprehensive, specified perils and collision per incident and shall be issued by a company duly authorized to write such insurance in the state. Such insurance shall be in the amount of not less than what is required in the rules adopted by the state transportation commission pursuant to the provisions of the Vehicle Storage Facility Act (V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 2303). 
(b)  Each applicant shall file satisfactory proof for each wrecker for which a permit is sought of a policy of public liability property damage insurance issued by a casualty insurance company authorized to do business in the state and in the standard form approved by the state board of insurance commissioners. The coverage provision will insure the public from loss or damage that may arise to any person or property by reason for the operation of a tow truck. The amount of recovery on each tow truck shall be in limits of not less than what is required by the provisions of V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 601. 
(c)  The certified insurance form shall be kept on file with the permit application, and it must warrant to the city that the insurance will not be cancelled without thirty (30) days prior notice, in writing, to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-23. - Issuance of tow truck permit. 
(a)  After the application for a permit under this article has been approved by the city marshal or such official's designee(s), the city clerk shall issue a permit to applicants complying with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  All permits issued shall be personal to the permit holder and may not be sold, leased or otherwise transferred to any other party. If a business or transfer holder sells, leases or conveys ownership or control of its tow truck business, the new owner shall not operate such tow truck business without obtaining all necessary permits. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-24. - Revocation. 
    The city council shall revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this article when it finds any of the following: 
(1)  The permit was procured by fraudulent conduct or false statement of a material fact in the written application; or 
(2)  The permit holder has violated any applicable provision of this Code, state law, or city ordinance, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 6-25. - Vehicle inspection permits. 
(a)  No city vehicle inspection permit shall be issued for any tow truck proposed to be used by the applicant, unless the applicant holds a valid tow truck company permit issued in accordance with this article and the tow truck complies with the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  The tow truck shall have a current license tag and state inspection sticker; 
(2)  The tow truck shall be not less than three-quarter ton in size and must be equipped with booster brakes; 
(3)  The tow truck shall be equipped with a power or hand-operated winch, winch line and boom where applicable, with a factory rated lifting capacity or a city-tested capacity of not less than five thousand (5,000) pounds, single line capacity; 
(4)  Each tow truck must carry proper safety equipment that includes, but is not limited to the following: 
a.  At least one (1) ten-pound or two (2) five-pound multiple-purpose fire extinguishers in good working condition; 
b.  Magnetic tow lights, unless wireless, with appropriate cable and cushions to protect a vehicle's finish; 
c.  Tow dollies as appropriate; 
d.  Straps and tie downs as specified by the tow truck manufacturer; 
e.  Gloves; 
f.  Wheel chocks; 
g.  Five-gallon trash receptacle and material designed to absorb oil and fluids; 
h.  Broom and shovel; 
i.  Thirty-six inch crow bar; and 
j.  Triangle reflectors, flares, cones, safety lights or other appropriate safety signals. 
(b)  Payment of city taxes prerequisite to issuance. No city vehicle inspection permit shall be issued to any applicant if the applicant owns any tow truck upon which delinquent taxes are due the city, nor for any tow truck if the applicant therefore has failed to render the tow truck for ad valorem taxation. 
(c)  Display. Each city vehicle inspection permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be affixed securely to the windshield of the appropriate tow truck and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any tow truck which does not have such permit so posted and displayed. 
(d)  Revocation. Any vehicle inspection permit issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked or suspended by the city police or fire chief for the violation of any provision of this Code, any state law, or any city ordinance, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 6-17-13) 
Secs. 6-26-6-50. - Reserved. 
Chapter 7 - DROUGHT CONTINGENCY PLAN[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 23, 2006, repealed chapter 7, sections 7-1-7-12, in its entirety and replaced it with a new chapter 7, sections 7-1-7-12. Former chapter 7 pertained to similar material and derived from Ord. No. 99-12, § 1, adopted Aug. 23, 1999. 

Sec. 7-1. - Declaration of policy, purpose and intent. 
    In order to conserve the available water supply and protect the integrity of water supply facilities, with particular regard for domestic water use, sanitation, and fire protection, and to protect and preserve public health, welfare, and safety and minimize the adverse impacts of water supply shortage or other water supply emergency conditions, the city hereby adopts the following regulations and restrictions on the delivery and consumption of water through ordinance passed by the city council. Water uses regulated or prohibited under this drought contingency plan (the plan) are considered to be non-essential and continuation of such uses during times of water shortage or other emergency water supply condition are deemed to constitute a waste of water which subjects the offender(s) to penalties as defined in section 7-9 of this plan. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-2. - Public involvement. 
    The city shall actively inform the public and wholesale water customers and affirmatively provide opportunity for input from the public and from wholesale water customers regarding the plan. Such provision includes, but is not limited to, notifying the public and wholesale water customers of the city's public meeting regarding the proposed plan, notice of which will be given pursuant to the Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-3. - Public education. 
    The city will periodically provide the public with information about the plan, including information about the conditions under which each stage of the plan is to be initiated or terminated and the drought response measures to be implemented in each stage. This information will be provided by means of: 
(1)  Publications of articles in a newspaper or newsletter of general circulation in the service area, providing information regarding the plan and/or information regarding water conservation techniques; 
(2)  Direct distributions to all residents and other users of water within the city, and all wholesale water customers of the city, if any, ("users") explaining the plan; 
(3)  Direct distributions to users of educational and informational material regarding the plan; and 
(4)  Additional educational activities consisting of: 
a.  Conducting an informational school program in a school attended by students within the city's service area; 
b.  Conducting an educational program for users at a public place within or accessible to residents of the city; 
c.  Conducting or engaging in such other informational or educational activity designed to further the plan as may be consistent with the purposes and policies of this plan; or 
d.  Any combination of the foregoing. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-4. - Coordination with regional water planning groups. 
    The service area of the city is located within East Texas Regional (Region I) Water Planning Group and the city has provided a copy of this plan to the East Texas Regional Water Planning Group. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-5. - Coordination with Lower Neches Valley Authority. 
    All water for the city is supplied through a municipal raw water contract with the Lower Neches Valley Authority (LNVA). LNVA has implemented its own drought contingency plan that includes water use restrictions that are applicable to its retail and wholesale customers. The LNVA's drought plan requires its wholesale customers to enforce similar or more stringent standards and procedures in their water systems. A copy of the LNVA drought contingency plan is [available for inspection in the offices of the city]. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-6. - Authorization. 
    The city's designee authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of this plan is as named in the ordinance approving the plan. The city's designee has the authority to determine when implementation is necessary to protect public health, safety, and welfare. The city's designee shall have the authority to initiate or terminate drought or other water supply emergency response measures as described in this plan. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-7. - Application. 
    The provisions of this plan shall apply to all persons and customers utilizing water provided by the city. The terms "person" and "customer" as used in the plan include individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, and all other legal entities. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 7-8. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this plan, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Aesthetic water use: Water use for ornamental or decorative purposes such as fountains, reflecting pools, and water gardens. 
(2)  Commercial and institutional water use: Water use that is integral to the operations of commercial and non-profit establishments and governmental entities such as retail establishments, hotels and motels, restaurants, and office buildings. 
(3)  Conservation: Those practices, techniques, and technologies that reduce the consumption of water, reduce the loss or waste of water, improve the efficiency in the use of water or increase the recycling and reuse of water so that a supply is conserved and made available for future or alternative uses. 
(4)  Construction water use: Water used in the process of building or erecting structures, streets, ditches, etc. or water used to prepare a surface for building and/or rehabilitation. Construction water use may occur through a fixed tap or through a mobile unit that fills at a fixed tap. 
(5)  Customer: Any person, company, or organization using water supplied by the city. 
(6)  Domestic water use: Water use for personal needs or for household or sanitary purposes such as drinking, bathing, heating, cooking, sanitation, or for cleaning a residence, business, industry, or institution.
