Chapter 22 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Streets and sidewalks, Art. XIV. 
Cross reference- Bond required of driller of gas or oil well guaranteeing restoration of damaged streets and sidewalks, § 17-21; blocking of street or alley by oil or gas drilling or production operation, § 17-48; use of streets for taxicab stands purposes, § 24-6; application of traffic provisions to workmen and equipment, § 25-9; removal of glass, nails, other injurious material from street, § 25-16; utilities, Ch. 27; minimum clearance of electrical signs above sidewalks, § 29-138; installation of electrical sign supports on public property, § 29-139; enclosure of high voltage electrical conductors, § 29-143. 
State Law reference- General authority of city relative to streets and sidewalks, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St., art. 1175, §§ (16-18). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Adoption of state law relative to street improvements. 
    The provisions of Chapter 106, 40th Legislature, the first called session, Acts of 1927, commonly known as Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, article 1105b, as amended, are hereby adopted by the city as controlling the establishment, construction and repair of street improvements within the city. 
Sec. 22-2. - Obstruction of drainage ditches. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place dirt, trash, broken concrete, bricks, rubbish, or any other obstruction in any drainage ditch within the city without written permission therefor from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 90, § 1, 5-21-56) 
Sec. 22-3. - Access driveways to highways; state regulations adopted. 
    The booklet, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, entitled "Regulations for Access Driveways to State Highways" dated September 23, 1953, as amended in September 1960, and published by the Texas Highway Department in accordance with Minute Order No. 34719, is hereby adopted by the city for the public safety and protection of the citizens of the city. 
Sec. 22-4. - Approval of plans and specifications. 
    All street and alley improvements within the city shall be constructed only in accordance with plans and specifications as approved by the city manager or by the director of public works. 
Sec. 22-5. - Preparation of plans and specifications. 
    Prior to the beginning of construction of any street or alley improvements within the city, plans and specifications and estimates of cost shall be prepared by the city manager or by the director of public works. 
Sec. 22-6. - Street numbers for buildings. 
    All buildings fronting on any street or alley in the city shall be numbered in some conspicuous place, by the owner thereof, according to the map made by the director of public works for such purpose and on file in his office, all odd numbers being on one side of the street and all even numbers on the other. 
    Any person desiring to have a number put on his buildings shall first apply to the director of public works for the proper number, and any person failing or refusing to put the proper number on his building or putting the wrong number thereon, or failing or refusing to comply with any other requirement of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 22-7. - Obstruction of public ways prohibited-By individuals. 
    A person shall not stop or stand in the way so as to in any manner obstruct the use of the sidewalks, streets, or any other public place in the city by loafing, lounging or standing in or upon the same. 
Sec. 22-8. - Same-Exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any materials, boxes, or other objects whatsoever in or upon any street, alley right-of-way or sidewalk in the city without first obtaining the written permission of the director of public works. If written permission is obtained, then it shall be unlawful to remove the material so placed without first obtaining the written permission of the director of public works to remove the same. 
Sec. 22-9. - Interference, obstruction of public improvements prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or obstruct any public improvements authorized by the city council, the mayor or the director of public works by means of threats, coercion, duress, or any other method whatsoever, either directly or indirectly. Any person who shall be deemed guilty of violating the provision of this section shall be fined as provided in section 1-5. 
Sec. 22-10. - Manner of work; cleanliness of premises. 
    All work done or performed under the provisions of this chapter shall be done or performed in a good, workmanlike manner. Such work shall not be accepted or approved by the city until the premises thereof has been cleaned and cleared of all debris, trash and rubbish which may have accumulated during such work. 
Sec. 22-11. - Change of street, sidewalk grade or line. 
    The city reserves the right, when putting down street pavement, either by original construction or reconstruction, to change, or alter the lines and/or grades of such street and/or the sidewalks when in the opinion of the city council such change is necessary for the proper improvement, surfacing, pavement, or drainage of said street, without liability on the part of the city by reason of said change. 
    In the event that a sidewalk, the line or grade of which is changed, is in good condition and does not, in the opinion of the city council require entire reconstruction, the owner or owners thereof shall be given notice to break said sidewalks back to a point fixed by the city's director of public works, and to remove the broken portion and reconstruct said portion on the line and grade determined by the city's director of public works, at the cost of the said abutting owner. This shall be required upon order of the council thereof in the same manner as required for the construction, reconstruction, repairing or regrading of sidewalks. 
Sec. 22-12. - Permit to lay sidewalks and driveways. 
(a)  No sidewalk or driveway shall be laid by any property owner in the city on any street right-of-way without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of public works. Application for said driveway and/or sidewalk permit shall be made on an application form to be provided by the office of the director of public works, and there shall be no fee for issuance of said permit. 
(b)  Driveways must be constructed so as not to end more than one (1) foot from the existing street surface unless otherwise specified by the city, the city will furnish and install material for the area between the street surface and driveway as stated on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 95-07, § 1, 7-31-95) 
Secs. 22-13-22-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 22-22. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the word "borrow pit" shall mean the pit, hole or depression created by any excavation of dirt, sand, stone or other earth material. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 1, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-23. - Exceptions to article provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to excavation for swimming pools or for foundation purposes where a building permit has been properly applied for and granted in accordance with the building code; provided, however, that if the construction for which a building permit had been granted should be abandoned or delayed for a period longer than one hundred eighty (180) days, any pit excavated shall be required to conform to the provisions of sections 22-31-22-35. 
    The provisions of this article also shall not be applicable to excavation of drainage ditches, canals, or similar facilities. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 3, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-24. - When declared nuisance. 
    Any excavation made within the city in violation of the provisions of this article shall be declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 2, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-25. - Permit required. 
    No person shall dig, excavate, remove, or cause to be dug, excavated, or removed, any dirt, clay, rock or other material below the surface of the ground without having first obtained an excavation permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 2, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-26. - Application for permit. 
    Each application for an excavation permit shall be in writing, on a form provided for that purpose by the public works director, stating the purpose of the proposed owner's use of the land upon which the excavation is to be done and the names of all owners of land lying within one hundred (100) feet of the proposed excavation, and shall be accompanied by an accurate drawing showing the location of the proposed excavation, and the dimensions of the borrow pit to be created thereby. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 4, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-27. - Permit fee. 
    Each application for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00); which fee shall be refunded to the applicant if the permit is not granted. Such permit fee shall not be required of any governmental agency, entity, or instrumentality but all other provisions of this article shall remain applicable to such bodies. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 4, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-28. - Issuance of permit. 
    Upon proper application, the public works director shall issue an excavation permit if he is satisfied, from competent evidence presented to him as he may require, that the proposed excavation is consistent with the public health, safety and welfare and that the provisions of this article will be met. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 8, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-29. - Appeal from denial of permit. 
    If an application for excavation permit is denied by the public works director, the applicant may within ten (10) days appeal such denial to the city council. The city council shall set a public hearing, which shall be held not later than thirty (30) days after presentation of the appeal to the city council. Following such hearing, the city council may either affirm, overrule, or modify the decision of the public works director and such decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 9, 2-20-64) 
Sec. 22-30. - Areas where permitted. 
    Borrow pit excavations shall be permitted within the city in only those areas so indicated on the official "Borrow Pit Excavations Map" on file in the office of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 364 § 8, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-31. - Proximity to adjoining property. 
    No excavation shall be made within ten (10) feet of any property line without the express written consent of the owner of the adjacent property. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 5, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-32. - Proximity to roadways, easements, etc. 
    Excavations which are conducted adjacent to roadways, easements, drainage systems, water lines, sewer lines, or other structures, shall be conducted at an adequate distance from such facilities, as determined by the public works director, so as not to interfere with or cause damage to such facilities. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 5, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-33. - Slope of borrow pits. 
    Borrow pits shall be sloped no steeper than two (2) feet horizontal for each one (1) foot vertical measurement. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 5, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-34. - Prohibited on streets, rights-of-way. 
    No borrow pit excavation shall be made upon any dedicated street or highway right-of-way or any planned or proposed street described in the master street plan of the city. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 6, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-35. - Fence required. 
    Upon completion of the excavation for which a permit has been granted, but not later than one hundred eighty (180) days after excavation has begun, a substantial fence, at least six (6) feet in height and otherwise being in accordance with specifications promulgated by the public works director shall be erected completely surrounding the borrow pit. Such fence shall be kept in good repair as long as the borrow pit exists, and all gates closed except as necessary for excavations and removal purposes. If any part of a borrow pit is situated within fifty (50) feet of a residence, the fence surrounding such pit shall be so constructed as to prevent small children from gaining access to the borrow pit. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 10, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-36. - Material not to be dropped on streets. 
    Excavated material shall not be dropped or placed upon any public street or highway. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 7, 2-20-67) 
Sec. 22-37. - Trucks to use truck routes. 
    Trucks hauling excavated material shall be required, insofar as possible, to use existing truck routes in the city. 
(Ord. No. 364, § 7, 2-20-67) 
Secs. 22-38-22-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 86-13, § 1, adopted Feb. 24, 1986, repealed Art. III, sidewalks and driveways, §§ 22-48, 22-49, derived from Ord. No. 291, §§ 1, 2, adopted Apr. 20, 1964. 

Secs. 22-48-22-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OBSTRUCTIONS AT INTERSECTIONS 

Sec. 22-60. - Declared traffic hazard. 
(a)  Any fence, tree, shrub, bush, vine or other plant, vehicle or any other article, existing at or within a distance of twenty-five (25) feet of the intersection of any street in the city, which interferes with the unobstructed vision of approaching vehicles at such intersection or which obstructs the view of any stop sign or other traffic signal in the city, is hereby declared to be a traffic hazard and to endanger the lives of persons approaching such intersection. 
(b)  Any fence, hedge, enclosure, shrub, bush, vine or other plant, vehicle or any other article, existing at or within a distance of ten (10) feet of a property line which borders a street in the city, which interferes with the unobstructed vision of vehicles at the intersection of a street or a private drive onto a street within the city, is hereby declared to be a traffic hazard and to endanger the lives of persons approaching such intersection. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 1, 11-16-64; Ord. No. 84-04, § 1, 1-30-84) 
Sec. 22-61. - Notice to correct hazard-Issuance. 
(a)  Whenever the existence of any condition declared to constitute a traffic hazard by this article shall come to the knowledge of the city marshal, he shall cause a written notice identifying the property on which such fence, tree, shrub, bush, vine or other plant exists, to be issued forthwith to the person owning or having possession or control of same. 
(b)  The notice shall require the remodeling, trimming, removing or otherwise correcting of such traffic hazard within ten (10) days from the service of such notice. Such notice shall also state that in default thereof the city may at once cause the same to be done, pay therefor, charge the cost and expense incurred in having such work done to the owner of such property and fix a lien on such property thereof. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 2, 11-16-64) 
Sec. 22-62. - Same-Service. 
(a)  The city marshal shall cause the notice provided for in section 22-61, to be served by any city policeman be delivering the same to the person to be served by leaving the same at his place of residence, if within the city. If such notice is to be served on a firm or corporation, he shall cause the notice to be served by any city policeman by delivering the same to any officer, agent or other representative authorized by law to accept service of citations. 
(b)  If the person to be served with the notice resides outside the limits of the city, the posting of a letter addressed to such person at his post office address, if known shall be sufficient service of such notice. If such person or his post office address is unknown, or if he cannot be found after a diligent search, service may be made by publishing such notice one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(c)  The officer serving the notice or causing publication thereof to be made, shall make due return thereof to the city marshal on a copy of such notice, showing the date and manner of service. 
(Ord. No. 308, §§ 3-5, 11-16-64) 
Sec. 22-63. - Same-Appeal. 
(a)  Right. If any person to whom the notice provided for in this article is issued is of the opinion that the condition declared a traffic hazard does not exist, he may, within ten (10) days after the date of such notice, file his written objections thereto with the city council. If the city council is of a contrary opinion, it shall set a date for hearing thereon. 
(b)  Notice of hearing. If the city council is of the opinion that a traffic hazard exists and is being maintained, it shall set a date for hearing thereon at any time not less than five (5) days from the date of receipt of the written objections thereto and not later than fifteen (15) days from receipt thereof. Notice of such hearing shall be served by personal service, by mail or by publication as provided in this article. 
(c)  Decision. If, upon such hearing, the city council is still of the opinion that such traffic hazard exists and is maintained, it shall direct the director of public works, without further notice to the owner, to proceed at once to cause the abatement of such traffic hazard by remodeling, trimming or removing same, as the city council may direct, and charge the necessary costs and expenses of such work to the owner of the property on which such traffic hazard exists. 
(Ord. No. 308, §§ 7-9, 11-16-64) 
Sec. 22-64. - Action by city to correct. 
    In the event of the failure, refusal or neglect of the person to whom notice prescribed in section 22-61 is given to comply with the requirements of such notice in the manner and within the time provided, the city marshal shall file a written report thereof to the city council showing due service of notice upon such person and describing the property and the condition existing thereon, and the city council shall order the abatement of such traffic hazard by remodeling, trimming, removing or otherwise correcting the same, unless written objections are filed with the city council. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 6, 11-16-64) 
    The work of abatement or correction of a traffic hazard shall either be done under contract to the lowest bidder or performed under the supervision of the director of public works, or his duly authorized representative, or by labor employed by the city, whichever the director of public works, in his opinion, deems most expeditious. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 10, 11-16-64) 
Sec. 22-65. - Filing of lien. 
(a)  When work to correct or abate a traffic hazard by the city has been completed, the director of public works shall cause a statement of the same to be filed in the office of the county clerk. 
(b)  The statement of costs shall show the costs and expense of the work, the date on which it was performed, a brief description of the property sufficient to identify the same and the name of the owner thereof, if known. 
(c)  Such statement of costs, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended in any such work. 
(d)  The amount shown by the statement of costs to have been expended by the city on such property, together with ten (10) per cent interest from the date of such payment, shall be a privileged lien thereon, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. 
(e)  For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure had in the name of the city in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 11, 11-16-64) 
Sec. 22-66. - Maximum height of shrubs, etc. 
    No person shall plant, grow or maintain in any restricted area any plant, hedge, shrub or other growth, except trees, at a height greater than three (3) feet from the street gutter flow line. 
Sec. 22-67. - Maximum clearance of trees. 
    Any trees planted, grown and maintained in any area shall not have branches or foliage extending from the trunk thereof at a height lower than fifteen (15) feet from the street gutter flow line. 
Secs. 22-68-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PERMANENT STREET IMPROVEMENTS IN DEVELOPED AREAS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Article V, §§ 22-71-22-73, is derived from Ord. No. 428, §§ 1-3, enacted April 13, 1970. This ordinance did not amend this Code. 

Sec. 22-71. - Definitions. 
(a)  Permanent street improvements and streets shall have the meanings accorded them in Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, Article 1105b and in Chapter XIV, Section 2 the City Charter. 
(b)  In regards to the surfacing of streets or alleys, the following work shall not be considered as permanent street improvements: 
(1)  The surfacing of less than twenty-five (25) lineal feet of street or alley, regardless of the thickness or type of surfacing material involved. This provision shall be construed so that only "spot" street or alley repairs may be made without expense to the owners of abutting property. It shall not be construed to authorize the use of city funds to construct small scale, permanent street or alley improvements abutting particular parcels or property without expense to the owners of the abutting property. 
(2)  The surfacing of streets, (regardless of the length of the section surfaced) by the laying of unstabilized shell or gravel. 
    All other surfacing work in streets and alleys shall be considered as "permanent street improvements". 
(3)  The surfacing, resurfacing and/or reconstruction of streets that are beyond the point of economical maintenance may be accomplished under the following conditions: Upon recommendation by the city manager, the city council may approve a yearly program for the surfacing, resurfacing and/or reconstruction of streets when such action is more economical than continued maintenance of said streets, and so long as sufficient funds, equipment and personnel are available. 
(c)  Developed area means an area situated within the corporate limits of the city, the plat of which has been on record in the office of the county clerk for at least five (5) years prior to the date upon which the request for permanent street improvements is submitted. 
(Ord. No. 428, § 1, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 22-72. - Statement of policy. 
(a)  The city council (regardless of whether it is acting under the statutory and Charter provisions cited herein or under some other lawful authority) will not authorize the spending or the obligation of the funds to the city to make permanent street improvements in developed areas until the requirements of section 22-73 hereof have been satisfied. 
(b)  The city council will not authorize the spending or the obligation of the funds of the city for the purpose of surfacing the streets of a developed area with oil. Nothing herein shall be construed to the contrary. 
(Ord. No. 428, § 2, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 22-73. - Prerequisites to authorize permanent street improvements in a developed area. 
(A)  A request, signed by at least twenty per cent (20%) of the owners of abutting property, shall be submitted to the city council through the city manager asking that permanent improvements be made on the street. The request shall contain: 
(1)  A designation of the section of the street which will be involved. 
(2)  A brief description of the permanent improvements which are proposed. 
(3)  A statement that the signers of the request have reason to believe that at least seventy-five per cent (75%) or more of the owners of abutting property or sixty per cent (60%) or more of the homestead owners of abutting property, abutting the section will sign the instruments required by subsection (F)(1) hereof. 
(4)  The date upon which the plat of the developed area was placed of record in the office of the county clerk. 
(B)  After studying the request, the city manager shall prepare his recommendations and forward his recommendations and the request to the city council. 
(C)  The city manager, when making his recommendations shall be guided by the following principles: 
(1)  If the city has sufficient funds immediately available to defray the entire cost of the proposed permanent improvements; if the proposed permanent improvements are consonant with the city's currently effective "Capital Planning Report"; if they are presently practicable; and if the area involved is in fact a developed area, the city manager shall recommend that the proposed permanent street improvements be authorized. 
(2)  In case the proposed permanent street improvements do not fulfill the requirements of subsection (C)(1), the city manager shall recommend (if it is possible so to do) the authorization of alternate permanent street improvements which fulfill the requirements of said subsection. 
(3)  In case the proposed permanent street improvements do not fulfill the requirements of subsection (C)(1), and in case an alternate improvement cannot be recommended, the city manager shall recommend that the request be rejected. 
(D)  If the city manager recommends that the permanent street improvements be made, his recommendations shall contain: 
(1)  Plans and specifications for said improvements. 
(2)  Estimate of the total cost of said improvements: 
(3)  A breakdown of the total cost to show what portion thereof shall be borne by the city and what portion shall be borne by the owners of abutting property. 
(4)  A list of all the abutting property which will be involved in making said improvement. The list will show: 
(a)  The legal description of each unit of property. 
(b)  The names of persons owning the property involved, indicating in every instance whether the property is or is not claimed by the owner as a homestead. 
(c)  The number of front feet which abut the street in each unit of property. 
(d)  The total cost which must be borne by each property owner. 
(5)  The priority to be assigned to making the improvements. 
(a)  It is the intent of this provision that the city manager shall maintain as a public record a "Priority List of Street Improvements." This list shall show the street improvement projects authorized by the city council, and the order in which the street improvement projects are to be accomplished. 
(b)  This rule shall be used both by the city manager and the city council in establishing the priority for accomplishing street improvement projects: 
(1)  Economical employment of the city's forces and equipment shall be determinative. 
(2)  When the factor of economy is equal, the date upon which the property owners sponsoring a have filed their request shall be determinative-priority being given the request which was filed first. 
(E)  This rule shall be used both by the city manager and the city commission in apportioning the cost of permanent street improvements: 
(1)  The city shall bear the expense of constructing: 
(a)  Storm sewers or drainage ditches. 
(b)  Base and/or wearing surface of the street at intersections. 
(c)  Curb and gutter "returns". 
(2)  The owner of abutting property shall bear the expense of constructing: 
(a)  Curb and gutter. 
(b)  Base and/or wearing surface of the street out to the center line of the street. 
(F)  The city council, after receiving the recommendations of the city manager, and acting in accordance with the principles set out in subsection (C) hereof, shall determine whether the request (or some modification thereof) shall be accepted or rejected. In the event a request is accepted, the council shall allocate from the city's unencumbered and immediately available funds a sum of money equal to the city manager's estimate of the total cost of said improvements. This allocation shall not have the effect of an "appropriation"; and it shall be effective only for a period of sixty (60) days. If the requirements provided hereafter in this subsection have been met on or before the end of said period, the council shall authorize the making of the requested improvements. If said requirements have not been met by the end of said period, the allocation shall expire; provided that the allocation, at the option of the council, may be extended for an additional period of thirty (30) days. 
(1)  Seventy-five (75) per cent, or more, of the owners of abutting property or sixty (60) per cent, or more, of the homestead owners of abutting property, using the forms prescribed herein, have properly executed, acknowledged, and delivered to the city three (3) instruments concerning their property, to-wit: street improvement contract, street improvement promissory note, and improvement deed of trust, (blank copies of these three instruments which are to be used are attached hereto and made a part hereof). 
(a)  The principal sum set forth in said three instruments shall be amortized as follows: If the principal sum is less than five hundred dollars ($500.00)-a minimum monthly payment (including payment to interest and principal) of ten dollars ($10.00) per month shall be made; if the principal sum is five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more-the principal sum and interest thereon shall be paid off in five (5) years. The monthly note payments set forth in said three instruments shall be established accordingly. 
(b)  It is hereby established as a public policy that should the homestead owners invoke the provisions of chapter XIX, section 14 of said Charter, the city council has determined that the proper execution and acknowledgment of these three instruments by seventy-five (75) per cent or more of the owners involved is the method which shall be used to secure the payment for said improvements. 
(2)  The city council (if such procedure is required by law) has given the notice, conducted the hearing, and adopted the ordinance which authorized construction of the permanent street improvements, and assesses the owners of abutting property according to the front foot plan. It is expressly provided that procedures of the nature described in this subsection shall not be started unless and until the provisions of subsection (F)(1) have been satisfied. It is further provided, however, that the city council is hereby authorized to construct permanent street improvements in a developed area without first making assessments if all the owners of the abutting property sign the instruments described in subsection (F)(1). 
(G)  Work on the permanent street improvements in a developed area may not be started until: 
(1)  All the applicable foregoing requirements have been met. 
(2)  An appropriate ordinance has been adopted which spells out that such requirements have been met, and which authorizes the construction of permanent street improvements in a developed area; and which establishes the priority assigned to accomplishing the street improvement. 
(Ord. No. 428, § 3, 4-13-70) 
ARTICLE VI. - MANAGEMENT OF STREET RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 22-74. - Definitions. 
    Applicant means any user or potential user who desires to own, operate, maintain, and/or install facilities in city rights-of-way. 
    Facility or facilities means any utility infrastructure including but not limited to pipes, wires, conduits, utility poles, and related appurtenances, situated within city rights-of-way which are owned, operated, maintained, and/or installed by users other than the city. 
    Person means a designated representative of a user. 
    Street, public way, public right-of-way, public rights-of-way, rights-of-way or right-of-way means the surface of, and the space above and below a public street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, public way or place, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive, or other easement now or hereafter held by or under the control of the city, to which the city holds the property rights in regard to the use for utilities. 
    User means any business, firm, corporation, entity, owner, and/or operator, other than the city, which owns, operates, maintains, and/or installs facilities within city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-75. - Criminal penalties. 
(a)  Any violation or failure to abide by, and comply with, any provision or requirement of this article shall be a violation, and shall be punishable as a class "C" misdemeanor, subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. 
(b)  Each day upon which there exists a violation of this article, or a failure to abide by, or comply with, any provision or requirement of this article, shall constitute a separate occurrence, and shall subject the offender to separate criminal penalties. 
(c)  Prosecution pursuant to this article is in addition to and does not supplant other remedies. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-76. - Civil penalties. 
(a)  Civil penalties may be imposed for the violation of any provision of this article, as follows: 
(1)  Up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation, and each day of a continuing violation may be considered a new violation; and/or 
(2)  If applicable, default and revocation of any or all permits granted to allow work in the rights-of-way, subject to the procedural guidelines noted in this article and any agreement which applies to the right-of-way user, and further subject to any limitations imposed by federal or state law. 
(b)  In imposing the penalties and the amount, the city may weigh all applicable factors, such as damages caused by the violation, reasons for the violation, the seriousness of the violation, and all other factors. 
(c)  Monetary civil penalties may be imposed in the manner prescribed by either local or state law. 
(d)  In addition, the city council may order specific performance of any actions required by this article or required by a franchise, license or permit, including the permit authorizing work to be performed in the right-of-way, or any other agreement or authorization. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-77. - Right-of-way construction. 
(a)  No user shall commence or continue with the construction, installation or maintenance of facilities within the right-of-way in the city except as provided by the ordinances of the city and the directives of the public works department. 
(b)  No user shall be permitted to cut or excavate a street when it is otherwise possible to perform the construction or installation without disturbing the roadway surface. The director of public works, or his/her designee, shall determine whether to allow excavation based upon the justification submitted by the person desiring to perform such work. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-78. - Registration and construction permits. 
(a)  In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, all users of the right-of-way will register with the city. Registration and permits will be issued in the name of the owner of the facilities. Registration must be renewed by January 15th of every year. Should, however, a user of right-of-way have a current and valid franchise agreement with the city, registration shall not be required as long as the franchise agreement remains in effect. When any information provided for the registration changes, the user will inform the city no more than thirty (30) working days after the date the change is made. 
Registration shall include: 
(1)  The name of the owner of the facilities located within the right-of-way; 
(2)  The name of the user of the right-of-way; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of people who will be contact person(s) for the user; 
(4)  The name(s) and telephone number(s) of an emergency contact who shall be available twenty-four (24) hours a day; 
(5)  Proof of insurance and bonds to include: 
a.  An applicant must provide proof of liability insurance in the amount of six million dollars ($6,000,000.00); one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) primary, plus five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) umbrella. 
b.  The coverage must be on an occurrence basis and must include coverage for personal injury, contractual liability, premises liability, medical damages, underground, explosion and collapse hazards. 
c.  Each policy must include a cancellation provision in which the insurance company is required to notify the city in writing not fewer than thirty (30) working days before canceling, failing to renew, or reducing policy limits. 
d.  The applicant shall file the required original certificate of insurance. The certificate shall state the policy number; name of the insurance company; name and address of the agent or authorized representative of the insurance company; name, address and telephone number of insured; policy expiration date; and specific coverage amounts. 
e.  The city will accept letters and/or certificates of self-insurance which provide the same coverage as required herein. The city shall be notified in writing not fewer than thirty (30) working days prior to any modification of the terms and/or conditions stipulated in the letter and/or certificate. 
(b)  Construction permits. 
(1)  Unless waived by the director of public works, or his/her designee, no person shall perform any construction or installation of facilities in the right-of-way without first obtaining a construction permit, except as provided herein. The permit will be in the name of the person and/or entity which will own the facilities to be constructed. The permit application must be completed and signed by a representative of the owner of the facilities to be constructed. 
Emergency responses related to existing facilities may be undertaken without first obtaining a permit; however, the city shall be contacted by telephone, at a number furnished by the city, and the public works department shall be notified in writing within three (3) business days of any construction related to an emergency response; including a reasonably detailed description of the work performed in the right of way and an updated map of any facilities that were moved. This requirement shall be waived in the event of an on-going, large scale emergency situation as a result of any man-made or natural occurrence which alters or interrupts the normal use of the user's service to its customers. 
(2)  The permit shall state to whom it is issued, the location of work, the location of facilities, dates and times that work is to take place and any other conditions set out by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(3)  The person (applicant) requesting a permit will provide the director of public works or his/her designee with documentation in the format specified by the city describing: 
a.  The proposed, approximate location and route of all facilities to be constructed, repaired, moved or installed and the applicant's plan for right-of-way construction; and the estimated construction time. 
b.  Engineering plans which will be on a scale of one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet unless otherwise approved by the director of public works. 
c.  Detail of the location of all right-of-way and utility easements which applicant plans to use. 
d.  Detail of all existing city utilities and, to the extent known, other facilities in the right-of-way in relationship to applicant's proposed route. 
e.  Detail of what applicant proposes to install, such as pipe size, number of interducts, valves, etc. 
f.  Detail of plans to remove and replace asphalt and/or concrete in the street and/or the right-of-way in accordance with the design improvement standards of the city. 
g.  Drawings of any bores, trenches, handholes, manholes, switch gear, transformers, pedestals, etc. including depth. 
h.  Handhole and/or manhole typical of type of manholes and/or handholes applicant plans to use or access. 
i.  Complete legend of drawings submitted by applicant. 
j.  Two (2) sets of engineering plans must be submitted with permit application. 
k.  The name, address and phone numbers of the contractor or subcontractor who will perform the actual construction, including the name and telephone number of an individual with the contractor who will be available at all times during construction. 
l.  The construction and installation methods to be employed for the protection of existing structures, fixtures, and facilities within or adjacent to the right-of-way, and the dates and times work will occur, all of which (methods, dates, times, etc.) are subject to approval of the director of public works or his/her designee. 
m.  Proof of insurance, bond or other required financial information is current and on file. 
(4)  All construction and installation in the right-of-way shall be in accordance with the permit for the facilities. The director of public works or his/her designee shall be provided access to the work and to such further information as he or she may reasonably require to ensure compliance with the permit. 
(5)  A copy of the construction permit and approved engineering plans shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for inspection by the director of public works or his/her designee at all times when construction or installation work is occurring. 
(6)  All authorized construction or installation work must be completed in the time specified in the construction permit. If the work cannot be completed in the specified time period, the applicant may request an extension in writing from the director of public works, or his/her designee. The work that was authorized under the permit may continue while the request for an extension is pending. 
(7)  A copy of any permit or approval issued by federal or state authorities for work in federal or state right-of-way located in the city. 
(8)  A request for a permit must be submitted at least three (3) working days before the commencement of work proposed in the request for review and approval, unless waived by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(9)  Requests for permits will be approved or disapproved by the director of public works or his/her designee within a reasonable time of receiving all the necessary information. The director of public works or his/her designee will use his/her best efforts to approve or disapprove a request for a construction permit as soon as possible. 
(10)  The director of public works may request a preconstruction meeting with the applicant and their construction contractor. 
(11)  Valid permits are required for all construction whether new, replacement, or upgrading of the company's network facilities in the right-of-way, either aerial or underground. 
(12)  The utility shall be required to enter into a hold harmless agreement as a condition of the permit. Telecommunications providers shall comply with the provisions of section 283.057, Texas Local Government Code, in meeting this requirement. 
(13)  Restoration of right-of-way must be made to a condition which puts the right-of-way back in substantially the same condition as prior to the commencement of the work. Such restoration shall be guaranteed through one (1) full year after the completion of construction. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-79. - Construction standards. 
(a)  The department of public works, or his/her designee, shall be notified twenty-four (24) hours in advance that construction is ready to proceed by either the right-of-way user, their contractor, or representative. 
(b)  All construction shall be in conformance with all city codes and applicable local, state and federal laws. 
(c)  Advance warning signs, markers, cones and barricades must be in place before work begins in accordance with the current edition of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(d)  Applicant may be required to show proof of TNRCC approved plans relating to storm water and erosion when applicable or a letter stating that they are not required to obtain such plans. 
(e)  Lane closures on major thoroughfares will be limited to between 8:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. unless the director of public works, or his/her designee, grants prior approval. 
(f)  Without affecting applicant's authority to pursue liability against its contractors, applicants are responsible for the workmanship and any damages by a contractors or subcontractors. A responsible representative of the applicant will be available to the public works department at all times during construction. 
(g)  Applicant or contractor or subcontractor will notify the public works department immediately of any damage to other utilities, either city or privately owned. 
(h)  Installed facilities must not interfere with city utilities, in particular gravity dependent facilities. 
(i)  New non-municipal, non-electric utilities must be installed at a minimum of two (2) feet depth, unless a lesser depth is approved by the director of public works, or his/her designee. New electric utilities must be installed at a minimum of three (3) feet depth, unless a lesser depth is approved by the director of public works, or his/her designee. Minimum depth requirements do not apply, however, to single, non-electric service drops. 
(j)  All directional boring shall have the locator place bore marks and depths while bore is in progress. Locator shall place mark at each stem with paint dot and depth at least every other stem. 
(k)  Working hours in the rights-of-way are 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Work that needs to be performed after 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday or on Saturday must be approved by the director of public works or his/her designee in advance. Directional boring is permitted only Monday through Friday 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. No work in the right-of-way shall be performed, except for emergencies, on Sunday or city holidays. 
(l)  Contractors working for applicant are responsible for obtaining line locates from all affected utilities prior to any excavation. 
(m)  Applicant will be responsible for verifying the location, both horizontally and vertically of all affected facilities whether by pot holing or hand digging prior to any excavation or boring with the exception of work involving lane closures. 
(n)  Placement of all manholes and/or hand holes must be approved in advance by the director of public works, or his/her designee. 
(o)  No construction or installation work will be initiated unless a construction permit has been obtained from the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-80. - Plans of record plans. 
(a)  Right-of-way users must provide the director of public works or his/her designee with plans of record (also called "as-built" plans) within ten (10) working days of completion of facilities in the right-of-way. Users who have facilities in the right-of-way existing as of the date of this article, and who have not provided "plans of record" shall do so not later than one hundred twenty (120) working days after the passage of this article when available. The plans shall be provided to the city in the format specified by the director of public works or his/her designee and with as much detail and accuracy as required thereby. All the criteria specified for plans submitted for the initial permit will be required for the "plans of record". Submittal of "plans of record" shall be in digital formatting as well as written or in any other format requested by the city. 
(b)  If the release of the location of any utilities or of plans of record submitted under this section would jeopardize public safety, the information shall be considered confidential. In addition, if plans of record submitted under this section include information expressly designated by the right-of-way user as a trade secret or other confidential information protected from disclosure by state law, the city may not disclose that information to the public without the consent of the right-of-way user, unless otherwise compelled by an opinion of the attorney general pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, as amended, or by a court having jurisdiction of the matter pursuant to applicable law. This subsection may not be construed to authorize a right-of-way user to designate all matters in its plans of record as confidential or as trade secrets. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-81. - Conformance with public improvements. 
    Whenever by reasons of widening or straightening of streets, water or sewer line projects, or any other public works projects (e.g. install or improve storm drains, water lines, sewer lines, etc.), it shall be deemed necessary by the city council to remove, alter, change, adapt, or conform the underground or overhead facilities of a right-of-way user, such alterations shall be made by the owner of the facilities at its expense within ninety (90) working days from receipt of notice to make the alternations, unless a different schedule has been approved by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-82. - Improperly installed facilities. 
(a)  Any person doing work in the city right-of-way shall properly install, repair, upgrade and maintain city facilities as determined by the director of public works, or his/her designee. In the event that such work is not acceptable to the director of public works, or his/her designee, such person shall be notified in writing by the director of public works, or his/her designee, and be granted ten (10) working days to correct the unsatisfactory work. Should, however, the unacceptable work be deemed an immediate threat to health and safety by the director of public works, or his/her designee, such person shall be notified verbally by the director of public works, or his/her designee, for immediate corrective action by such person. 
(b)  Facilities shall be considered to be improperly installed, repaired, upgraded or maintained if: 
(1)  The installation, repairs, upgrade or maintenance endangers people or property; 
(2)  The facilities do not meet applicable city codes; 
(3)  The facilities are not capable of being located using standard practices; 
(4)  The facilities are not located in the proper place in accordance with the directions provided by the public works department; or 
(5)  The facilities are placed in an area that interferes with city-owned facilities, including but not limited to water or sewer lines or streets. Non-city-owned facilities shall be considered to interfere with city-owned facilities if the non-city-owned facility is within three (3) feet horizontally of the city-owned facility, or the distance required by the permit, whichever is greater. Nothing in this section shall diminish the authority of the director of public works to direct the specific placement of specific lines. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-83. - Type of facilities. 
(a)  The director of public works, or his/her designee, shall approve the location of underground facilities. 
(b)  When poles are used, location and depth shall be subject to the approval of the director of public works, or his/her designee, as it pertains to possible conflicts with the city's infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-84. - Restoration of property. 
(a)  Users of the right-of-way shall reasonably restore property affected by the construction of facilities to a condition that is equal to or better than the condition of the property prior to the performance of the work. 
(b)  Restoration must be to the reasonable satisfaction of the director of public works, or his/her designee, and shall not be considered complete until approved by the director of public works, or his/her designee. The restoration shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Installation of all manholes and handholes, as required; 
(2)  Backfilling all bore pits, potholes, trenches or any other holes. All such excavations shall be filled in daily, unless other safety requirements are approved by the director of public works, or his/her designee; 
(3)  Leveling of all trenches and backhoe lines; 
(4)  Restoration of excavation site to city specifications including compacting, grading, and appropriate fill material; 
(5)  All locate flags shall be removed during the clean up process by the applicant or his/her contractor at the completion of the work; 
(6)  Restoration must be made in a timely manner as specified by approved schedules and to the satisfaction of the director of public works or his/her designee. If restoration is not satisfactory and/or performed in a timely manner, all work in progress, including all work previously permitted but not completed, will be immediately halted and additional permits shall not be approved until all restoration is complete. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 22-85. - Revocation or denial of permit. 
    If any provisions of this article is not followed, a permit may be revoked by the director of public works, or his/her designee. If a person has not followed the terms and conditions of this article in work done pursuant to a prior permit, new permits may be denied or additional terms required. 
(Ord. No. 02-02, § 1, 3-11-02) 
Chapter 23 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Taxation, Art. VIII; persons indebted to city shall not hold office or employment, Art. XVIII, § 16. 
State Law reference- Taxation generally, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. Title 122, Vol. 20; Title 122A, Vol. 20A. 

Sec. 23-1. - Adoption of state law relative to payment of taxes and penalties. 
    The provisions of state law applicable to municipalities shall apply to and govern the payment of taxes due and owing to the city and penalties and interest in connection therewith, to the same extent as if such provisions have been, by the terms thereof, made applicable to city taxes by ordinances of the city. 
Secs. 23-2-23-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2, Ord. No. 87-15, adopted Mar. 9, 1987, repealed §§ 23-2-23-4 and subsection (b)(3) of § 23-5. Sections 23-2-23-4, relative to personal and real property tax liens and occupation taxes, contained no historical notation and are presumed adopted with the adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 23-5. - Hotel occupancy tax. 
(a)  Definition of terms. The following words, terms and phrases are, for the purpose of this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, defined as follows: 
(1)  Hotel shall mean any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration, but "hotel" shall not be defined so as to include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
(2)  Consideration shall mean the cost of the room in such hotel only if the room is ordinarily used for sleeping, and shall not include the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room for occupancy. 
(3)  Occupancy shall mean the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room in a hotel if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping and if the occupant's use, possession or right to use or possession extends for a period of less than thirty (30) days. 
(4)  Occupant shall mean anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has a right to use or possess, any room in a hotel if the room is ordinarily used for sleeping. 
(5)  Person shall mean any individual, company, corporation, or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
(6)  Tax assessor-collector shall mean the tax assessor-collector of the City of Groves. 
(7)  Quarterly period shall mean the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being composed of the months of January, February and March, the second quarter being the months of April, May and June, the third quarter being the months of July, August and September, and the fourth quarter being the months of October, November and December. 
(8)  Permanent resident shall mean any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or room or sleeping space or facility in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days during the current calendar year or preceding year. 
(b)  Levy of tax; rate. 
(1)  There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any sleeping room furnished by any hotel, where the cost of occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day. Such tax is to be equal to seven (7) per cent of the consideration paid by the occupant of the sleeping room to the hotel, in accordance with V.T.C.A., Tax Code Section 351.001 et seq. 
(2)  No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident. 
(3)  Reserved. 
(4)  All revenue derived from the occupancy tax imposed in paragraph (1) hereof will only be used for the following: 
(i)  The acquisition of sites for and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation and maintenance of convention center facilities, including, but not limited to, civic center convention buildings, auditoriums, coliseums and parking areas or facilities for the parking or storage of motor vehicles or other conveyances located at or in the immediate vicinity of convention center facilities. 
(ii)  The furnishing of facilities, personnel and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants. 
(iii)  For advertising of general promotional and tourist advertising of the City of Groves and its vicinity, and conducting a solicitation and operating program to attract conventions and visitors either by the City of Groves or through contracts with persons or organizations selected by the City of Groves. 
(iv)  A portion of the occupancy tax authorized hereby may be pledged to the payment of bonds which the city may issue pursuant to the provisions of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1269j-4.1 if such bonds are issued solely for one or more of the purposes set forth herein; provided that at least one-half of one per cent (.5%) of the occupancy tax collected hereunder shall be reserved; however, all of such occupancy tax may be reserved, for the purpose of advertising and conducting solicitation programs to acquaint potential users with public meeting and convention facilities, and for promotion of tourism and advertising of the city and its vicinity either by the city or through contract with persons or organizations selected by the city. 
(c)  Collection. Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel shall collect the tax imposed in subsection (b) hereof for the City of Groves. 
(d)  Reports. On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required in subsection (c) hereof to collect the tax imposed herein shall file a report with the tax assessor-collector showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of the tax collection on such occupancies, and any other information as the tax assessor-collector may reasonably require. Such person shall pay the amount of tax collected from occupants during the period of the report at the time of filing the report. 
(e)  Rules and regulations. The tax assessor-collector shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied herein, and shall upon reasonable notice have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this section. 
(f)  Penalty. If any person shall fail to collect the tax imposed herein, or shall fail to file a report as required herein, or shall fail to pay to the tax assessor-collector the tax as imposed herein when said report for payment is due, or shall file a false report, then such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). In addition, such person who fails to remit the tax imposed by this chapter within the time required shall forfeit five (5) per cent of the amount due as a penalty, and after the first thirty (30) days shall forfeit an additional five (5) per cent of such tax. Provided, however, that the penalty shall never be less than one dollar ($1.00). Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of six (6) per cent per annum beginning sixty (60) days from the date due on the tax imposed by this section. 
(Ord. No. 495, § 1, 11-20-72; Ord. No. 638, § 1, 10-31-77; Ord. No. 87-15, §§ 1, 2, 3-9-87; Ord. No. 89-05, § 1, 6-26-89) 
Sec. 23-6. - Exemption to persons sixty-five or over. 
(a)  From and after January 1, 1980, twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) of the assessed value of residence homesteads as defined by law, of persons who have attained the age of sixty-five (65) years on or before January first of the year for which the exemption is claimed shall be exempt from city ad valorem taxes; provided, however, that where the ad valorem tax has heretofore been pledged for the payment of any debt, the taxing officers of the city shall have authority to continue to levy and collect the tax against the homestead property at the same rate as the tax so pledged until the debt is discharged, if the cessation of the levy would impair the obligation of the contract by which the debt was created. 
(b)  In order to secure the benefit of the exemption, the owner shall, between January first and April thirtieth, inclusive, of each year, file with the city tax assessor and collector, on form furnished by the tax assessor-collector, a sworn inventory of such property owned on January first of each year for which the exemption is claimed, and shall initially furnish proof of age by certified copy of his or her birth certificate or, if such person does not have a certificate of birth, then by the affidavit of two (2) persons at least five (5) years older than the exemption claimant with actual knowledge of the date and place of birth and by the original or certified copy of any two, of the following documents, which must be at least five (5) years old, to-wit: 
(1)  Social Security record, 
(2)  Federal census record, 
(3)  State census record, 
(4)  Own child's birth certificate, 
(5)  Original birth notice in newspaper, 
(6)  School record, 
(7)  Insurance policy, 
(8)  Lodge record, 
(9)  Military record, 
(10)  Passport, 
(11)  Marriage record, 
(12)  Hospital record, 
(13)  Voter's registration record, 
(14)  Church baptismal record, 
(15)  Employment record, and 
(16) Physician's  record. 
(Ord. No. 498, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 2-26-73; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 11-1-8-74; Ord. No. 597, 1, 8-9-76; Ord. No. 653A, § 1, 8-7-78; Ord. No. 705, 1, 6-23-80) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 498 did not expressly amend the Code; hence codification as 123-6 was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 23-7. - Exemption for disabled persons. 
(a)  From and after January first, 1980, twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) of the assessed value of residence homesteads as defined by law of persons who are under a disability for purposes of payment of disability insurance benefits under Federal Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance, or its successor, shall be exempt from all ad valorem taxes thereafter levied by the city; provided, however, that where the ad valorem tax has heretofore been pledged for the payment of any debt, the taxing officers of the city shall have authority to continue to levy and collect the tax against the homestead property at the same rate as the tax so pledged until the debt is discharged, if the cessation of the levy would impair the obligation of the contract by which the debt was created. An eligible disabled person who is sixty-five (65) years of age or older may not receive this exemption and the twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) exemption already provided for age, in the same year, but may choose either. 
(b)  In order to secure the benefit of the exemption, the owner shall, between January first and April first of each year, file with the city tax assessor-collector written evidence of eligibility for disability insurance benefits from the Social Security Administration. 
(Ord. No. 680, § 1, 9-17-79; Ord. No. 706, § 1, 6-23-80) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 680, § 1, adopted Sept. 17, 1979, being nonamendatory of the Code has been codified as §§ 23-7. at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 23-8. - Ad valorem tax on leased motor vehicles. 
(a)  Pursuant to and in accordance with section 11.252(f) of the Texas Tax Code, the city council hereby declares its intent to assess a tax on leased motor vehicles that are not used for commercial purposes. 
(b)  The tax rate for such leased motor vehicles shall be in an amount set by city council from year to year as part of the budget and taxing process, or as may otherwise be approved from time to time in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 01-17, § 1, 12-17-01) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-17, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2001, did not specifically amend the Code. Hence, its inclusion herein as section 23-8 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 24 - TAXICABS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license and regulate persons owning, operating or controlling vehicles used for carrying passengers for hire, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(21). 

Sec. 24-1. - City officers, employees not to accept favors from owners or drivers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the city to accept directly or indirectly any gifts, discounts or gratuities from any holder of a taxicab franchise or any taxicab driver or from any person engaged in the repair of taxicabs. 
Sec. 24-2. - Nonbusiness use of vehicle restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any taxicab to use such vehicle for any purpose other than the transporting of passengers for hire, running errands or delivering of packages customarily in the taxicab business. 
(b)  In the event the owner of any vehicle licensed as a taxicab during off duty hours needs the use of such vehicle in his personal affairs, a conspicuous sign with the words "Out of Service" shall be displayed in a prominent place on the taxicab. 
Sec. 24-3. - Property left in vehicle; disposition. 
    All drivers of taxicabs shall promptly deliver to the police department of the city or to their employers all property left in such vehicles by passengers. If a driver delivers such articles to his employer, the latter shall deliver them to the police department. When articles left in taxicabs have been delivered to the office of the city marshal, he shall make an entry of the fact in a book provided for that purpose and shall keep all such articles until claimed by the owner, as the city council may authorize. 
Sec. 24-4. - Maximum seating. 
    It shall be unlawful to carry more than five (5) passengers in any taxicab, and in no event shall more than two (2) passengers ride in the front seat with the driver. 
Sec. 24-5. - Receipt, discharge of passengers. 
    No driver of a taxicab shall receive or discharge passengers in the roadway of any street, but shall drive to the right-hand sidewalk, as nearly as possible, or, in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road, and there receive or discharge passengers. 
Sec. 24-6. - Use of streets for taxicab stand purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab owner or operator to use the public streets or any part thereof as a taxi stand. 
Sec. 24-7. - Parking of taxicabs generally. 
    All taxicabs shall be subject to the sections of this Code, ordinances of the city and state laws concerning parking of motor vehicles. 
Cross reference- Parking regulations, § 25-164 et seq. 
Sec. 24-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1, Ord. No. 87-16, adopted Mar. 9, 1987, repealed §§ 24-8, 24-13 and 24-14, restricting operation of taxicabs on behalf of prostitutes or unlawful establishments, criminals and persons other than for hire, respectively, which sections contained no historical notation and are presumed adopted with the adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 24-9. - Alcoholic beverages-Transportation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to transport alcoholic beverages, not owned and in the exclusive possession and control of a fare paying passenger, in the taxicab or for any taxicab driver to have on his person any alcoholic beverage while driving and operating a taxicab in service. 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 24-10. - Same-Consumption in vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or passenger of any taxicab to drink alcoholic beverages of any kind while inside the taxicab. 
Sec. 24-11. - Same-Sale. 
    No driver of a taxicab or owner of a taxicab shall engage in selling intoxicating liquors or soliciting business for any person selling intoxicating liquors. 
Sec. 24-12. - Cruising prohibited. 
    The practice of cruising the streets of the city is hereby prohibited. 
Secs. 24-13, - 24-14. Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to § 24-8. 
Sec. 24-15. - State chauffeurs license prerequisite to issuance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab within the city unless he is a duly licensed chauffeur under the laws of the state. 
Chapter 241/2 - TOXIC MATERIALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, Ch. 10; flood damage prevention, Ch. 101/2; food and food establishments, Ch. 11; garbage and trash, Ch. 12; health and sanitation, Ch. 13; junk and junk dealers, Ch. 14; oil and gas wells, Ch. 17; police, Ch. 20; traffic, Ch. 25; sewers generally, § 27-44 et seq.; discharge of industrial waste, § 27-50 et seq.; buildings, Ch. 28; plumbing code, Ch. 31; zoning, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 241/2-1-241/2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MANUFACTURE, STORAGE, HANDLING AND DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 83-24, §§ 1-13, adopted Dec. 5, 1983, amended the Code by the addition of the provisions herein set out; designation as Art. II, Divs. 1, 2, §§ 241/2-21-241/2-28, 241/2-41-241/245, was at the discretion of the editor. Penalty provisions, duplicative of § 1-5 of this Code, set out in § 14 of said ordinance have been left uncodified. For a complete account of the disposition of individual sections of said ordinance, see the history note following each Code section, and the Code Comparative Table at the back of this volume. 
Cross reference- General penalty for violation of Code, § 1-5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 241/2-21. - Applicability. 
    The manufacturing, storage, handling and disposal of toxic materials within the city shall be, and is hereby, controlled by the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 1, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-22. - Definition. 
    Toxic materials, as referred to in this article are obnoxious, toxic or poisonous solids, liquids and gasses. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 2, 12-5-83) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction, definitions generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 241/2-23. - Exceptions from article. 
    Retail sales of containers of household chemicals normally sold in retail stores or petroleum products normally sold in service stations or other retail establishments are excepted from this article. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 3, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-24. - Proximity to adjoining property. 
    No toxic material operation shall be conducted within two hundred (200) feet of any adjoining property line without the express written consent of the owner of said adjoining property. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 9, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-25. - Proximity to roadways, easements, drainage systems, water lines or sewer lines. 
    Toxic material operations conducted adjacent to roadways, easements, drainage systems, water lines or sewer lines shall be conducted at an adequate distance from such facilities, as determined by the building official, so as not to interfere with or cause damage to such facilities. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 10, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-26. - Fence required. 
    The tract of land upon which the toxic material operations are conducted must be fenced with a substantial industrial grade fence at least six (6) feet in height. Such fence shall be kept in good repair. All gates shall be closed except as is necessary for ingress and egress. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 11, 12-5-83) 
Cross reference- Screening walls and fences, Ch. 33. 
Sec. 241/2-27. - Trucks to use truck routes. 
    Trucks transporting toxic materials shall be required to use existing truck routes in the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 12, 12-5-83) 
Cross reference- Truck routes, § 25-134 
Sec. 241/2-28. - Nuisance. 
    The handling of toxic waste without complying with all of the provisions of this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be summarily abated by the police department of the city. This remedy is in addition to the penal provision provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 13, 12-5-83) 
Cross reference- General penalty for violation of Code, § 1-5. 
Sec. 241/2-29. - Transports responsible for discharge, leak, etc. of hazardous materials. 
(a)  The Code of Federal Regulations Title 49, Parts 100 to 177, revised as of October 1, 1993, is annexed hereto and incorporated herein by reference. 
(b)  Hazardous substances will be defined for the purposes of this section as any substance that meets at least one (1) of the following criteria: 
(1)  Any petroleum product or by-product. 
(2)  Any mixture or solution containing material identified by the CFR 49, 172.101 as materials in a reportable quantity. 
(c)  The owner and/or carrier of any container, package, tank or vessel or the contents therein shall be responsible for all costs, to include standby costs, incurred by the city for the cleanup and restoration of any area within the jurisdiction of the city resulting from contamination by any hazardous substance described in subsection (b) hereof. 
(d)  If there is no actual discharge, leak, release or spill of a hazardous substance but rather the imminent potential for a discharge, leak, release or spill, as determined in the reasonable judgment of the chief of the Groves fire department or his designee, the owner and/or carrier shall be responsible for all costs, to include standby costs, incurred by any city agency due to the presence or threat of release of a hazardous substance. 
(Ord. No. 95-12, §§ 1-4, 10-9-95) 
Secs. 241/2-30-241/2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 241/2-41. - Required. 
    Every person, firm or corporation desiring to engage in the manufacturing, storage, handling and disposal of toxic materials within the city shall first obtain a permit therefor, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 4, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-42. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a permit required by the provisions of this article shall file a sworn written application therefor with the building official, which application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The purpose of the proposed use of the land upon which the manufacturing, storage, handling and disposal of toxic materials is proposed to be conducted; 
(2)  The names of all owners of land lying within five hundred (500) feet of the proposed operation; 
(3)  An accurate drawing showing the location, dimensions and general features such as proposed buildings, tanks, drainage facilities, utility systems, and other items as may be required by the building official; 
(4)  A complete explanation of the nature of the materials to be handled and the specific hazards involved in the handling of toxic, objectionable materials; 
(5)  A safety data sheet on all toxic materials to be handled or stored on the site; 
(6)  A full disclosure of all phases of the proposed operation, in order that it may be determined whether the operation is consistent with the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens; 
(7)  A statement that all provisions of this article will be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 5, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-43. - Fee. 
    At the time the application for a permit to be issued under the provisions of this article is filed with the building official, the applicant therefor shall pay to the building official a permit fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Should the permit be denied or refused, the fee will be refunded to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 6, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-44. - Issuance. 
    The building official shall issue a permit if the evidence furnished with the application concerning the proposed operation shows that the operation will not adversely affect the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens and that no adverse environmental impact would result from such operation. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 7, 12-5-83) 
Sec. 241/2-45. - Appeal from denial. 
    Upon the denial of a permit by the building official, the applicant may, within ten (10) days, appeal such denial to the city council. The city council shall set a public hearing not later than thirty (30) days after presentation of the appeal. After such public hearing, the city council may affirm, overrule or modify the decision of the building official and such ruling of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 83-24, § 8, 12-5-83) 
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 87-17, § 1(2)-(50), adopted Mar. 9, 1987, repealed the following sections or subsections of this chapter, relative to various traffic regulations: §§ 25-8-25-10; 25-12; 25-14; 25-16(a); 25-17; 25-29; 25-30; 25-32; 25-33(a); 25-34, 25-49; 25-51-25-53; 25-55-25-57; 25-59; 25-60; 25-72-25-76; 25-78; 25-80; 25-83; 25-84(b); 25-85-25-87; 25-94; 25-95; 25-104-25-106; 25-119; 25-120; 25-125; 25-126; 25-128; 25-151; 25-152.1; 25-153; 25-165(a)(1)-(6); 25-167; 25-168; 25-171; 25-200; 25-201 and 25-203.
