Sec. 25-150. - In city park. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in excess of ten (10) miles per hour within the boundaries of any city park unless otherwise posted. 
(Ord. No. 136, § 1, 4-7-58) 
Sec. 25-151. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to this chapter title. 
Sec. 25-152. - Minimum limits. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle at such a slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic, except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation or in compliance with law. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 170(a). 
Secs. 25-152.1, - 25-153. Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to this chapter title. 
Secs. 25-154-25-163. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Application of parking regulations to taxicabs, § 24-7. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(1). 

Sec. 25-164. - Presumption that owner of vehicle illegally parked same. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any applicable provision of this Code, or of any other ordinance or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
Sec. 25-165. - Impoundment of standing or parked vehicles-Generally. 
(a)  Any vehicle which shall be or remain standing or parked upon any public street, avenue, way, alley or other public place may be removed by or upon order of the city marshal, and placed in storage in a privately operated garage or other place designated by or maintained by the city. 
(b)  In order to obtain possession of a vehicle stored under the provisions of this section, the claimant must produce satisfactory evidence of ownership or right to possession within thirty (30) days from the date of such storage and, in addition thereto, must pay all charges for storage and removal of such vehicle, in addition to any fine. 
(c)  If a vehicle removed under this section is not claimed within thirty (30) days from the date of storage, the same may be sold by the city or the garage where the same is stored, for storage charges, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 71, § 2, 4-25-55; Ord. No. 87-17, § 1(44), 3-9-87) 
State Law reference- Removal of illegally parked vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 94. 
Sec. 25-166. - Same-Liability of city. 
    The provisions of section 25-165 shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person who shall leave his vehicle parked on the streets of the city in such a manner that the same may be impounded; nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of impounding or causing to be impounded such vehicle. 
Secs. 25-167, 25-168. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to this chapter title. 
Sec. 25-169. - Starting parked vehicle. 
    No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless and until such movement can be made with safety. 
State Law reference- Vernon's Ann. Civ. St., art. 6701d, § 67. 
Sec. 25-170. - Twelve feet of roadway to be left available for traffic. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than twelve (12) feet of the width of either lane of a roadway for free movement of the vehicular traffic, except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals of a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 561, § 1, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 25-171. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to this chapter title. 
Sec. 25-172. - Parallel and angle parking. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this section. On one-way streets, vehicles may be parked on the left side of the street, with the left-hand wheels within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, unless signs prohibit parking. 
(b)  The traffic engineer, with the approval of the city council, shall determine upon which streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal aid or state highway within the city unless the state highway commission has determined by resolution or order entered in its minutes that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street or upon any railway tracks. 
(c)  Upon those streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to, and with the hood or front end of such vehicle next to, the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(d)  Whenever parking spaces are marked by lines on the pavement, whether for parallel or angle parking, a vehicle must be parked entirely within the lines of the parking space. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 96. 
Sec. 25-173. - Designation and marking of parking stalls and areas where parking is prohibited or limited. 
    The traffic engineer shall cause parking stalls to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets and parts thereof as may be designated by the city council from time to time and he shall cause spaces in which parking is prohibited to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets and parts thereof as may be designated by the city council from time to time. The traffic engineer shall also cause time limit parking areas to be maintained and marked off in and on such part or parts of streets as may be designated by the city council from time to time. All such spaces or areas shall be clearly indicated by appropriate signs or by markings on the pavement or curb. 
    In areas designated as time limit parking areas, parking may be limited to any period prescribed by the council, the same to be designated with clearly distinguished markings or signs at both ends of the time limit area and at reasonable intervals between the beginning and ending of such time limit area, indicating the time allowed for parking in such area. 
    Any prohibition of or time limit on parking established under this section shall apply on such days and between such hours as prescribed by the council. 
Sec. 25-174. - Parking in prohibited areas; overtime parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or owned or operated by him or in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any space or area in which parking is prohibited, as provided in section 25-173, or in a time limit parking area for a longer period of time than that designated by the markings on the street or by signs clearly visible. 
Sec. 25-175. - Parking or standing in alleys. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to block the free passage of other vehicles in such alley. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a), it shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in any alley within the fire limits of the city, except when such vehicle is actually being used for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
Sec. 25-176. - Parking for more than seventy-two hours prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to allow, cause or permit such vehicle to remain standing or parked on any street, alley, avenue or public way within the city for more than seventy-two (72) hours continuously. 
Sec. 25-177. - Loading and unloading generally. 
    All freight trucks shall be, and are hereby required, to be loaded and unloaded from the alley entrance, if practicable. Where conditions are such as to make the loading or unloading thereof from an alley impracticable, such trucks shall be parked on the street in accord with all applicable provisions of this article. 
Sec. 25-178. - Loading, unloading zones-Designation. 
    The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to determine and designate the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions therefor are applicable. 
Sec. 25-179. - Same-Use of passenger zones. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zones are effective, and then only for a period of time not to exceed three (3) minutes, except when such spaces are adjacent to and serving a hotel or bus station, when such period of time may not exceed fifteen (15) minutes. 
Sec. 25-180. - Same-Use of freight zones. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any length of time in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during the hours so set aside except that commercial vehicles may so stop, stand or park for the expeditious unloading and delivery or loading and pickup of material. In no case shall the stop for unloading, loading, pickup or delivery of material exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
    The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a freight curb loading zone for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping, standing or parking does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
Sec. 25-181. - Permit to back to curb for loading or unloading. 
    The city marshal is authorized to issue special permits of such fee as may be determined by the city council from time to time to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized herein, and it shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
Sec. 25-182. - Vehicles exceeding twenty-five feet. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle, trailer or combination thereof on the streets, alleys or other public ways of the city which shall exceed twenty-five (25) feet in length for more than two (2) hours, unless obstructing traffic. 
Sec. 25-183. - Parking for the disabled; enforcement; offense; penalty for violation etc. 
(a)  Under the authority given by Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, Article 6675a-5e.1, the police department of the city is hereby authorized and empowered to enforce parking regulations for the disabled by filing charges against any person who commits an offense at any place within the city at a parking space designated specifically for temporarily or permanently disabled persons in accordance with said act. 
(b)  A person commits an offense hereunder in accordance with Article 6675a-5e.1: 
(1)  If the person is neither temporarily nor permanently disabled nor transporting a temporarily or permanently disabled person and parks the vehicle with such special device or displaying a disabled person identification card in a parking space or parking area designated specifically for the disabled; 
(2)  If the person parks the vehicle neither displaying the special device nor displaying a disabled person identification card in a parking space or parking area designated specifically for the disabled; 
(3)  If the person parks a vehicle so that the vehicle blocks an access or curb ramp or any other architectural improvement designed to aid the disabled; 
(4)  If he lends an identification card issued to him for disabled parking as provided by the state law. 
(c)  An offense under this section is a Class C misdemeanor. In a prosecution of an offense under this section, it is presumed that the registered owner of the motor vehicle that is the subject of the prosecution is the person who parked the vehicle at the time and place the offense occurred. 
(Ord. No. 88-27, §§ 1-3, 10-31-88) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-27, §§ 1-3, adopted Oct. 31, 1988, being not expressly amendatory of this Code, has been included as § 25-183 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 25-184-25-192. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 25-193. - Application of article. 
    Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic-control signals as provided in this chapter, but at all other places pedestrians shall be granted those rights and be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 76(a). 
Sec. 25-194. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
    When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk, when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger, but no pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle, which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
    Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 77. 
Sec. 25-195. - When pedestrian shall yield. 
    Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at any intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
    Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St., art. 6701d, § 78(a, b). 
Sec. 25-196. - When crosswalk required for crossings. 
    Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St., art. 6701d, § 76(b). 
Sec. 25-197. - Use of crosswalks required at intersections: crossing between intersection. 
(a)  All crossings by any pedestrian of any intersection within the corporate limits of the city shall be made within the crosswalk of such intersection. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to cross a street at any place other than an intersection, but when any such crossing is made or being made by any pedestrian he shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon such street approaching such place of crossing and in proximity thereto. It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cause any vehicle to stop or for such pedestrian to cause any interference with the movements of any vehicle by reason of such crossing at such place. 
Sec. 25-198. - Roadway to be crossed at right angles; exception. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in crosswalk. 
Sec. 25-199. - Walking on roadways. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a street or highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 81(a, b). 
Secs. 25-200, - 25-201. Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to this chapter title. 
Sec. 25-202. - Use right half of crosswalk. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever possible, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 80. 
Sec. 25-203. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to this chapter title. 
Chapter 26 - INDUSTRIALIZED MODULAR STRUCTURES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, adopted June 18, 2012, repealed the former Ch. 26, §§ 26-1-26-15, and enacted a new Ch. 26, as set out herein. The former Ch. 26 was entitled "Mobile Home Parks and Mobile Home Subdivisions", and derived from: Ord. No. 388, §§ 1-15, adopted on April 1, 1968; and Ord. No. 84-11, adopted July 16, 1984. 
Cross reference- Mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions, App. A, § 10-800; mobile home subdivisions, App. B, § 10. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Short title. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be known as the "City of Groves Industrialized/Modular Structure Code" and may be cited as such. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-2. - Purpose. 
    The City of Groves, recognizes the hazards of being a coastal city and hereby prohibits the placement of a mobile home, a housing and urban development home, or a trailer home within the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-3. - Definitions. 
    "HUD-code manufactured home" is: 
(1)  A structure constructed on or after June 15, 1976, according to the rules of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development; 
(2)  Built on a permanent chassis; 
(3)  Designed for use as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when the structure is connected to the required utilities; 
(4)  Transportable in one (1) or more sections; 
(5)  In the traveling mode, at least eight (8) body feet in width or at least forty (40) body feet in length or, when erected on-site, at least three hundred twenty (320) square feet; 
(6)  Includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems of the home; and 
(7)  Does not include a recreational vehicle. 
    "Industrialized/modular housing" is a residential structure that is: 
(1)  Designed for the occupancy of one (1) or more families; 
(2)  Constructed in one (1) or more modules or constructed using one (1) or more modular components built at a location other than the permanent site; 
(3)  Designed to be used as a permanent residential structure when the modular or the modular component is transported to the permanent site or installed on a permanent foundation system; 
(4)  Industrialized housing includes the structure's plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. 
"Industrialized/modular housing" does not include: 
a.  A residential structure that exceeds three (3) stories or forty-nine (49) feet in height as measured from the finished grade elevation at the building entrance to the peak of the roof; 
b.  Housing constructed of a sectional or panelized system that does not use a modular component; or 
c.  A ready-built home constructed in a manner in which the entire living area is contained in a single unit or section at a temporary location for the purpose of selling and moving the home to another location. 
    An "industrialized/modular building" is a commercial structure that is: 
(1)  Constructed in one (1) or more modules or constructed using one (1) or more modular components built at a location other than the commercial site; and 
(2)  Designed to be used as a commercial building when the module or the modular component is transported to the commercial site and erected or installed. 
(3)  An industrialized/modular building includes the structure's plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. 
(4)  An industrialized/modular building includes a permanent commercial structure and a commercial structure designed to be transported from one (1) commercial site to another commercial site. 
"Industrialized/modular building" does not include: 
a.  A commercial structure that exceeds three (3) stories or forty-nine (49) feet in height as measured from the finished grade elevation at the building entrance to the peak of the roof; or 
b.  A commercial building or structure that is installed in a manner other than on a permanent foundation; and either is: 
1.  Not open to the public; or 
2.  Less than one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet in total area and used other than as a school or a place of religious worship. 
    "Manufactured home". The manufactured home must not have been constructed before June 15, 1976. The unit must have been built to the manufactured housing construction safety standards as evidenced by having a small, red metallic label attached to it. 
    "Mobile home" is: 
(1)  A structure constructed before June 15, 1976; 
(2)  Built on a permanent chassis; 
(3)  Designed for use as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when the structure is connected to the required utilities; 
(4)  Transportable in one (1) or more sections; and 
(5)  In the traveling mode, at least eight (8) body feet in width or at least forty (40) body feet in length or, when erected on-site, at least three hundred twenty (320) square feet; and 
(6)  Includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems of the home. 
    "Recreational vehicle" means a vehicle that is primarily designed as a temporary living quarters for recreational camping or travel use and that is permanently tied to, affixed, or anchored to the premises as in the case of a park model unit. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-4. - Municipal regulation of industrialized housing and buildings. 
    Industrialized/modular structures. Any person wishing to place an industrialized/modular housing unit or units within the city shall submit the engineered/architectural building plans to the building official for review. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-5. - Determining eligibility. 
    An engineered/architectural set of plans shall be submitted to the building official for review to determine eligibility for placement and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  a.  The determined wind load resistance of the module. 
b.  An elevation depicting the type of exterior siding, roofing materials and roof pitch. 
c.  A detail of the permanent foundation for which the industrialized/modular unit shall be placed upon. 
d.  Compliance with the municipal standards for square footage, and other site requirements applicable to single-family dwellings. 
(2)  The industrialized/modular unit shall have a value equal to or greater than the median taxable value for each single-family dwelling located within five hundred (500) feet of the lot on which the industrialized housing is proposed to be located, as determined by the most recent certified tax appraisal roll for each county in which the properties are located. 
(3)  The modular unit shall have exterior siding, roofing, roof pitch, foundation fascia, and fenestration compatible with the single-family dwellings located within five hundred (500) feet of the lot on which the industrialized housing is proposed to be located. 
(4)  The modular unit shall comply with municipal aesthetic standards, building setbacks, side and rear yard offsets, subdivision control, architectural landscaping, square footage, and other site requirements applicable to single-family dwellings. 
(5)  The modular unit shall be securely fixed to an engineered permanent foundation. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Secs. 26-6-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXISTING MOBILE HOME PARKS 

Sec. 26-26. - License and fees for existing mobile home parks. 
(a)  Annual license fee. Before any mobile home park may be occupied, application shall be made to the city for a mobile home park license. Upon application for a mobile home park license or the renewal thereof, the applicant shall pay to the city a minimum fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) or four dollars ($4.00) for each mobile home space, whichever is greater. Said license shall be renewed in January of each year. 
(b)  Monthly parking fee. 
(1)  In addition to the above license fee, each licensee is hereby required to remit to the city on the first day of each month, a monthly parking fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each occupied mobile home space. This fee is deemed equal to the actual cost of municipal services furnished by the city, including maintenance, debt retirement, general administrative costs, including, but without limitations because of lack of specific enumeration hereon, the following: fire protection, police protection, health services and street maintenance. Said fee shall be paid by the owner of said property to the city on or before the tenth day of the month following the month for which such parking permit fee is due. 
(2)  The licensee of a park shall be liable for the monthly parking permit fee for any mobile home occupying space therein. 
(c)  Failure on the part of the licensee of a park to pay the fees as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) above, will result in forfeiture of the right to renew the annual license and the right to replace any mobile home within the park with an industrialized/modular structure. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-27. - Revocation of mobile home park license. 
    A mobile home park license may be revoked or suspended by the building official for any period of time after a sixty-day written notice sent to the license holder and upon determination by him that: 
(1)  That the license holder or any employee of the license holder has violated or is failing to comply and maintain said mobile home park in compliance with the requirements set forth in this chapter and any other applicable ordinance. 
(2)  The license holder or any employee of the license holder has refused to allow the building official or any of his inspectors, the fire marshal, the city marshal, or any other duly authorized employee of the city to enter upon the mobile home park at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspecting same for compliance with the provision of this chapter or any other applicable city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-28. - Application of provisions to existing mobile homes. 
(a)  Where an existing mobile home becomes damaged to the extent that the cost to repair said mobile home exceeds fifty (50) per cent of the appraised value of said mobile home, such mobile home shall be demolished or removed from the mobile home park. The replacement of said mobile home shall meet the requirements of section 26-5. 
(b)  There are mobile homes now located at the following places within the city which do not conform to some or all of the requirements as set forth in this chapter and which will hereafter fall in the category of mobile home parks as follows: 
Location Number of 
Mobile Homes Permitted 6116-6126 Capitol 6 6150-60 Hansen 4 6341 Gulfway 22 6345 Gulfway 37  
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any of the above mobile home parks to exceed the total number of approved spaces as listed herein. And it is specifically provided that license shall be obtained and parking fees be paid in accordance with section 26-26 of this chapter. The failure to obtain a license and pay the fees as provided for herein shall result in a forfeiture of the right to renew the license and to renew any inhabited mobile home space. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Secs. 26-29-26-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 

Sec. 26-49. - Application for a recreational vehicle park. 
    Any person wishing to develop a recreational vehicle park or in case of an existing mobile home park, wishing to extend, alter, expand and/or improve within the corporate limits of the City of Groves shall first make application to the Planning and Zoning Commission of the City of Groves for a specific use permit as required in appendix A Zoning of the City of Groves Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-50. - License and fees for (RV) recreational vehicle parks. 
(a)  Annual license fee. Before any RV park may be occupied, application shall be made to the city for a RV park license. Upon application for a RV park license or the renewal thereof, the applicant shall pay to the city a minimum fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) or five dollars ($5.00) for each RV space, whichever is greater. Said license shall be renewed in January of each year. 
(b)  Monthly parking fee. In addition to the above license fee, each licensee is hereby required to remit to the city on the first day of each month, a monthly parking fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each RV space. This fee is deemed equal to the actual cost of municipal services furnished by the city, including maintenance, debt retirement, general administrative costs, including, but without limitations because of lack of specific enumeration hereon, the following: fire protection, police protection, health services and street maintenance. Said fee shall be paid by the owner of said property to the city on or before the tenth day of the month following the month for which such parking permit fee is due. 
(c)  The licensee of a park shall be liable for the monthly parking permit fee for any RV occupying space therein. Failure on the part of the licensee of a park to pay the fees as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) above, will result in forfeiture of the right to renew the annual license and the right to replace any recreational vehicle in the park. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-51. - Revocation of (RV) recreational vehicle park license. 
    An RV park license may be revoked or suspended by the building official for any period of time after a sixty-day written notice is sent to the license holder and upon determination by him that: 
(1)  That the license holder or any employee of the license holder has violated or is failing to comply and maintain said RV park in compliance with the requirements set forth in this chapter and any other applicable ordinance. 
(2)  The license holder or any employee of the license holder has refused to allow the building official or any of his inspectors, the fire marshal, the city marshal, or any other duly authorized employee of the city to enter upon the RV park at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspecting same for compliance with the provision of this chapter or any other applicable city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-52. - Minimum standards for recreational vehicle park. 
    Any recreational vehicle park (RV) hereinafter established, constructed, erected, and in case of existing parks, that portion extended, altered, expanded and/or improved shall conform to and comply with the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Park area. Each recreational vehicle park shall provide a minimum of five (5) acres in area. 
(2)  Density. Each recreational vehicle park shall not exceed a maximum density of fifteen (15) spaces per acre as determined by the total area bounded by the mobile home park property lines. 
(3)  Private streets. Private streets shall be provided and shall extend continuously from the public street right-of-way so as to provide suitable access to all spaces and other facilities or uses permitted in said park. Private streets shall meet the following standards. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-53. - Minimum pavement widths. 
    Minimum pavement widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Private streets which provide direct access recreational vehicle spaces: twenty (20) feet. 
(2)  Private street intersections shall generally be at right angles, offsets at intersections of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet (centerline to centerline) should be avoided, intersection of more than two (2) streets at one (1) point should be avoided. 
(3)  Dead-end private streets shall be limited to a maximum length of one thousand (1,000) feet and shall be provided with a vehicular turning space, with a turning circle of eighty (80) feet in diameter. 
(4)  All private streets shall be provided with a smooth asphalt surface which shall be durable and well drained under normal use and weather conditions. 
(5)  Private streets which may connect two (2) public street rights-of-way shall by the use of curves, offsets, locations, and/or the use of two (2) or more streets be located so as to discourage through traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-54. - Recreational vehicle space. 
    Each and every space shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Be served with sanitary sewer, water, electrical power. 
(2)  Provide an average minimum width of thirty (30) feet and an average minimum depth of seventy-five (75) feet and contain a minimum of two thousand two hundred fifty (2,250) square feet. 
(3)  Abut and/or have access to a private street for a minimum distance of twelve (12) feet. 
(4)  Setbacks for supplementary structure. No physical structure, dumpster container, carport, canopy, awning, fence or storage locker shall be permitted within ten (10) feet of a private street, provided further, the setbacks from the sides and rear shall be three (3) feet, save and except a fence, from any lot line not adjacent to the private street. 
(5)  Provide a minimum of two (2) off-street parking per RV space. 
(6)  Double frontage of RV spaces should be avoided. 
(7)  No vehicular access to a RV space is permitted from a public-dedicated street. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-55. - Useable open space. 
(a)  Conveniently situated and containing a minimum of two thousand two hundred fifty (2,250) square feet for each fifteen (15) RV spaces. 
(b)  Such open space may be in one (1) or more areas but shall be of such size and shape as to afford reasonable use by the occupants. 
(c)  No portion of such required useable open space shall be used for off-street parking, vehicular drive loading areas or accessory uses, save and except recreational uses such as swimming pools and tennis courts. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-56. - Visitor parking. 
    Off-street parking for visitors shall be provided at a rate of two (2) parking spaces for each RV lot. Off-street parking spaces not located on the RV lot shall be located on or within the park and be easily accessible to the occupants and visitors; said places shall: 
(1)  Have a permanent asphalt all-weather surface. 
(2)  Have dimensions of not less than nine (9) feet by eighteen (18) feet. 
(3)  Be accessible to an asphalt all-weather surfaced private street. 
(4)  Be appropriately defined and marked. 
(5)  Provide adequate barriers to keep any parked vehicle from extending into or overhanging any private street. 
(6)  Be so designed that any vehicle may be parked without requiring the moving of any other vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-57. - Setbacks. 
    All RV spaces shall be located at a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet from any RV park property boundary line abutting upon a public-dedicated street and twenty-five (25) [feet from] all other property lines. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-58. - Lighting. 
    The private streets, parking lots, walks, and service areas shall be kept properly and adequately illuminated at all times so the RV park shall be safe for occupants and visitors; provided further, all entrances and exits shall be illuminated. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-59. - Refuse disposal. 
    Facilities shall be provided for the storage, collection, and disposal of refuse of the occupants of the RV park. Refuse containers (dumpsters) shall be located no closer than twenty-five (25) feet to any property line and maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-60. - Fire protection. 
    Adequate fire hydrants must be provided for each RV park. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-61. - Screening. 
    A six-foot permanent screening fence or wall shall be constructed along the boundary lines of the RV park. Refuse containers (dumpsters) shall be screened in the same manner. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Sec. 26-62. - Laundromats. 
    Laundromats consisting of no less than two (2) washers and two (2) dryers shall be available for each fifteen (15) RV spaces. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Secs. 26-63-26-82. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VARIANCES 

Sec. 26-83. - Authority of city council to allow specific permit variances. 
    When a developer shows that a provision of these regulations would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to; and where in the opinion of the city planning commission, a departure may be made without destroying the spirit of these regulations, the city planning commission may recommend to the city council, and the city council, at its sole discretion authorize a variance at the time of issuing the specific use permit. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Secs. 26-84-26-100. - Reserved. 
Chapter 27 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Utilities, art. XVII. 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash, ch. 12; health and sanitation, ch. 13; trailers, mobile homes and mobile home parks, ch. 26; electrical code, ch. 29; housing code, ch. 30; plumbing code, ch. 31. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Customer, consumer. The person purchasing water, sewer, garbage or any other utility service from the city. 
    Department. The department of the city functioning and controlling water, the sewer or other utility service within the city. 
    Utility, utility service. Water, sewer, garbage collection or any other utility service furnished by the city to customers or consumers. 
(Ord. No. 41, § 1, 4-29-54; Ord. No. 353, § 1, 9-19-66) 
Cross reference- General definitions and rules of construction, § 1-3. 
Sec. 27-2. - Liability of city for damage. 
    The city shall not be liable for any damage to the property of any consumer of any utility service furnished by the city due to failure of water pressure, backflow of the sewerage system or any other cause affecting any utility service outside the direct control of the city. 
Sec. 27-3. - Trespass at city reservoir. 
    Any person entering and trespassing on the grounds of the city reservoir without the consent and permission of the superintendent of the water and sewer department or other person in charge of the reservoir shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 34, § 1, 3-11-54) 
Cross reference- Malicious mischief generally, § 16-23; climbing water towers or utility poles, § 16-31. 
Sec. 27-4. - Establishment of restricted zone at the raw water intake. 
    As required by the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) Permanent Volume of Rules, Chapter 290, "Water Hygiene" (290.42(e)(2)(C)), there is hereby established a restricted zone of two hundred (200) feet radius from the raw water intake works of the city. All recreational activities and trespassing are hereby prohibited in this area, which shall be designated with signs recounting these restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 96-03, § 1, 3-25-96) 
Sec. 27-5. - Trespass prohibited at restricted zone of the raw water intake. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon and trespass on the grounds of the restricted zone (within a two hundred-foot radius of the raw water intake for the city potable water supply) without the consent and permission of the director of public works and engineering, or other person in charge of the raw water intake works of the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-03, § 1, 3-25-96) 
Sec. 27-6. - Water service required. 
    It shall be the duty of every person, corporation or firm that owns, occupies, rents or leases any building within the city to apply for and maintain water utility service. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 3-16-09) 
Secs. 27-7-27-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 27-14. - Permission required for private collection of garbage, trash, etc.; application for city utility service. 
(a)  Permit. Control of the collection of garbage, trash, rubbish and junk is vested in the city and the collection thereof on a regular basis for hire is prohibited except upon written permission from the city manager. 
(b)  Application for service. Written application shall be made for water, sewer, or any other utility service that may be furnished by the city to the city upon forms furnished therefor. Such application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the type of utility service desired, the purposes for which the application is made and such other information as the city may request. 
(Ord. No. 353, §§ 2, 4, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 785, § 1, 9-13-82) 
Cross reference- Public utilities communications regulations, § 27-87 et seq. 
Sec. 27-15. - Service connections-Made by city. 
    The department shall install and maintain all utility service connections in the streets, alleys, or easements within the city, to the property line of the consumer if the distance from the main to the property line does not exceed twenty-five (25) feet except where a tie-in directly across the street is required and then an extension to the property line shall not exceed sixty (60) feet. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-16. - Service connections-Fees. 
    For each utility service tap or connection, the city shall charge the applicant therefore fees as set forth below: 
(1)  Water 
3/4-inch service ..... $ 500.00 
1-inch service ..... 600.00 
Over one-inch service-Actual cost of material and labor plus ten (10) per cent of cost of material plus twenty (20) per cent of cost of labor. 
(2)  Sewer. 
4-inch line ..... $ 400.00 
Over four-inch line-Actual cost of material and labor plus ten (10) per cent of cost of material plus twenty (20) per cent of cost of labor. 
(3)  Additional fee for unconventional taps. Taps requiring the saw cutting of concrete streets, or boring below or under concrete streets, or any excavations exceeding six (6) feet in depth, shall be charged the actual cost of material, equipment and labor plus ten (10) per cent of material plus twenty (20) per cent of cost of labor. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 1, 12-19-55; Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 560, § 1, 3-24-75; Ord. No. 756, § 1, 10-12-81; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 1, 5-14-07; Ord. No. 2017-12, § 1, 9-18-17) 
Sec. 27-17. - Same-Individual taps. 
    Each water customer shall have an individual water service tap and service line, and the same shall be carried in his own name or in the name of some firm, association or corporation with its agent making the application in its behalf. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3(d), 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-18. - Same-Multiple service. 
    Where multiple service is desired from one (1) tap, each utility service shall be at the regular price in accordance with section 27-16. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-19. - Meters-Required. 
    Meters shall be required to measure the consumption of each utility service furnished by the city, except garbage collection and sewerage service. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-20. - Same-Installation, maintenance. 
    All meters required by this chapter and used to measure the consumption of utility services furnished by the city shall be installed and maintained by the city. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-21. - Same-Ownership. 
    All meters used for the measurement of the consumption of any utility service furnished by the city shall be the property of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to install or maintain any meter for such purposes anywhere within the city which is not owned by the city. 
Sec. 27-22. - Same-Tampering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a duly authorized employee of the city, to tamper with any meter; or to in any manner injure any meter; or to manipulate or attempt to manipulate any meter in any manner so as to affect its registration or measurement of the metered utility service. 
Cross reference- Malicious mischief generally, § 16-23. 
Sec. 27-23. - Same-Malfunctions. 
    If any meter required by this article goes out of order, fails to register or develops any other malfunction, the consumer will be charged at the average bimonthly consumption rate, as shown by the meter in the last six (6) months or such lesser time as has elapsed. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-24. - Same-Testing. 
    When a test of any meter installed pursuant to the provisions of this article is requested, and in the event the meter is found to be two (2) per cent fast, the city shall adjust the customer's bill and no charge will be made; however, if the meter is slow or accurate, there shall be a twenty dollar ($20.00) charge made to the customer for such testing. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 5, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 482, § 1, 7-31-72; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-6-81; Ord. No. 98-17, § 1, 11-2-98) 
Sec. 27-25. - Water deposit. 
    Along with the application for new water service, the applicant shall pay to the city a deposit as follows: 
(1)  Residential: A deposit of one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) shall be required. 
(2)  Commercial: A deposit equal to the charges for an average two-month period. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 526, § 1, 12-17-73; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 4-8-74; Ord. No. 84-15, § 1, 8-13-84; Ord. No. 95-13, § 1, 11-6-95; Ord. No. 2013-17, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 27-25.1. - Water turn-on fee. 
    There shall be charged and collected from each new water customer within the city a water turn-on fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 9-20-04; Ord. No. 2013-17, § 2, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 27-26. - Deposit refund. 
(a)  Any deposit made to the city by any applicant shall be held by the city until such applicant's utility service for which the deposit was made shall be terminated. 
(b)  Upon termination of such service, the applicant shall be entitled to a refund of such deposit, less any amount which is due and owing to the city. Should the account not be paid in full, the city shall have the right to discontinue service and bill for the excess account balance. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 3, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 2013-17, § 3, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 27-26.1. - Delinquent account procedure. 
(a)  If utility services have been discontinued, any delinquent amount due to the city after the deposit has been applied for utility services at a place of consumption must be paid before any utility services are restored by the city. 
(b)  If any applicant is indebted to the city on any account at their then or previous place of consumption, the delinquent amount due at the previous place of consumption may be transferred to the applicant's active account and such service shall be discontinued by the city until payment in full, plus any service charge, is made. 
(Ord. No. 2013-17, § 4, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 27-27. - Solid waste rates and charges. 
    There shall be charged and collected from each person within the city who owns, manages, operates, leases or rents any premises where garbage, trash or rubbish is accumulated, the following monthly charges, whether or not any pickups of such garbage, trash or rubbish are made: 
(1)  For each residential unit, meaning one-family dwelling; and each unit of group housing; and each unit of apartment houses (except that multi-unit apartments using containers will be charged at the commercial rate) ..... $19.96 
(2)  Commercial: each establishment shall be charged a monthly fee for weekly pickup as noted on the current schedule determined by the solid waste division and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 328, § 14, 9-20-65; Ord. No. 369, § 1, 8-7-67; Ord. No. 398, § 1, 9-16-68; Ord. No. 414, § 1, 5-28-69; Ord. No. 488, § 1, 10-9-72; Ord. No. 514, § 1, 8-31-73; Ord. No. 526, § 2, 12-17-63; Ord. No. 544, § 1, 8-26-74; Ord. No. 596, § 1, 8-9-76; Ord. No. 631, § 1, 8-22-77; Ord. No. 675, § 1, 8-6-79; Ord. No. 749, § 1, 8-3-81; Ord. No. 785, § 2, 9-13-82; Ord. No. 87-30, § 1, 8-10-87; Ord. No. 89-10, § 1, 8-21-89; Ord. No. 90-11, § 1, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 91-02, § 1, 3-4-91; Ord. No. 93-10, § 1, 8-2-93; Ord. No. 99-06, § 1, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 00-15, §§ 1, 2, 9-28-00; Ord. No. 04-01, § 2, 1-12-04; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 9-20-04; Ord. No. 05-10, § 1, 9-19-05; Ord. No. 06-16, § 1, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2008-17, § 1, 9-29-08; Ord. No. 2012-09, § 1, 9-24-12; Ord. No. 2014-07, § 1, 9-22-14; Ord. No. 2015-12, § 1, 9-21-15; Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 9-19-16; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 1, 4-30-18) 
Sec. 27-28. - Sewer rates and charges. 
    The following rate is hereby established for sanitary sewer services to be furnished by the City of Groves, and said rates shall be charged and collected from all persons, firms and corporations for services rendered and shall be effective after the effective date of this section. The sewer rate charge shall be based on water consumption and the number of dwelling units located in a building and/or the number of commercial units located in a building as follows, to-wit: 
(1)  Within city limits: 
2,000 gallons of water consumption, per units ..... $11.25 
2,001 or more gallons of water consumption, per 1,000 gallons ..... 3.45 
(2)  Outside city limits: The rate shall be one and one-half (11/2) times the city rate. 
    Charges for sewer service furnished shall be rendered by the water and sewer departments of the City of Groves and shall be due and payable on the date of billing and shall become delinquent if not paid within ten (10) days from the date of billing. If after such charges are not paid, the city reserves the right to discontinue sewer service to the premises without further notice. Such charge shall be billed to the customer or user on the water bill of such customer or user each month. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 1, 9-20-65; Ord. No. 405, § 1, 12-9-68; Ord. No. 514, § 2, 8-31-73; Ord. No. 526, § 3, 12-17-73; Ord. No. 574, § 1, 8-25-75; Ord. No. 630, § 1, 8-22-77; Ord. No. 83-12, § 1, 8-1-83; Ord. No. 87-31, § 1, 8-10-87; Ord. No. 91-16, § 1, 8-5-91; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1, 8-31-92; Ord. No. 94-07, § 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 95-08, § 1, 8-28-95; Ord. No. 98-09, § 1, 8-31-98; Ord. No. 00-15, §§ 3, 4, 9-28-00; Ord. No. 02-10, § 1, 9-19-02; Ord. No. 06-18, § 1, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2008-19, § 1, 9-29-08; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 1, 9-27-10; Ord. No. 2011-14, § 1, 9-26-11; Ord. No. 2012-09, § 2, 9-24-12; Ord. No. 2013-17, § 5, 9-23-13; Ord. No. 2014-07, § 2, 9-22-14; Ord. No. 2015-12, § 2, 9-21-15; Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1, 9-7-18) 
Sec. 27-28.1. - Industrial sewer rate and surcharge. 
    An industrial sewer rate and surcharge shall be established to recover costs attributed to operation and maintenance of the sewer system. These charges shall be in addition to any industrial cost recovery system charges. The industrial sewer rate shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Industrial sewer rate (based upon water consumption) to be billed monthly to match existing city policy: 
a.  Within city limits: 
Minimum (2,000 gallons) ..... $ 11.25 
All over 2,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 3.45 
b.  Outside city limits: 
The rate shall be one and one half (11/2)times the city rate. 
(2)  Surcharge: 
a.  Discharge of abnormal sewage shall pay a surcharge computed on the following formula: 
SC = V[$0.20(BOD 5 -340) + $0.50(TSS 5 -340)] 
SC = Surcharge 
V = Volume in million gallons based on metered water 
BOD 5 = 5 days, 20°biochemical oxygen demand of industrial wastewater in ppm (or mg/1) 
TSS 5 = Total suspended solids of industrial waste in ppm (or mg/1) 
(Ord. No. 703, § 7, 3-31-80; Ord. No. 724, § 1, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 91-16, § 2, 8-5-91; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1, 8-31-92; Ord. No. 94-07, § 2, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 95-08, § 2, 8-28-95; Ord. No. 98-09, § 1, 8-31-98; Ord. No. 00-15, § 5, 9-28-00; Ord. No. 02-10, § 2, 9-19-02; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 9-27-10; Ord. No. 2011-14, § 2, 9-26-11; Ord. No. 2012-09, § 3, 9-24-12; Ord. No. 2013-17, § 6, 9-23-13; Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 9-22-14; Ord. No. 2015-12, § 3, 9-21-15; Ord. No. 2018-11, § 2, 9-7-18) 
Sec. 27-28.2. - Sewer maintenance fee. 
    There shall be charged and collected from each water customer within the city a monthly maintenance fee of one dollar and five cents ($1.05) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used; said fee to be used for debt service for sewer rehabilitation. 
(Ord. No. 04-11, § 1, 9-20-04; Ord. No. 05-11, § 1, 9-19-05; Ord. No. 06-17, § 1, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2008-18, § 1, 9-29-08; Ord. No. 2012-09, § 4, 9-24-12; Ord. No. 2014-07, § 4, 9-22-14) 
Sec. 27-29. - Water rates and charges. 
    The following monthly billing rates and charges for furnishing water and water service by the city are hereby fixed and established as follows, to-wit: 
(1)  Within city limits: 
2,000 gallons, or less, minimum charge ..... $ 11.00 
2,001 or more gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 3.45 
(2)  Outside city limits: 
The rate shall be one and one-half (11/2) times the city rate. 
    Where multiple services are provided, the minimum charge shall be made for each additional residence taking water through such meter. The regular minimum, the additional minimum and all water used over the minimum amounts by such consumers shall be charged to the customer having the meter. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 5, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 397, § 1, 9-16-68; Ord. No. 404, § 1, 12-9-68; Ord. No. 514, § 3, 8-31-73; Ord. No. 526, § 4, 12-17-73; Ord. No. 629, § 1, 8-22-77; Ord. No. 676, § 1, 8-6-79; Ord. No. 83-11, § 1, 8-1-83; Ord. No. 91-15, § 1, 8-5-91; Ord. No. 92-09, § 1, 8-31-92; Ord. No. 94-06, § 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 97-07, § 1, 8-25-97; Ord. No. 00-15, §§ 6, 7, 9-28-00; Ord. No. 02-10, § 3, 9-19-02; Ord. No. 06-19, § 1, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1, 9-29-08; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 3, 9-27-10; Ord. No. 2011-14, § 3, 9-26-11; Ord. No. 2012-09, § 5, 9-24-12; Ord. No. 2013-17, § 7, 9-23-13; Ord. No. 2014-07, § 5, 9-22-14; Ord. No. 2015-12, § 4, 9-21-15; Ord. No. 2018-11, § 3, 9-7-18) 
Sec. 27-30. - Payment of rates and charges. 
    The rates and charges fixed and prescribed by this chapter shall be due and payable in the office of the clerk of the water office on or before the tenth day after the date of billing. If said bill is not paid on or before the fifteenth day after the date of billing an additional charge of ten (10) per cent shall be added to the bill. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 5, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 439, § 1, 9-28-70) 
Sec. 27-31. - Disconnection of service for nonpayment. 
    In the event that any consumer of utility services furnished by the city does not pay the rates and charges on or before the day the same are due, the clerk of the water office shall have the authority to disconnect or terminate or cause to be disconnected or terminated all utility services furnished such consumer. 
(Ord. No. 353, § 5, 9-19-66) 
Sec. 27-32. - Resumption of service; reconnection fee. 
    Any consumer of the utility services furnished by the city whose utility services have been disconnected or terminated for the nonpayment of the rates and charges therefor may have such utility services resumed by paying all rates and charges due by the consumer to the city, including the making of a deposit in accordance with the current deposit required, and, in addition thereto, a reconnection fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00), if such reconnection is made during regular working hours. If such reconnection is made after regular working hours or on Saturday or Sunday, the reconnection fee shall be sixty-five dollars ($65.00). 
(Ord. No. 353, § 5, 9-19-66; Ord. No. 471, § 1, 2-28-72; Ord. No. 526, § 5, 12-17-73; Ord. No. 743, § 2, 7-6-81; Ord. No. 98-17, § 2, 11-2-98) 
Sec. 27-33. - Rates and charges for public utilities to be fixed by city. 
    The city council shall fix and approve the rates charged by any private public utility company doing business within the city. It shall be unlawful for any such public utility company or any officer or employee thereof to assess or charge for services rendered any rate other than the rate so fixed or approved. 
Sec. 27-34. - Service agreement required. 
    A service agreement, as required by the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) Permanent Volume of Rules, Chapter 290, "Water Hygiene", in the form promulgated by said rules, with provisions for proper enforcement to insure that neither cross-connections, nor other unacceptable plumbing practices are permitted, shall be signed by the proposed customer and filed with water billing and public works. 
(Ord. No. 95-17, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 27-35. - Service inspection certification required. 
    A service inspection certification, as required by the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) Permanent Volume of Rules, Chapter 290, "Water Hygiene", in the form promulgated by said rules, shall be completed, at customer's expense, prior to providing continuous water service to new construction, on any existing service when the water purveyor has reason to believe that cross-connections or other unacceptable plumbing practices exist, or after any material improvement, correction, or addition to the private plumbing facilities, and filed with public works. 
(Ord. No. 95-17, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 27-36. - Disconnection and resumption of service at request of customer. 
(a)  Temporary disconnection and resumption of utility services by the city to any customer of the city, whose account is current and not in arrears, shall be performed during regular working hours of the employees of the city, and the charge for such service shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(b)  In the case where a temporary disconnection or a reconnection is made for a customer on an emergency basis outside the regular working hours of the employees of the city, a fee of sixty-five dollars ($65.00) shall be charged to the customer for each instance that the employees of the city are called out to perform such service. 
(Ord. No. 98-17, § 3, 11-2-98) 
Sec. 27-37. - Water usage surcharge. 
    At any time the raw water rate charged to the city by the Lower Neches Valley Authority is increased pursuant to the drought contingency plan, said surcharge shall be passed through to each water customer of the city based upon the water usage of each customer. 
(Ord. No. 2011-20, § 1, 12-19-11) 
Secs. 27-38-27-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Sanitary sewer system, art. II, § 4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Toxic materials, ch. 241/2. 

Sec. 27-44. - Privies, cesspools, septic tanks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build, construct, dig, maintain or use any dry toilet, surface privy, cesspool or septic tank within the city; provided, however, when connection to the city's sanitary sewer system is impossible or impractical at any time, the construction, maintenance and use of a septic tank constructed in conformity to state law and approved by the building inspector may be permitted until such time as connection to the sewer system may be made. 
Sec. 27-45. - Sewer connections-Required. 
    All owners or occupants of buildings, or agents for the owners, situated within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a sanitary sewer are hereby required to construct or cause to be constructed suitable water closets on their property, and connect the same with the city sanitary sewer system under the direction and supervision of the city. 
(Ord. No. 88, §§ 1-3, 3-26-56) 
Sec. 27-46. - Same-Maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of any owner or occupant of any building connected with the city sanitary sewer system to keep and maintain the connection to the sewer system in perfect condition and free from any obstruction. 
Sec. 27-47. - Discharge prohibited; notice; penalty. 
(a)  Prohibited discharges. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, groundwater, surface water, roof runoff, foundation drainage, subsurface drainage, or any unpolluted industrial process water into the sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  Notice. The city shall serve persons in violation of this section with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing for satisfactory compliance within a period of sixty (60) days from the service of said notice. 
(c)  Continuing prohibited discharges. No person may continue to be in violation of this section beyond the time limit provided in the notice. 
(d)  Penalty. 
(1)  A person who continues prohibited violations is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction is punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each act of violation and for each day of violation. 
(2)  In addition to preceding under authority of subsection (d)(1) above, the city is entitled to pursue all other criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a person continuing prohibited violations. 
(e)  Surcharge. A person who continues "prohibited discharges" as provided in the foregoing subsection (c), beyond the time period provided in subsection (b), shall, in addition to being subject to the penalty provided in subsection (d), also be subject to a surcharge of twenty-four dollars ($24.00) per month to cover the cost of treating the prohibited discharge into the sanitary sewer system. Such charge will be added to the person's monthly water, sewer and garbage bill and will remain in effect until the person satisfactorily corrects the violation and contacts the city for an inspection of the repairs. Upon approval of the repairs by the proper authority of the city, the surcharge shall henceforth be removed from the person's water, sewer and garbage bill. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 10, 3-31-80; Ord. No. 93-2, § 1, 3-15-93) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 703, §§ 3, 8-12, enacted Mar. 31, 1980, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion as §§ 27-47-27-49 has been at the discretion of the editors. Sections 1, 2, 4, 6, 13 and 14 of such ordinance, providing for the adoption of a sewer use ordinance, including all previously enacted resolutions and ordinances since Jan. 2, 1953, providing that Ord. No. 702, be considered a part of the sewer use ordinance, providing that the Texas Department of Water Resources and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Water Quality Standards will be enacted if needed, providing that conflict between this ordinance and others be ruled by the sewer use ordinance, providing for severability and an effective date, have been omitted from codification. 
Sec. 27-48. - Failure to pay. 
    In addition to sanctions provided for by subsection 27-47(d), the city is entitled to exercise sanctions provided for by the other ordinances of the city for failure to pay the bill for water and sanitary sewer service when due. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 11, 3-31-80) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 27-47. 
Sec. 27-49. - Penalty for criminal mischief. 
    The city may pursue all criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes and ordinances against a person negligently, willfully, or maliciously causing loss by tampering with or destroying public wastewater facilities. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 12, 3-31-80) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 27-47. 
DIVISION 2. - DISCHARGE OF INDUSTRIAL WASTE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 702, §§ 2-32, being nonamendatory of the Code has been set out herein as Div. 2, §§ 27-51-27-56.22 at the discretion of the editors. 
Cross reference- Toxic materials, Ch. 241/2. 

Sec. 27-50. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Approving authority means the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
    Average quality means the arithmetic average (weighted by flow value) of all the daily determinations of concentrations made during a calendar month. Daily determinations of concentrations made using a composite sample. When grab samples are used, the daily determination of concentration shall be the arithmetic average (weighted flow value) of all the samples collected during the calendar day. 
    B.O.D. (Biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed in mg/l, utilized in the bio-chemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for five (5) days at a temperature of twenty (20) degrees centigrade. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal (also called house lateral and house connection). 
    Daily composite quality means the concentration of a sample consisting of a minimum of three (3) grab samples of effluent collected at regular intervals over a normal operating day and combined proportional to flow, or a sample continuously collected proportional to flow over a normal operating day. 
    City means the City of Groves, Texas, or any authorized person acting in its behalf. 
    C.O.D. (Chemical oxygen demand) means measure of the oxygen consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in the water or wastewater expressed in mg/l as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test, but not differentiating between stable and unstable organic matter and thus not necessarily correlating with biochemical oxygen demand. 
    Control manhole means a manhole giving access to a building sewer at some point before the building sewer discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Control point means a point of access to a course of discharge before the discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable wastes and residue from preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, processing, storage and sale of food products and produce. 
    Grab sample quality means the concentration of an individual sample of effluent collected in less than fifteen (15) minutes. 
    Hazardous metal includes each of the following metals in its elemental state and any of its compounds expressed as that metal: arsenic, barium, cadmium, chromium, copper, lead, manganese, mercury, nickel, selenium, silver, and zinc. 
    Industrial waste means waste resulting from any process of industry, manufacturing, trade, or business from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of the waste with water or normal wastewater, or distinct from normal wastewater. 
    Industrial waste charge means the charge made on those persons who discharge industrial wastes into the city's sewer system. 
    Inland waters shall include all surface waters in the state other than "tidal waters" defined below. 
    Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means the same as parts per million and is a weight-to-volume ratio; the milligram-per-liter value multiplied by the factor eight and thirty four one hundredths (8.34) shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Normal domestic wastewater means wastewater excluding industrial wastewater discharged by a person into sanitary sewers and in which the average concentration of total suspended solids is not more than three hundred forty (340) mg/l and BOD is not more than three hundred forty (340) mg/l. 
    Overload means the imposition of organic or hydraulic loading on a treatment facility in excess of its engineered design capacity. 
    Person includes corporation, organization, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership association, and any other legal entity. 
    pH means the logarithm (Base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. 
    Public sewer means pipe or conduit carrying wastewater or unpolluted drainage in which owners of abutting properties shall have the use, subject to control by the City of Groves, and Jefferson County Drainage District No. 7. 
    Sanitary sewer means a public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water, groundwater, and other unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, wastewater, or industrial waste which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Standard methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved, and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    Storm sewer means a public sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage and into which domestic wastewater or industrial wastes are not intentionally passed. 
    Stormwater means rainfall or any other forms of precipitation. 
    Superintendent means the water and/or wastewater superintendent of the City of Groves, or his duly authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
    Suspended solids means solids measured in mg/l that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, wastewater, or other liquids, and which are largely removable by a laboratory filtration device. 
    Tidal waters shall mean those waters of the Gulf of Mexico within the jurisdiction of the State of Texas, bays, estuaries thereto, and those portions of the river systems which are subject to the ebb and flow of the tides, and to the intrusion of marine waters. 
    To discharge includes to deposit, conduct, drain, emit, throw, run, allow to seep, or otherwise release or dispose of, or to allow, permit, or suffer any of these acts or omissions. 
    Trap means a device designed to skim, settle, or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand, flammable wastes or other harmful substances. 
    Unpolluted wastewater means water containing: 
(a)  No free or emulsified grease or oil; 
(b)  No acids or alkalis; 
(c)  No phenols or other substances producing taste or odor in receiving water; 
(d)  No toxic or poisonous substances in suspension, colloidal state, or solution; 
(e)  No noxious or otherwise obnoxious or odorous gases; 
(f)  Not more than an insignificant amount in mg/l each of suspended solids and BOD, as determined by the Texas Department of Water Resources; and 
(g)  Color not exceeding fifty (50) units as measured by the Platinum-Cobalt method of determination as specified in Standard Methods. 
    Waste means rejected, utilized or superfluous substances in liquid, gaseous, or solid form resulting from domestic, agricultural, or industrial activities. 
    Wastewater means a combination of the water-carried waste from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with any ground, surface, and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities includes all facilities for collection, pumping, treating, and disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes. 
    Wastewater treatment plant means any city-owned facilities, devices, and structures used for receiving, processing, and treating wastewater, industrial waste, and sludges from the sanitary sewers. 
    Wastewater service charge means the charge on all users of the public sewer system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values established as representative of normal wastewater. 
    Watercourse means a natural or man-made channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 702, § 2, 3-31-80) 
Sec. 27-51. - Prohibited discharges. 
(a)  No person may discharge to public sewers any waste which by itself or by interaction with other wastes may: 
(1)  Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes or facilities; 
(2)  Constitute a hazard to humans or animals; or 
(3)  Create a hazard in receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant effluent. 
(b)  All discharges shall conform to requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 702, § 3, 3-31-80) 
Sec. 27-52. - Chemical discharges. 
(a)  No discharge to public sewers may contain: 
(1)  Cyanide greater than 1.0 mg/l; 
(2)  Fluoride other than that contained in the public water supply; 
(3)  Chlorides in concentrations greater than 250 mg/l; 
(4)  Gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; or 
(5)  Substances causing an excessive chemical oxygen demand (C.O.D.) 
(b)  No waste or wastewater discharged to public waters may contain; 
(1)  Strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not; 
(2)  Fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (0 and 65° Centigrade). 
(3)  Objectionable or toxic substances, exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by the Approving Authority for such materials; or 
(4)  Obnoxious, toxic, or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in quantities sufficient to violate the provisions of Section 27-51(a). 
(c)  No waste, wastewater, or other substance may be discharged into public sewers which have a pH lower than five and five tenths (5.5) or higher than nine and five tenths (9.5), or any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and/or personnel at the wastewater facilities. 
(d)  All waste, wastewater, or other substance containing phenols, hydrogen sulfide, or other taste-and-odor producing substances, shall conform to concentration limits established by the approving authority. After treatment of the composite wastewater, concentration limits may not exceed the requirements established by state, federal, or other agencies with jurisdiction over discharges to receiving waters. 
(Ord. No. 702, § 4, 3-31-80) 
Sec. 27-53. - Heavy metals and toxic materials. 
(a)  No discharges may contain concentrations of heavy metals greater than amounts specified in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The allowable concentrations of heavy metals stated in terms of milligrams per liter (mg/l), determined on the basis of individual sampling in accordance with "Standard Methods" are:

(c)  No other heavy metals or toxic materials may be discharged into public sewers without a permit from the approving authority specifying conditions of pretreatment, concentrations, volumes and other applicable provisions.
