(A)  Location and length of boundary lines. 
(B)  Orientation of area being subdivided in relation to adjacent areas and principal streets. 
(C)  Proposed name of subdivision (which must not be so similar to that of an existing subdivision as to cause confusion). 
(D)  Location and width of existing and proposed streets within the subdivision and immediately adjacent to it. 
(E)  The alignment of proposed streets with existing city streets. 
(F)  The width, depth, and location of all lots. 
(G)  The location of building lines. 
(H)  Location, width, and purpose of all easements. 
(I)  Utilities on and adjacent to the tract. Sizes of existing sewer and water mains. 
(J)  Topography shown by contour lines on one foot vertical interval, U.S.C. & G. Datum. 
(K)  Adjacent subdivisions and tracts shown (dashed lines). 
(L)  North point, scale, and date. 
(M)  Clearly marked "Preliminary Plat." 
Section 4. - Final plat. 
    After the preliminary plat has been approved, a final or record plat with a duplicate original and ten (10) copies shall be prepared and submitted to the office of the public works department, accompanied by a filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The plat shall be drawn on mylar in India ink at a scale of one hundred (100) feet to the inch or larger, unless otherwise directed by the city plan commission; and shall show or be accompanied by the following information: 
(A)  The name of the subdivision and adjacent subdivisions, the names of streets, and the numbers of lots and blocks. 
(B)  An accurate boundary survey of the property by a duly licensed or registered civil engineer, or land surveyor, with closure information bearings and distances, referenced to section corners and showing the lines of adjacent lands and lines of adjacent streets, their names and widths. Also, the location of all permanent survey monuments. 
(C)  Location of lots, streets, public highways, alleys, parks, and other features, with accurate dimensions in feet and decimals of feet, with the length of radii and of arcs of all curves, and with all other information necessary to reproduce the plat on the ground. 
(D)  The location of building lines on front and side streets, and the location and purpose of all easements. 
(E)  The relation of streets and alleys of the subdivision to adjacent and projected streets and alleys. 
(F)  North point, scale, and date. 
(G)  Keymap, at small scale, showing area being subdivided in relation to adjacent areas and principal streets. 
(H)  An affidavit of ownership, and certificates from all taxing agencies having jurisdiction showing taxes paid on current basis. 
(I)  Statement by owner dedicating streets, right-of-way, and any sites for public use, together with two (2) copies of deed restrictions. 
(J)  The final plat shall be accompanied by two (2) complete sets of engineering drawings and specifications for streets, drainage and utilities, prepared by a registered engineer. 
(K)  The final plat shall be accompanied by letters of approval from the necessary state or other agencies, utility companies covering proposed utility installations and easements, and Drainage District No. 7 covering outfall drainage, if applicable. 
(L)  After approval by the plan commission, the final plat shall be submitted to the city council for approval. 
(M)  A certificate of approval to be signed by the chairman of the plan commission and the city council shall be placed on the face of the plat. 
(N)  Upon final approval by the city council of all improvements, street pavement, sanitary sewer, water lines, fire hydrants and drainage, within the subdivision, the final plat and dedication deed, with restrictions, shall be recorded in the county clerk's office in Jefferson County, by the city clerk. All cost incurred in the filing of the final plat and dedication deed, with restrictions, shall be paid by the developer of the subdivision. 
(O)  The City Manager or his/her authorized agent may approve and issue an amending plat (replat), which may be recorded and is controlling over the preceding plat without vacation of that plat, to relocate one or more lot lines between one (1) or more adjacent lots if: 
1.  The owners of all affected lots join in the application for amending the plat; 
2.  The amendment does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or restrictions; 
3.  The amendment does not increase the number of lots; 
4.  The replat does not require the creation of any new street or the extension of municipal facilities; 
5.  The city manager or his/her authorized agent shall not disapprove the replat and shall be required to refer any replat which he refuses to approve to the planning and zoning commission if the person or persons making the application requests in writing that the planning and zoning commission act on the replat. 
(Ord. No. 745, § 1, 7-20-81; Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 7-2-01; Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 6-18-12) 
Section 5. - General requirements and design standards. 
(A)  Street arrangement. 
(1)  Conformity to major street plan. Provision must be made for the extension of main thoroughfares as shown on the major street plan for the city. Secondary streets must provide for free circulation within the subdivision. 
(2)  Relation to adjoining streets and land. The street system for the subdivision, except in unusual cases, and at the recommendation of the plan commission, and with the approval by the city council must connect with streets already dedicated in adjacent subdivisions. Where no adjacent connections are platted, the streets must be, in general, reasonable projections of streets in the nearest subdivided tract; and must be continued to the boundaries of the tract being subdivided, so that future subdivisions may connect thereto. Maximum distance between streets which are to align with existing or future planned city streets shall be one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) feet. 
(3)  Widths. Widths of the major streets shall conform to the major street plan of the city. Minimum width of right-of-way for roads or streets shall be sixty (60) feet. 
(4)  Dead-end streets. Streets designed to leave one end permanently closed shall not exceed six hundred sixty (660) feet in length and shall be provided at the closed end with a turn-around. The street right-of-way for the turn-around shall have a minimum diameter of eighty (80) feet; the surfaced portion of the road at the turn-around shall have a minimum diameter of sixty (60) feet. Developers shall install four-inch diameter concrete posts, four (4) inch diameter pipe post, or four-inch creosote posts on twelve (12) feet, six (6) inch maximum centers with standard Armco, or approved equal, guard rail and three (3), three-inch bracket sealed reflectors at ends of all dead-end streets in the subdivision. 
(5)  Intersections. Street intersections shall preferably be at right angles and at never less than sixty (60) degrees. 
(6)  Street names. Street names shall be submitted by the office of the city manager in accordance with the city's street naming system. 
(7)  Street markers. Aluminum signs on galvanized posts (anchored) shall be installed as necessary for convenient identification of the streets and at each intersection. Signs must meet city standards. 
(8)  Street lights. Street lights shall be provided as, and the plans therefor shall be approved by the city council. The lights shall be mounted on ornamental poles of the type approved by the city and shall be installed at the expense of the developer. 
(B)  Lots and blocks. 
(1)  Block length. No block shall exceed one thousand (1,000) feet in length. All block corners shall be established on the ground by concrete monuments. 
(2)  Lot sizes. Lot sizes shall conform to those set forth in the city zoning ordinance. Lot corners shall be marked on the ground by one-half-inch by twenty-four-inch long iron pipe driven flush with ground. 
(3)  Lot shape. In general, side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines. 
(4)  Building lines. Building lines shall conform to city zoning requirements. 
(5)  Utility easements. A minimum easement of ten (10) feet for utilities is required; except easements shall be twenty (20) feet, minimum, if more than one utility is to be located therein. 
(6)  Drainage easements. When drainage easements are necessary, they shall be designated for drainage and utility purposes. 
(C)  Water supply and wastewater disposal. 
(1)  Water and wastewater facilities. Each developer shall agree, as a condition of approval of a plat, that the Subdivider will install at his own cost, water and sewer lines to connect with the City's water and wastewater system. Water and wastewater system improvements shall be in accordance with Texas State Department of Health Requirements. 
(2)  Water and sewers. The city council may refuse to approve a plat unless it is apparent that proper water and sewage facilities will be completed within a reasonable time. 
(D)  Improvements. 
(1)  Conditions to final approval. As a condition to final approval of the plat and of the subdivision, the city council shall require completion of street construction and utilities. In lieu of completion of such work, the city council may accept bond in the amount and with the security satisfactory to the city manager, providing and securing to the city the actual construction and installation of such improvements and utilities, including sanitary sewers, water lines, fire hydrants, drainage, within a period of time to be specified by the city council. 
(2)  Inspection. Inspection of improvements shall be by the director of public works or his representatives. 
    After completion of improvements, the subdivider's engineer shall certify that improvements have been made in accordance with his plans and specifications, and/or modifications thereto, and request inspection and approval of facilities by the director of public works, or his representatives. Upon inspection and approval of facilities by the director of public works, and the receipt of certificate from subdivider's engineer, the subdivision shall be presented to the council for final acceptance. 
(E)  Variances. 
(1)  [ Authorization by city council. ] When a subdivider shows that a provision of the regulations would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to; and where in the opinion of the plan commission, a departure may be made without destroying the spirit of the regulations, the city plan commission may recommend to the city council, and the city council, at its sole discretion, authorize a variance. 
(Ord. No. 745, §§ 2, 3, 7-20-81) 
Section 6. - Minimum street requirements. 
(A)  Streets with curb and gutter sections. 
(1)  Curb and gutter sections shall be used with concrete pavement, only, and shall require the installation of storm sewers. 
(2)  Minimum width back-to-back of curb shall be thirty-one (31) feet. Greater width shall be required on major thoroughfares to conform with the city's master street plan. 
(3)  Height of standard curb above gutter shall be in accordance with city standard. 
(4)  Minimum gradient on gutters shall be 0.20%. Minimum fall around curb return shall be 0.10 feet. 
(5)  Storm sewer inlets shall be installed in such a manner that storm water is not carried more than four hundred (400) feet from the high point of the gutter to a storm sewer opening. 
(6)  Storm sewer inlets shall have throat opening of not less than 1.5 square feet and shall be sized for contributing area. 
(7)  Minimum run-off used in calculating drainage structures shall be in accordance with city standards. 
(8)  Drainage across streets by means of "valley" gutters shall be prohibited. 
(9)  Storm sewer and inlet leads having less than 1.0 feet cover at street crossings shall be reinforced concrete pipe. 
(10)  General specifications for construction within the City of Groves are on file at the city hall. 
(B)  Minimum requirements for concrete pavement. 
(1)  All subgrade is to be accurately shaped prior to placing base or pavement thereon, and shall be compacted to provide for uniform density capable of supporting the pavement loads imposed thereon. Unstable subgrade is to be carefully stabilized by the addition of suitable material or by removing unstable area and placing therein a suitable subgrade material. 
(2)  The pavement shall be six (6) inch, uniform thickness; and curbs to be constructed monolithic with the pavement, or with three-eighths ( 3/8 ) inch dowels at twelve (12) inch centers. 
(3)  Concrete to have a minimum of five and one-half (51/2) sacks of cement per cubic yard of concrete. 
(4)  Concrete to have a flexural strength of six hundred (600) pounds per square inch at twenty-eight (28) days, or core test with compressive strength of three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch. 
(5)  All slabs are to be provided with acceptable load transmission device at expansion joints, with expansion joints at approximately sixty (60) foot intervals. Expansion joints to be placed at all structures and at curb returns at street intersections. 
(6)  Contraction joints to have a maximum spacing of twenty (20) feet. 
(7)  When completed the concrete shall be kept moist for a period of not less than three (3) days and longer, if necessary; or by spraying with approved commercial-type moisture sealer; and shall be protected from the elements in a satisfactory method. 
(8)  Backfill shall be of suitable selected material and shall be placed and tamped until firm and solid. Layer of backfill between tamping operations shall not exceed six (6) inches. Backfilling shall follow immediately after the concrete forms have been removed. 
(9)  Concrete pavement shall be reinforced with either welded wire mesh or deformed steel rod reinforcing material. When wire mesh is used, said wire mesh shall be no smaller than six (6) gauge (0.192" diameter) in cross section, nor have a center line to center line dimension in excess of six (6) inches. Reinforcing wire mesh shall be placed in the forms prior to placing of the concrete. Sheets of wire mesh shall overlap each other on ends and edge a minimum of six (6) inches and shall be securely fastened at the ends and edges with wire ties on a maximum of two (2) foot centers. As the concrete is placed, the wire mesh shall be pulled up into the concrete so that the mesh is at an average elevation of one and one-half (11/2) inches above the bottom of the slab cross section. Deformed steel rods, when used, shall be a minimum of three-eighths ( 3/8 ) inch diameter. Rods shall be installed on twenty-four (24) inch centers each way. 
(C)  Testing. Necessary testing of subgrade and concrete pavement, to prove that these items meet requirements shall be done by the Southwestern Testing Laboratories or other commercial testing laboratory acceptable to the city council, cost of such testing shall be borne by the subdivider. 
(D)  Inspection. Inspection of construction shall be at the direction of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 745, § 4, 7-20-81) 
Section 7. - Water distribution-Minimum requirements. 
(A)  Layout and sizing of mains shall conform with the city's long-range plan. 
(B)  System to provide for fire flow with minimum of six (6) inch mains to serve fire hydrants. 
(C)  Fire hydrants to be located as required by the State Fire Insurance Board and shall be equipped with a valved "lead." 
(D)  Fire hydrants to be located on corners of blocks, if possible. 
(E)  Minimum system pressure to be forty (40) psig under peak domestic consumption of one hundred fifty (150) G.P.C.P.D. 
(F)  Minimum house connections to be three fourths (3/4) inch pipe. 
(G)  A satisfactory flushing connection shall be provided at the end of all dead-end lines. 
(H)  All sanitary features, construction and location to conform to suggested state health department requirements. 
(I)  All materials to be used in the water distribution system shall be new materials and shall meet the requirements of the American Waterworks Association. 
(J)  Fire hydrants shall rest on a concrete block or base not less than four (4) inches thick and fifteen (15) inches square, and the back side opposite the pipe connection shall be backed with concrete between the hydrant and the vertical wall of the trench to prevent the hydrant from blowing off the line. The size of this concrete shall be not less than fifteen (15) inches wide by fifteen (15) inches high, the thickness to be determined by the space between the hydrant and the vertical wall of the trench, but in no instances less than six (6) inches thick. The "weep holes" shall be kept clear of this concrete block. Hydrants shall be set truly vertical. 
(K)  Water mains shall be tested hydrostatically and evaluation of leakage made from time and pressures as follows: 
(1)  One hundred (100) p.s.i. test for twenty-four (24) hours, or 
(2)  One hundred twenty-five (125) p.s.i. test for sixteen (16) hours, or 
(3)  One hundred fifty (150) p.s.i. test for eight (8) hours, the high (one hundred fifty (150) p.s.i.) test being preferred. 
    Bacteriological test shall be performed with city assistance in accordance with Texas State Department of Health requirements. Tests shall be performed without cost to the city. 
Section 8. - Sanitary sewage system-Minimum requirements. 
(A)  Sanitary sewer lines shall have a minimum diameter of eight (8) inches and a slope of .25%, and shall be vitrified clay (pre-molded joint) or equal, approved by the public works department. 
(B)  Sanitary sewer pipe shall be covered not less than 3.0 feet. 
(C)  Manholes on laterals are to be located at points of change in grade, size, or directions, and at junctions with other lines, and at "dead-ends" of lines. 
(D)  Manhole spacing on sewer to be a maximum of four hundred (400) feet, with manholes at points of change in grade, size, or directions, and at junctions with other lines. 
(E)  General specifications for construction within the City of Groves are on file at the department of public works and shall be complied with. 
(F)  Sanitary sewer lines shall be tested for infiltration as directed by the director of public works. Air test, hydrostatic test, etc., shall be performed in accordance with current test standards without cost to the city. The city reserves the right to evaluate quality standards from data developed from information by televiewing lines. If the city chooses to use this method, the city will pay for television survey. 
Sec. 9. - Planned development projects. 
(A)  Any person wishing to develop a townhouse project or a zero lot line project shall comply with the requirements as set forth in this section in preparing the plat, plans and specifications for the project. 
(B)  Access: 
(1)  All projects shall have direct access from at least one improved, dedicated street accepted by the city. 
(2)  All lots shall immediately abut and have direct access to an access street, an interior street or an alley. 
(3)  Interior streets shall meet one of the following: 
(a)  Minimum right-of-way width of sixty (60) feet and a minimum twenty-seven-foot wide concrete pavement with no parking on street. 
(b)  Minimum right-of-way width of sixty (60) feet and a minimum thirty-five-foot wide concrete pavement with parking permitted. 
(4)  Alleys shall have a right-of-way width of at least twenty-five (25) feet and shall be developed with a twenty-five-foot wide concrete pavement. However, where an alley provides access to head-in automobile parking spaces along both sides, the alley must have a right-of-way width of not less than thirty (30) feet. 
(C)  Density: 
(1)  No townhouse project shall have a greater density than fifteen (15) lots per gross acre. 
(2)  No zero lot line project shall have a greater density than ten (10) lots per gross acre. 
(D)  Lot area: One thousand eight hundred (1,800) square feet for townhouses and three thousand two hundred (3,200) square feet for zero lot line dwellings. 
(E)  Lot width: Twenty (20) feet for townhouses and forty (40) feet for zero lot line houses, except that lots siding on a corner or upon a plat boundary of the project shall not be less than thirty (30) feet for townhouses and fifty (50) feet for zero lot line dwellings. 
(F)  Building setback lines: 
(1)  Front: 
(a)  A front building setback line of twenty (20) feet on lots fronting on an access street. 
(b)  A front building setback line of ten (10) feet on all other lots. 
(2)  Rear: 
(a)  A rear building setback line of twenty (20) feet on all lots backing on an access street and said lots shall be denied direct driveway access to the access street, and on all lots backing on lots in a recorded plat used or intended to be used for single family detached dwelling units. 
(b)  All lots without a rear drive access shall have a minimum rear setback of ten (10) feet. 
(3)  Sides: 
(a)  A side building setback of ten (10) feet on all lots siding on a corner or siding upon a plat boundary of the project. 
(b)  No side building setback line shall be required on all other townhouse lots and on all zero lot lines there shall be no minimum on one side and ten (10) feet on the opposite side. 
(G)  Open space: 
(1)  A minimum of four hundred (400) square feet of open space shall be provided for each lot. 
(2)  Where townhouse lots and dwelling units are designed to face or front each other upon an open or common access court rather than upon a street. This open court shall be a minimum forty (40) feet wide and said court shall not include vehicular drives or parking areas. 
(3)  When computing the required open space, the required front or side setbacks, streets, alleys or other public right-of-ways of any kind, vehicular drives, parking areas, drainage easements and utility easements shall not be included. 
(4)  Common open space is not required but may be permitted. If common open space is provided, it shall be permanently maintained by the homeowners association. 
(H)  Sidewalks. A sidewalk of concrete or other permanent material having a width of at least four (4) feet shall be constructed along the front of each lot. If the required sidewalk is constructed within public street right-of-way, it shall not have a width more than four (4) feet and shall be constructed to city standards. 
(I)  Easements: 
(1)  Aerial easements, if any, may not be located along the frontage of any lot. 
(2)  Utility easements and drainage easements shall be as required in subsections 5(B)(5) and 5(B)(6) of this ordinance. 
(3)  Private easements: 
(a)  Townhouse projects without a homeowner association must provide for a perpetual maintenance easement of four (4) feet in width along each side of adjacent lot lines and parallel thereto. 
(b)  Zero lot line dwellings shall be constructed against the lot line on one side of a lot, and no windows, doors, or other openings shall be permitted and on the adjacent lot the developer must provide for a perpetual wall maintenance easement of four (4) feet in width along such wall. 
(c)  When required by the city council, a two-foot wide private easement shall be provided for the placement of a six-foot high screening fence. The location and type of screening fence shall be determined by the city council. The screening fence shall be permanently maintained by the homeowners association. 
(J)  Dwelling height. No dwelling structure shall exceed thirty-five (35) feet in height or two (2) stories. 
(K)  Parking: 
(1)  At least two (2) off-street parking spaces (covered or uncovered) shall be provided for on each lot. 
(2)  In addition to the above requirement, one (1) additional parking space shall be provided for each lot within the project. Said additional space may be parallel parking on public street or tandem parking on individual driveways connecting such lots with the adjacent street. Parking on or over sidewalks shall not be credited toward the parking requirements. 
(L)  Dwelling floor area: 
(1)  Each dwelling unit shall have a minimum living area of nine hundred (900) square feet. 
(2)  The developer shall submit typical floor plans which shall show the general layout of the units, open courtyard and garages. 
(M)  The following data shall be shown on the preliminary plats: 
(1)  Density: Lots per gross acre; 
(2)  The number and size of each type unit; 
(3)  Number and type of parking spaces. 
(N)  Homeowners association. If applicable, a copy of the articles of incorporation of a nonprofit homeowners association assuring that all common open space and screening fences, and/or walls shown on the final plat shall be permanently held in common ownership by each original or successive lot owner through mandatory membership in said association. The association is to have continuing responsibility for the maintenance of all common open space and screening wall and said responsibility is to be assured by the annual assessment of each lot owner to establish a maintenance fund sufficient for such maintenance. Said copy of the articles of incorporation of a nonprofit homeowners association shall be submitted along with the final plat and other documents required by this ordinance for approval. 
(O)  All other requirements pertaining to concrete paving, drainage systems, water lines, sanitary sewer lines and street lighting shall conform to the requirements as set forth in this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 84-13, § 1, 7-30-84) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 84-13, §§ 1, 2, adopted July 30, 1984, deleted former App. B, §§ 9, 10, pertaining to townhouse and townhome requirements and mobile home parks type "B," and enacted new §§ 9, 10, pertaining to mobile home subdivisions and planned development projects. 
Sec. 10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-05, § 2, adopted June 18, 2012, deleted § 10, entitled "Mobile home subdivisions", which derived from: Ord. No. 84-13, § 2, adopted July 30, 1984. 
Section 11. - Maintenance bond. 
    To insure that all improvements, streets, drainage, water, sewer, are constructed in accordance with specifications and to guarantee that they will be properly maintained by the subdivider for a period of one (1) year from the date of final completion of all of the subdivision improvements and subsequent formal acceptance by the city, the subdivider shall provide a bond, in an amount and with the security acceptable to the city manager, payable to the City of Groves. 
Section 12. - Maintenance and services. 
    In any subdivision for which a final plat has not been approved and filed for record in the Jefferson County Deed Records, nor in which subdivision, the standards herein stipulated have not been complied with in full, the city, shall issue no building, repair, plumbing, or electrical permit; and the city shall not repair or maintain any street; and the city shall not sell or supply water or sanitary sewer service therein. 
Section 13. - Subdivision development procedures. 
(1)  The subdivider shall pay all costs providing the subdivision with streets, water, sanitary sewer, and drainage in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the plan committee and the city council. 
(2)  The subdivider shall pay to the city an inspection fee of five (5) per cent of the total cost of the development to ensure compliance with the plans and specifications. 
(3)  Method of payment and determination of contractor. 
(a)  The developer may, before any work is started in the subdivision in regard to laying of water or sewer lines, request the city council to solicit bids for the account of the developers. These bids shall be solicited in accordance with the requirements and specifications presently in force in regard to work done by the city, and shall include a one hundred (100) per cent material payment bond and a one hundred (100) per cent performance bond by contractor. 
(b)  The bids, if received by the city, shall be awarded during an official meeting of the city council. The developer shall award the contract to the bidder accepted by the city council as the lowest, responsible bidder, quality considered. 
(c)  If the city solicits bids, the developer shall, within ten (10) days, deposit with the city secretary a certified check, cashier's check, or bank officer's check made payable to the City of Groves in an amount equal to the awarded contract bid, plus five (5) per cent inspection fee. 
(d)  Upon completion of the work and acceptance of said work by the developer and the city, the city shall pay to the contractor the sum so deposited by the developer. 
(4)  It is further agreed that the City of Groves has the option to do any or all of the contract work itself, and the actual cost of said work will be paid by the developer. 
(5)  It is further agreed by and between the parties thereto that the developers will only be responsible for laying such lines as are necessary to adequately serve the subdivision under development. In the event the city desires any excess lines, then the city will be responsible for any excess cost over and above what would be adequate lines for the subdivision; for example, if an eight-inch intro-subdivision sewage trunk line would be adequate to serve within a proposed subdivision but the city wanted twelve-inch intra-subdivision lines laid in the subdivision so that the city could connect to municipal trunk lines and thereby render services to other property in the vicinity of the subdivision, then, and if in that event, the city required the developer to lay a twelve-inch intra-subdivision line, then the city would be responsible for the difference between the cost of purchasing the eight-inch line and the cost of purchasing and laying the twelve-inch line. 
(6)  It is further agreed by and between the parties that the city assumes the obligation to maintain and operate such utility system; and shall have complete control, management, and operation of said lines during the term of this section; and shall have the right to tap in or cut said lines in any manner that shall be expedient to the city. 
(Ord. No. 84-13, § 3, 7-30-84; Ord. No. 2012-05, § 3, 6-18-12) 
Section 13.1. - Development of small tracts of land, Class A subdivisions, specifications, requirements, reimbursement procedures. 
(A)  All improvements shall be constructed in accordance with specifications outlined in the subdivision ordinance of the city. 
(B)  The city will provide [or will do] the following: 
(1)  Feasibility study. 
(2)  Preparation of preliminary plat, if requested. 
(3)  Receive bids and award contracts, if requested. 
(4)  Inspect and supervise construction. 
(C)  Property owners will provide the following: 
(1)  An application signed by all property owners in the project accompanied by a five hundred dollar ($500.00) deposit for initiation of preliminary studies and estimates. 
(2)  A certified survey of the boundaries of the project. 
(3)  Each property owner shall provide all right-of-way and easements for project. 
(4)  Each property owner shall provide proof of ownership to accompany any dedications of right-of-way. 
(5)  The owner shall provide all improvements at no cost to the city. Improvements are defined as streets, roadways, drainage, storm sewer, water, sanitary sewer, electrical, telephone, T.V. cable service and street lighting. 
(E)  No rebates or "pay back" to property owners will be made for improvements. 
(F)  The procedures for development of a project under this ordinance are as follows: 
(1)  Upon receipt of an application and deposit the city will initiate a preliminary study to determine project feasibility. 
(a)  The initiation fee will be credited to project development cost if the project is started within ten (10) months. 
(b)  If preliminary studies indicate that development is not feasible, the five hundred dollar ($500.00) deposit will be returned or refunded. 
(c)  Determination of feasibility will be made by the city staff. 
(2)  The developer may, before any work is started in the subdivision in regard to infrastructure, request the city council to solicit bids for the account of the developers. These bids shall be solicited in accordance with the requirements and specifications presently in force in regard to work done by the city, and shall include a one hundred (100) per cent material payment bond and a one hundred (100) per cent performance bond by contractor. 
(3)  The bids, if received by the city, shall be awarded during an official meeting of the city council, The developer shall award the contract to the bidder accepted by the city council as the lowest, responsible bidder, quality considered. 
(4)  If the city solicits bids, the developer shall, within ten (10) days, deposit with the city secretary a certified check, cashier's check, or bank officer's check made payable to the City of Groves in an amount equal to the awarded contract bid, plus five (5) per cent inspection fee. 
(5)  Upon completion of the work and acceptance of said work by the developer and the city, the city shall pay to the contractor the sum so deposited by the developer. 
(6)  It is further agreed that the City of Groves has the option to do any or all of the contract work, and the actual cost of said work will be paid by the developer. 
(7)  It is further agreed by and between the parties that the city assumes the obligation to maintain and operate such utility system; and shall have complete control, management, and operation of said lines during the term of this section; and shall have the right to tap in or cut said lines in any manner that shall be expedient to the city. 
(8)  Upon completion of preliminary studies which have found the project feasible, property owners or developer will place fifty (50) percent of estimated construction costs in escrow and final development plans will be prepared. 
(9)  All required right-of-way and easements shall be dedicated to public use at this time. 
(10)  Total project funding will be provided to the city by the property owners prior to the city contracting for improvements. Funding will include project contingency. 
(11)  Performance bonds will be required at the discretion of the city. 
(12)  All improvements shall meet current city standards. 
(13)  Variance may be considered by the city council on the recommendation of the city staff. 
(G)  Reimbursement procedures in Class A subdivisions. 
(1)  If the subdivision submitted by the developer and approved by the council is in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance, the city council may, at its sole discretion, enter into a contract with the developer to reimburse the developer for all expenditures made in laying water and sewer lines and concrete streets and storm sewers within that Class A subdivision; subject to, and in accordance with, the applicable provisions of the foregoing Section 13.0. Subdivision Development Procedures. and the following additional provisions: 
(1)  Upon the completion of all of the water, sanitary sewer lines, concrete streets and storm sewers, within the said subdivision, it is agreed that the City of Groves shall purchase all of said water and sanitary sewer and concrete streets and storm sewers lines located within the said subdivision; and the City of Groves shall pay for said water, sanitary sewer lines and concrete streets and storm sewers as follows: 
(a)  Said payment shall be made from water and sewer charge revenues received by city from sales and service within the boundaries of the subdivision and payments shall be made annually on, or before, November 1 st of each calendar year for the previous calendar year on the basis of fifty (50) per cent of the revenues received. The said fifty (50) per cent of the income so received shall be applied to the payment of the cost of the lines and streets until same are paid in full, including engineering fees equal to six (6) per cent of the construction contract cost; but in no event shall payments continue for a period longer than twenty (20) years from the date of the dedication of the subdivision even though within said time the fifty (50) per cent of the revenues received from services and charges within said subdivision is not sufficient to repay the cost in full. 
(b)  Upon payment of the above-mentioned sums of money or upon termination of the contract period, whichever is prior in time, it is hereby agreed that the developers, their heirs or assigns shall execute any and all quit claim deeds necessary to convey said lines and streets to the city. 
(2)  It shall be further agreed by and between the parties thereto that the developers will only be responsible for laying such lines and streets as are necessary to adequately serve the subdivision under development. In the event the city desires any excess lines, then the city will be responsible for any excess cost over and above what would be adequate lines and streets for the subdivision; for example, if an eight-inch line intro-subdivision sewage trunk line would be adequate to serve within a proposed subdivision but the city wanted twelve-inch intra-subdivision lines laid in the subdivision so that the city could connect to municipal trunk lines and thereby render services to other property in the vicinity of the subdivision, then, and if in that event, the city required the developer to lay a twelve-inch intra-subdivision line, then the city would be responsible for the difference between the cost of purchasing the eight-inch line and the cost of purchasing and laying the twelve-inch line. 
(3)  It shall be further agreed between the parties thereto that the city shall assume the obligation to maintain and operate such utility system; and shall have complete control, management, and operation of said lines during the term of this contract; and shall have the right to tap in or cut said lines in any manner that shall be expedient to the city. 
(4)  It shall be further agreed between the parties thereto that the sole consideration for the developer executing this contract shall be the remuneration the developer will receive from the city for the cost of all water lines, sewer lines, streets and storm sewers, constructed within said subdivision; and developer would not develop the above-described property without this written guarantee on the part of the city to reimburse said developer for the costs expended by the developer. 
(Ord. No. 2013-06, § 2, 3-25-13; Ord. No. 2013-07, § 2, 4-22-13) 
Section 13.2. - Development of small tracts of land, Class B subdivisions; specifications; requirements. 
(A)  To be considered under the guidelines of this section, the property must be shown on the accompanying map, which is referred to, incorporated herein and made a part hereof for all purposes. 
(1)  Amber Estates (Class B Subdivision). A tract of land containing 4.439 acres of land out of Lot 2, Block 5, Range "C", of Port Arthur Land Company Subdivision, in Jefferson County, Texas, as the same appears upon the map or plat thereof, on file and of record in Volume 1, Page 22, Map Records of Jefferson County, Texas. 
(B)  All improvements shall be constructed in accordance with specifications outlined in the subdivision ordinance of the city, except for the following: 
(1)  Street right-of-way width to be determined by the city council, upon recommendation by the city manager or his/her authorized agent. 
(2)  Construction of roadways shall be determined by the city manager or his/her authorized agent. Design requirements shall be determined and approved based on the functional classification of the roadway. Some components used in the development of pavement design may include but are not limited to: anticipated traffic loads, type of thoroughfare and adjacent or intersecting roadways. 
(3)  Roadside drainage to be open ditches. 
(C)  The property owner/owners will provide the following: 
(1)  An application signed by all property owners in the project, and accompanied by a five hundred dollar ($500.00) deposit, for initiation of preliminary studies and estimates. 
(2)  A certified survey of the boundaries of the project and proof of ownership. 
(3)  Each property owner/owners shall provide all rights-of-way and easements. 
(4)  Each owner/owners shall provide all improvements at no cost to the city. Improvements are defined as roadway construction, open drainage ditches, six-inch water main, eight-inch sanitary sewer main, electrical, gas, telephone, TV cable service and street lighting. Each owner/owners shall also pay for the services of an engineering firm, survey company and a testing laboratory, selected by developer or the director of public works, to perform civil drawings, drainage calculations, drainage requirements, storm water permitting, preparation of the final plat and to test the subbase, base and final street surface. 
(5)  Method of payment and determination of contractor. 
(a)  The developer may, before any work is started in the subdivision in regard to laying of water or sewer lines, request the city council to solicit bids for the account of the developers. These bids shall be solicited in accordance with the requirements and specifications presently in force in regard to work done by the city, and shall include a one hundred (100) per cent material payment bond and a one hundred (100) per cent performance bond by contractor. 
(b)  The bids, if solicited by the city, shall be awarded during an official meeting of the city council. The developer shall award the contract to the bidder accepted by the city council as the lowest, responsible bidder, quality considered. 
(c)  The developer shall within ten (10) days, deposit with the city secretary a certified check, cashier's check, or bank officer's check made payable to the City of Groves in an amount equal to the awarded contract bid, plus five (5) per cent inspection fee. 
(d)  Upon completion of the work and acceptance of said work by the developer and the city, the city shall pay to the contractor the sum so deposited by the developer. 
(e)  No rebates or "payback" to property owners will be made for improvements. 
(f)  The city will provide [or do] the following; 
1.  Feasibility study. 
2.  A preliminary plat. 
3.  Receive bids if requested. 
4.  Award bids if requested. 
5.  Inspect and supervise construction. 
6.  Will apply the five hundred dollars ($500.00) toward the total inspection fee, if the project is started within ten (10) months of deposit. 
(6)  Variances and amendments to the map may be considered by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 780, § 2, 8-16-82; Ord. No. 784, § 1, 9-13-82; Ord. No. 95-15, § 1, 11-20-95; Ord. No. 05-05, § 1, 6-27-05; Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1, 8-16-10; Ord. No. 2012-05, § 5, 6-18-12; Ord. No. 2013-02, § 1, 1-14-13; Ord. No. 2013-06, § 1, 3-25-13; Ord. No. 2016-08, § 1, 8-22-16) 
Note- Formerly codified as § 13.1 which was renumbered by Ord. 2013-06 as § 13.2. 
Section 14. - Enforcement for violations. 
    In behalf of the City of Groves, the city attorney shall, when directed by the city council, institute appropriate action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this ordinance. 
Section 15. - Conflict with other ordinances. 
    Whenever the standards and specifications in this ordinance conflict with those contained in another ordinance, the most stringent or restrictive provision shall govern. 
Section 16. - Separability clause. 
    Should any portion or part of this ordinance be held for any reason invalid or unenforceable, the same shall not be construed to affect any other valid portion hereof, but all valid portions hereof shall remain in full force and effect. 
Section 17. - Penal provisions. 
    Any person violating any provision of this ordinance within the corporate limits of the City of Groves, Texas, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction, shall be fined an amount not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day that such violation exists shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such hereunder. 
Section 18. - Publication. 
    This ordinance shall be published by publishing the caption thereof, within ten (10) days after the passage thereof, for three (3) successive days in The News, the official newspaper of the City of Groves. 
Section 19. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall be effective from and after its passage and publication of the caption only as required by the City Charter. 
PASSED, APPROVED and ADOPTED by the City Council of The City of Groves at a regular meeting held on the 16th day of July, A.D., 1973.

APPENDIX C - STANDARDS FOR DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF WATER AND SEWER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS, DRAINAGE, STREET, SIDEWALK, DRIVEWAY AND TRAFFIC SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS[1] 
ORDINANCE NO. 510 
    AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING CITY STANDARDS FOR DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF WATER AND SEWER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS, DRAINAGE, STREET, SIDEWALK, DRIVEWAY AND TRAFFIC SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS FOR THE CITY OF GROVES; PROVIDING A PENALTY; PROVIDING FOR PUBLICATION BY PUBLISHING THE CAPTION ONLY; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY OF GROVES: 
    SECTION 1: That there is hereby adopted and established standards for design and construction of water and sewer system improvements, drainage, street, sidewalk, driveway and traffic system improvements for The City of Groves; such standards for design and construction are fully set forth in Exhibit "A", attached hereto and made a part thereof, the same as if stated herein verbatim. 
    SECTION 2: Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in any sum not to exceed $200.00. 
    SECTION 3: This ordinance shall be published for three (3) successive days in The News, the official newspaper of The City of Groves, within ten (10) days after the passage hereof. 
    SECTION 4: This ordinance shall be effective from and after its passage and publication of the caption only as required by the City Charter. 
    PASSED, APPROVED and ADOPTED by the City Council of The City of Groves at a regular meeting held on the 16 day of July, 1973.

      City Attorney   EXHIBIT "A" 
STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR ALL WATER AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS, PUBLIC BUILDING IMPROVEMENTS AND OTHER GENERAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS 
1.  Texas Highway Department. 
    The City of Groves, Texas, hereby adopts the 1962 Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction as adopted by the State Highway Department of Texas, January 2, 1962, to be used to prepare specifications for specific projects to be accomplished in the City of Groves. All reference to the "Texas Highway Department" shall be deleted when preparing city standard specifications. 
2.  American Public Works Association. 
    The City of Groves, Texas, hereby adopts the "Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction", 1967 Edition. These standard specifications are to be used to prepare specifications of specific projects to be accomplished in the City of Groves, and will require updating and modification on a continuing basis to reflect conditions and requirements within this city. 
3.  American Water Works Association. 
    The AWWA prepared and published standard specifications for water and sewerage system operations, maintenance, construction and improvements and the City of Groves hereby recognizes the AWWA as an authority in this field, and approves the use of this organizations' standard specifications within the City of Groves on related projects and work. 
4.  Statement of policy. 
(a)  It is the intention of the city council of the City of Groves that the standard specifications of the above three recognized authorities be made available for use by the City of Groves on all types of work, projects, operation, and maintenance in water and sewer system improvements, public works, public buildings and other general construction projects. 
The respective department heads, i.e., director of public works, are charged with the responsibility to modify, adapt and keep on a current basis, these standard specifications for use by the city. Current editions of all specifications used by the city standard specifications will be kept on hand and clearly marked approved by the department head. These standard specifications (as changed by the city), shall be presented with and made a part of the formal plans and specifications for a project when it is presented for public approval by the city council. 
(b)  It is also adopted as a city policy that the departments of water and sewer, public works, and planning, are hereby charged with the maintenance of these standard specifications, and standard engineering drawings included herein as the "city standards" and are hereafter charged with the maintenance and updating of these "city standards" and the development of new standards in the future. 
STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR WATER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS 
    The specifications shown below are considered to be the minimum standards required by the City of Groves for subdivision of land for residential, commercial and/or industrial development, for city force account projects, and for contracts let by the City of Groves and for the City of Groves by other governmental agencies. 
1.  Design criteria. 
All water lines shall be six (6) inches in diameter or larger and installed in a looped system for residential development. For multi-family, commercial and/or industrial development an eight (8) inch line with a looped system shall be required as a minimum. The director of public works may require larger diameter water lines where the engineering design dictates more volume due to consumption and/or fire protection demands. 
Fire hydrants are to be located as required by the State Fire Insurance Board and shall be equipped with valved "lead". The director of public works, city engineer, and the fire marshal shall approve the water line layout and fire hydrant locations for each development based upon consumption and protection requirements. Fire hydrants shall be placed from two (2) to four (4) feet behind curb lines with steamer connections running parallel with the street line. 
2.  Guidelines. 
The city will use as guidelines for water system installation, those requirements set out in the Texas State Department of Health book "Design Criteria for Water Systems." 
3.  Materials. 
The standard material for water line installation in the City of Groves shall be asbestos-cement pipe with cement lined cast iron fittings and valves. Concrete lined steel pipe or cast iron water lines will be specified for street, roadway, drainage ditch crossings where required by the city public works director. 
4.  Coordination with city. 
The water superintendent shall determine all special water meter locations, locations of points where taps will be made to the city's water system, the cost to the developer for any work to be performed by city forces and any other special requirements related to new development. The issuance of a building permit does not constitute an agreement by the city nor an acknowledgment of the city that water service can and will be provided a development. 
5.  Installation. 
Water lines will generally be located on the front of residential lots and in open areas of multifamily, commercial and/or industrial developments to provide good access to water meters, valves and fire hydrants. 
6.  Tests. 
Water mains shall be tested hydrostatically and evaluation of leakage made from time and pressures as follows: (1) 100 p.s.i. test for 24 hours, or (2) 125 p.s.i. test for 16 hours, or (3) 150 p.s.i. test for 8 hours, the high (150 p.s.i.) test being preferred. Bacteriological test shall be performed with city assistance in accordance with Texas State Department of Health requirements. Tests shall be performed without cost to the city. 
GUIDELINES FOR THE DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION, TESTING AND INSPECTION OF SANITARY SEWER SYSTEMS 
A.  Design. 
1.  Maximum depth of sewers. No main or trunk sanitary sewer line shall have a depth greater than 12 feet below average ground elevation through which the line passes, unless specifically permitted as a special condition to the plans and/or specifications for a particular project. Such special condition shall indicate that all factors of cost, service, and other pertinent engineering facts justify a line of greater depth. 
2.  Minimum depth of sewers. 
a.  No main or trunk sanitary sewer line shall have a depth of cover less than 3 feet below average ground elevation through which the line passes. 
b.  In the event local ground conditions exist, which prevent compliance with the above specified depth, a minimum depth of less than 3 feet may be used if approved by the superintendent of water and sewer. 
3.  Minimum size of sewers. Design of sanitary sewer mains shall be based on a flow capacity of 4500 gallons per acre per day, but in no case shall be of a size less than 8 inches. 
4.  Manholes. 
a.  Manholes shall be placed at all change ingrade or alignment and maximum spacing of manholes shall not exceed 400 feet under normal conditions. Should existing conditions such as street gutters, underground lines, etc., prevent specified spacing, a maximum spacing of 600 feet may be used if approved by superintendent of water and sewer. 
b.  All manholes shall conform to standards adopted and approved by the public works department; such standards to be attached to, and become a part of, these specifications. All manholes shall be coated inside with an acid resistant material; 1/8 inch epoxy, duracrete, or approved equal. 
c.  Sewer lines entering or leaving manholes shall be designed to snugly fit pre-formed or field-drilled openings in manholes. All openings through walls of manholes shall be coated with epoxy material specified above. 
5.  Detention time for sewerage. Detention time for sewerage on any new system to any existing lift station and/or sewer system shall not exceed one hour. In no case shall detention time exceed two hours from any new system to existing treatment plant without approval by the superintendent of water and sewer; unless another method is provided to prevent sewerage from becoming septic. 
6.  Joint deflection. Maximum joint deflection shall be in accordance with ASTM standards applicable to the type of pipe specified. 
B.  Materials. 
1.  No sanitary sewer line of concrete or Orangeburg, shall be acceptable to the city. The city reserves the right to accept or reject any type pipe and/or jointing material as it deems necessary for good construction. 
2.  Jointing material shall be in accordance with ASTM standards applicable to the type of pipe specified. 
3.  Inside diameters of sanitary sewer pipe shall be as indicated on plans and/or specifications within tolerances specified in ASTM standards applicable to the type of pipe specified. 
4.  The city reserves the right to reject any materials delivered to the job site in a damaged condition, or any material not complying with specifications. 
C.  Testing. 
1.  The city reserves the right to require contractors to submit alternate bids on sewer work based on the method of testing to be used. Alternate bids will be submitted on the following methods of testing. 
a.  Exfiltration and/or infiltration. 
b.  The City of Groves standard air test. The city may accept or reject any or all bids as it deems necessary. 
2.  Allowable exfiltration and infiltration rates on sanitary sewer lines being tested shall not exceed 200 gallons per inch of diameter per mile per day. Regardless of the method of testing required, no more than 1200 feet of pipe shall be installed under any one operation before testing. 
3.  If any section of line fails to meet required tests, contractor shall provide continuous photographs of entire section to determine areas where corrective work needs to be done to place the line in proper shape. 
4.  All exfiltration tests, if required, shall be performed under a line head of 6 feet to the top of the pipe. 
5.  Exfiltration and/or infiltration tests, if required, shall be performed upon the completion of each section as specified above under a method agreed upon by the city and contractor, but in no case shall be less than the 200 gallon basis. 
D.  Inspection. 
1.  All contracts for design, construction, inspecting and testing of sanitary sewer work entered into by the city shall designate responsibility for furnishing inspectors on the project. The number of inspectors, if furnished by the city's consulting engineers, shall be approved by the department of public works. 
2.  No major item of sanitary sewer work shall be performed under contract in the absence of a qualified inspector furnished by the city or their consultants. 
3.  All inspectors on sanitary sewer work, whether furnished by the city or their consultants, shall have had not less than three (3) years experience in the field of water and/or sewer line construction. 
4.  All work shall be performed in accordance with and as directed by the city engineer, director of public works and sewer superintendent. 
E.  Award of contract. 
1.  Prior to award of any contract, the city manager and staff shall review plans and procedures contract documents, etc., to determine adequacy of design and acceptability of proposed facility. 
2.  No contract shall be awarded by the city until such time as all permits, easements, or right-of-way necessary for construction have been acquired or are in the process of condemnation. 
3.  Any proposed easements to be secured by the city exempting previously platted subdivisions shall have the following minimum widths. 
a.  10 feet for any easement proposed to contain only one utility. 
b.  20 feet for any easement proposed to contain two or more utilities. 
F.  Plans and specifications. 
    Plans and specifications for sanitary sewer construction shall be approved by the public works department prior to presentation to city council for acceptance. 
STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR STREET CONSTRUCTION 
    Included herein are the Minimum Standard City of Groves Street Construction Standards and Specifications. 
1.  All streets constructed in Groves shall conform to the details and requirements shown on the "Standard Street Cross Sections" and the master street and highway plan for Groves, unless specifically changed and permitted herein. 
2.  All reinforced concrete pavements shall have minimum thickness of six (6) inches and shall be designed to support the traffic loads and conditions required by the master street plan for Groves. Reinforcing wire mesh of 6 gage by 6 gage or approved equivalent reinforcing bar steel shall be used as a minimum unless design requirements are higher. Standard pavement and joint details approved by the City of Groves shall be followed. A comprehensive strength of 3,000 pounds per square inch within 28 days is required for all concrete. The subgrade must be undisturbed native soil with a maximum of two (2) inches of compacted sand cushion below the concrete pavement. Curbs can be placed monolithically or by dowell anchor bars or pins. Curb design will follow existing city standard design, and shall be placed to provide a minimum grade of 0.20%. 
3.  Flexible base streets shall, when permitted in writing by the director of public works, conform to these requirements. The base shall be twenty-four (24) feet wide and eight (8) inches thick compacted to a 95% Proctor Density. The sub-base material shall be shaped, rolled and compacted to a 90% Proctor Density prior to placing any base material. Surface course and prime course of twenty-two (22) feet in width shall be applied during the year only between April and October. The transverse slope on the surface will be from one-fourth (1/4) to one-half (1/2) inch per foot. There will be an eight (8) foot shoulder provided between the edge of the base and ditch slope. Base material for flexible base streets can be sandshell admixture, crushed stone of proper gradation, blast furnace slag and sand-admixture or other materials meeting the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, Texas Highway Department, adopted 1962. 
4.  Design of street section: 
a.  A residential street with a paved width of thirty-one (31) feet shall be used. 
b.  A secondary collector street with a paved width of thirty-seven (37) feet shall be used when serving three (3) or more thirty-one (31) foot residential streets or their equivalent. 
c.  Secondary collector street sections shall be required where connections are made to major streets and highways and at important entrance and exit routes for subdivisions. 
STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR DRAINAGE SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS 
[1.]  The specifications shown below are considered to be the minimum standards required by the City of Groves for subdivision of land for residential, commercial and/or industrial development, for city force account projects and for contracts let by the City of Groves and for the City of Groves by other governmental agencies. 
A.  Storm sewer facilities shall be designed in accordance with curves available from the director of public works and the city engineer. Special problem areas will require additional consideration as established by the director of public works and city engineer. 
B.  Inlets and leads shall be sized to provide adequate entry to other facilities. 
C.  Minimum lead size shall be 15" diameter and minimum slope for 15" lead shall be 0.25% and for 18" lead shall be 0.20%. 
D.  A minimum velocity in pipe flowing full or half full shall be 2.5 feet per second. 
E.  Roughness assumptions, Manning "n": 
(1)  Main ditches, "n" = 0.030 
(2)  Lateral ditches, "n" = 0.035 
(3)  Storm sewers, "n" = 0.013 
(4)  Concrete-lined ditches, "n" = 0.015 
2.  Design criteria-Drainage pump stations: 
A.  Pump station capacity=Comply with D. D. No. 7 and city engineering department. 
B.  Pump station design to balance power source to achieve approximately 50% electrical and 50% natural gas, diesel oil or gasoline-driven units. 
C.  Maximum use must be made of existing borrow areas in site selection of future pump station locations. 
3.  Construction criteria: 
A.  All reinforced concrete pipe shall meet the minimum requirements of the American Society for Testing Materials: "C-76", Reinforced Concrete Culvert Storm Drain and Sewer Pipe. No nonreinforced concrete pipe will be permitted except by special written permission of the director of public works and in no case will nonreinforced concrete pipe be permitted under roadways and/or pavements, adjacent to structure foundations and at depths greater than three (3) feet. Reinforced concrete pipe shall be considered to be the standard storm sewer construction material. 
B.  Precast concrete box pipe may be used when approved in writing by the director of public works, and supported by engineer testing data provided by the developer, contractor and/or owner. 
C.  Bridges, culverts, and all concrete work shall conform to minimum Texas Highway Department Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, adopted by the State Highway Department of Texas, January 2, 1962. 
D.  Corrugated metal pipe with special sizes, shapes and coatings, vitrified clay pipe (extra strength) and other materials for drainage structures may be used for special materials for special applications and shall have the written approval of the director of public works to be used within the City of Groves. 
4.  Other drainage design and specification requirements shall be submitted to the director of public works, who shall determine the standards and requirements for and by the City of Groves for a specific problem and/or project.
